questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with epiphora and probing reveals a soft block at 7 mm. What is the best treatment option for this condition?
questions.solution:
A soft stop 5–8 mm from the punctum implies a canalicular obstruction. Conjunctival Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) is the management of choice for proximal canalicular obstruction at 7mm. If present more than 8 mm from the punctum, the obstruction is probably at the common canaliculus.

The canalicular obstruction is divided as proximal (<8 mm from puncta) and distal (>8 mm from puncta).It can be congenital or acquired. Acquired causes are post-traumatic, repeated syringing or chronic inflammation/infection of the system. It may follow prolonged use of idoxuridine.

Conjunctival DCR (Jones procedure) creates a bypass between the conjunctival fornix and nasal cavity using a Pyrex or silicone tube. The procedure involves creating a fistula through the lacrimal bone, bypassing the blocked canalicular system entirely. The tube is placed from conjunctiva to nose, secured with sutures, and typically left in place for 3-6 months. It has a success rate of around 80% in properly selected cases.

The main advantage is its ability to create an alternative drainage pathway when the proximal lacrimal system is non-functional or absent.

This procedure is specifically indicated for:

  • Canalicular obstruction
  • Failed standard DCR
  • Cases with extensive canalicular damage
  • Congenital absence of canaliculi

The given set of instruments is used for dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR)

Other Options:

Option B: External DCR: An osteotomy is created between the lacrimal sac and nasal cavity through an external skin incision. While effective for nasolacrimal duct obstruction, it cannot address canalicular blocks at 7mm.

Option C: Endonasal DCR: Creates similar bypass as external DCR but through nasal approach. Not suitable for proximal canalicular system problems as it only addresses distal obstruction.

Option D: Dacryocystectomy: Complete removal of lacrimal sac. Too radical for this case and eliminates possibility of future reconstructive procedures. Only indicated in chronic dacryocystitis with mucocele or tumor.

questions.text: A patient undergoing surgery receives succinylcholine for muscle relaxation and later develops hyperthermia, rigidity, tremors, and tachycardia. What is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of malignant hyperthermia. The drug of choice for the condition is dantrolene.

Dantrolene is a direct-acting skeletal muscle relaxant that acts on the RyR1 (ryanodine receptor) calcium channels in the sarcoplasmic reticulum of skeletal muscles and inhibits calcium-induced calcium release. This results in the uncoupling of membrane depolarization and muscle contraction, thus inhibiting muscle contraction.

Malignant hyperthermia is a genetic condition in which mutated RyR1 receptors are present in the skeletal muscles. In the presence of certain triggers, this mutated RyR1 causes severe dysfunction in the RyR1 channels. This leads to the accumulation of calcium ions in the sarcoplasmic reticulum resulting in sustained muscle contraction, rigidity, increased heat production, acidosis, hyperkalemia, and increased end-tidal CO2.

Drugs triggering malignant hyperthermia:

  • Succinylcholine
  • Halothane
  • Isoflurane
  • Sevoflurane

Susceptible patients:

  • Patients with a positive family history. It can be inherited as an autosomal dominant trait.
  • Patients with congenital myopathies.

Treatment: 

Dantrolene sodium is the drug of choice for malignant hyperthermia. Once the diagnosis is made, the causative inhalational agent should be stopped immediately. Supportive treatment with rapid cooling, inhalation of 100% oxygen, control of acidosis, and treatment of hyperkalemia should be given.

questions.text:
A patient with CSOM presented to the OPD with seizures, headache, vomiting and photophobia. On eye examination, homonymous hemianopia was noted. CT brain showed the following findings. Identify the condition.

Chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM)
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette depicting features of seizures, headache, vomiting, and photophobia in a patient with a chronic ear infection and the CT image showing a ring-enhancing lesion point to a diagnosis of a temporal lobe abscess.

Temporal lobe abscess is an intracranial complication that can arise from chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM).

Brain abscess typically progresses through 4 stages.

  • The first stage is the stage of invasion (initial encephalitis), which often goes unnoticed. Symptoms such as headache, malaise, low-grade fever, and drowsiness may be present.
  • The second stage is the stage of localization (latent abscess), during which a capsule forms around the abscess, effectively localizing the pus.
  • The third stage is the stage of enlargement (manifest abscess). The abscess enlarges, leading to increased intracranial pressure (ICP) and the development of edema surrounding the abscess. As a result, symptoms worsen.
  • The final stage is the stage of termination (rupture of abscess). At this point, the abscess expands and eventually ruptures into the ventricle or subarachnoid space, which can result in potentially fatal meningitis.

Characteristic findings associated with temporal lobe abscess include nominal aphasia, homonymous hemianopia, seizures, contralateral motor paralysis, pupillary changes, and oculomotor palsy. Signs of raised ICP like headache, nausea, vomiting, lethargy, drowsiness, confusion, papilledema, and coma may also be seen.

The preferred diagnostic imaging modality for temporal lobe abscess is a CT scan of the brain. This imaging study reveals a ring-enhancing lesion indicative of a brain abscess.

Medical treatment involves initiating intravenous antibiotics, typically metronidazole. Raised ICP can be addressed using dexamethasone or mannitol. Surgical intervention is the definitive management and involves drainage of the abscess followed by radical mastoidectomy to address the underlying CSOM.

Other options:

Option B: Cerebellar abscess is a form of brain abscess and is usually associated with an otogenic source of infection. It can occur as a direct extension through Trautmann's triangle or via retrograde thrombophlebitis. 

An MRI image showing cerebellar abscess is given below:

Option C: Subdural abscess refers to the focal collection of purulent material between the dura mater and the arachnoid mater. 

An MRI image showing subdural abscess is given below:

Option D: Meningitis is the inflammation of the leptomeninges which includes the arachnoid mater and pia mater. It can be due to an infectious or noninfectious etiology. It presents with fever, vomiting, neck stiffness, and signs of meningeal irritation. Ring-enhancing lesion on neuroimaging is not a feature of meningitis.

questions.text: A patient with liver cirrhosis presents with breathing difficulty due to massive ascites. Which is an incorrect statement about this case?

choices.text: Serum albumin ascites gradient of > 1.1 g/dL
Serum albumin ascites gradient of <1.1 g/dL
Ascitic protein level <2.5 g/dL suggests damage to hepatic sinusoids

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement in the given clinical scenario of a patient with liver cirrhosis presenting with breathing difficulty due to massive ascites is a Serum albumin ascites gradient of <1.1.

SAAG >1.1 g/dl and ascitic protein <2.5 g/dl are seen in ascites due to cirrhosis.

Serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG):

  • Calculated by subtracting the ascitic albumin concentration from the serum albumin level.
  • Reflects the pressure within the hepatic sinusoids
  • SAAG ≥1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites are due to increased pressure in the hepatic sinusoids. It reflects the presence of portal hypertension.
  • SAAG <1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites are not related to portal hypertension. It may be due to infection or malignancy.

Ascitic protein level:

  • ≥2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids are normal and are allowing the passage of protein into the ascites. eg. cardiac ascites
  • <2.5 g/dL (Option C)  indicates that the hepatic sinusoids have been damaged and scarred and no longer allow passage of protein. Eg. cirrhosis

Other Options:

Option A: Serum albumin ascites gradient of > 1.1 g/dL is a correct statement as liver cirrhosis presents with SAAG >1.1 g/dl and ascitic protein <2.5 g/dl.

Option D: Secondary hyperaldosteronism is due to aldosterone released in response to the activation of the renin-angiotensin system, and usually seen in cirrhosis, heart failure, and nephrosisand can lead to massive ascites and similar finding as cirrhosis.

Related Pearl: Serum Ascites Albumin Gradient (SAAG)

questions.text: A 22-year-old male was brought to the ER after sustaining an astride injury. Following the trauma, he experienced an urge to urinate but was unable to pass urine. On examination, blood was present at the urethral meatus. What is likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a history of an astride injury, blood at the tip of the meatus, and inability to pass urine are all suggestive of an injury to the bulbar urethra.

Astride injury refers to trauma that occurs when a person falls with their perineum straddling a hard object, leading to blunt perineal trauma.

Urethral injuries can be classified into:

 Type Proximal urethral injury Distal urethral injury
Site of injury
  • Prostatic urethra
  • Membranous urethra
  • Bulbar urethra
  • Penile urethra
Mechanism Secondary to pelvic fracture

Occurs due to a blow to the perineum by:

  • Straddle injury
  • Gymnasium accidents
Clinical features
  • Urinary retention
  • Blood at the urethral meatus
  • High-riding prostate on digital rectal examination (Vermooten sign)
  • Deep perineal hematoma
  • Urinary retention
  • Blood at the urethral meatus
  • Perineal hematoma (Butterfly hematoma)


Note: Urinary bladder rupture occurs due to an injury to the suprapubic region. Extraperitoneal bladder rupture is more common and associated with pelvic fracture. Intraperitoneal bladder rupture is caused by a blow or a fall on the distended bladder. It manifests as sudden severe pain in the hypogastrium and syncope.

questions.text: A 53-year-old male patient was admitted following a road traffic accident. Paradoxical respiration was seen. His chest X-ray is shown below. He was given analgesics and oxygen was administered via face mask but he developed respiratory failure. What is the best line of management in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the X-ray showing contiguous rib fractures on the right side suggest flail's chest.

It is characterized by contiguous rib fractures and paradoxical respiration following blunt trauma to the chest wall. Mechanical ventilation (like Intermittent Positive Pressure Ventilation) is the management of flail chest with respiratory failure.

Flail Chest :

  • A flail chest occurs when a segment of the chest wall does not have bony continuity with the rest of the thoracic cage.
  • This condition results from blunt trauma associated with multiple rib fractures, i.e. 2 adjacent ribs or 3 or more ribs fractured in two or more places.
  • The blunt force required to disrupt the integrity of the thoracic cage typically produces an underlying pulmonary contusion as well.

Clinical Features:

On inspiration, the loose segment of the chest wall is displaced inwards and less air, therefore, moves into the lungs. On expiration, the segment moves outwards(paradoxical respiration).

Diagnosis - Made clinically, not by radiography. To confirm the diagnosis the chest wall can be observed for the paradoxical motion of a chest wall segment for several respiratory cycles and during coughing. Voluntary splinting as a result of pain, mechanically impaired chest wall movement, and the associated lung contusion are all causes of hypoxia and respiratory failure.

The patient is also at high risk of developing a pneumothorax or hemothorax.

Treatment

  • Chest strapping or splinting should be avoided
  • Currently, treatment consists of oxygen administration, adequate analgesia (including opiates) or epidural analgesia and physiotherapy.
  • IPPV (Intermittent Positive Pressure Ventilation) is reserved for cases developing respiratory failure despite adequate analgesia and oxygen.

Other options:

Option A: Chest tube drainage can be done in traumatic pulmonary contusion associated with pneumothorax or hemothorax

Option B: Intrapleural local analgesia can be given if the patient has a chest tube inserted. Since the chest tube drainage is only done after stabilising the patient, intrapleural analgesia is not the best line of treatment at this stage.

Option D: Surgical fixation of the fracture is done only in patients with severe chest injury and pulmonary contusion. Also, surgery should be proceeded only after the patient's condition is stabilised.

questions.text: A patient with a history of diabetes presents with cataract. Which of the following metabolic products is primarily responsible for cataract formation?
questions.solution:
A diabetic cataract occurs due to the accumulation of sorbitol within the lens.

In diabetic patients, increased levels of blood glucose lead to high levels of glucose in the aqueous humor. The excess glucose in the aqueous humor is metabolized into sorbitol through the polyol pathway by the enzyme aldose reductase. Sorbitol is then converted to fructose (option B) by sorbitol dehydrogenase but at a much slower rate. In addition, the polar nature of sorbitol prevents its intracellular removal through diffusion.

Sorbitol and fructose accumulate in the lens and the osmotic stress so produced results in overhydration, hydropic lens fibers, and apoptosis of the lens epithelial cells. Thus, the secondary osmotic overhydration is responsible for cortical opacities in a distinct pattern causing snowflake cataracts as shown below (Option B).

Other Options:

Option A: Mannitol is used to lower intracranial pressure. Features of raised of intracranial pressure are vomiting and papilledema.

Option C: In Classic Galactosemia, deficiency of galactose-1-uridyltransferase leads to the accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate and galactitol (dulcitol).

Related Pearl: Diseases and Associated Cataracts - Images

Wilson's Disease/Chalcosis: Sunflower Cataract

Diabetes mellitus:  Snowflake cataract

Blunt trauma: May present as rosette-shaped cataract

Myotonic dystrophy - Christmas tree cataract

questions.text: Which of the following is the most specific clinical use of Prostate-Specific Antigen (PSA) in the management of prostate cancer?

choices.text: Monitoring the response to treatment in prostate cancer patients
Screening for prostate cancer in all men
Prognosis and survival of prostrate cancer patient
Confirming the diagnosis of prostate cancer

questions.solution:
Monitoring the response to treatment is the most specific clinical use of PSA in prostate cancer management.

Carcinoma of the prostate is the most common malignancy in men above 65 years. The clinical features of prostate cancer are bladder outlet obstruction, pelvic pain, hematuria, arthritis, anaemia, and renal failure. Per rectal examination reveals a hard, nodular, irregularly indurated gland. 

Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) is useful in assessing the follow-up. PSA >10 ng/mL is suggestive of cancer and levels >35 ng/mL are diagnostic of advanced prostate cancer. The prostatic biopsy is indicated when there is a raised PSA level or suspicion of prostate cancer.

PSA's highest specificity comes into play when monitoring treatment response - whether after surgery, radiation, or hormonal therapy - as PSA levels should fall predictably after successful treatment and any rise can specifically indicate disease recurrence or treatment failure. This is particularly evident in post-prostatectomy patients, where PSA should be undetectable, making any detectable level highly specific for recurrence. 

Other Options:
 
Option B: While PSA is used in screening, its specificity is actually lower in this context due to false positives from benign conditions like BPH and prostatitis.
 
Option C: PSA levels do correlate with prognosis, other factors like Gleason score and clinical stage are more specific prognostic indicators. 
 
Option D: PSA's are also elevated in conditions like BPH, hence it cannot help confirm the diagnosis of prostate cancer.

Related Pearl: Types of metastasis(osteoblastic or osteolytic) and their primary:

Predominantly osteoblastic:

  • Prostate cancer
  • Osteosarcoma 
  • Medullary carcinoma thyroid

Mixed osteoblastic and osteolytic:

  • Breast cancer(preponderance toward osteolytic)
  • Lymphoma
  • Urothelial carcinoma 
  • Lung cancer

Predominantly osteolytic:

  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Multiple myeloma 
  • Thyroid carcinoma(except medullary carcinoma thyroid)
  • Gastrointestinal tract carcinoma
  • Malignant melanoma

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with a mass in the neck. Her T4 levels are high with decreased TSH. She undergoes thyroid ablation therapy using I-131. What is the most likely adverse effect associated with I-131 treatment in this patient?
questions.solution:
I-131 is a beta-emitter that is taken up by thyroid tissue as well as differentiated thyroid cancers and is used for treatment of thyroid cancer. The most likely adverse effect is hypothyroidism.

I131 emits both beta and gamma rays. It is used both for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes for thyroid disorders.

I-131 therapy is commonly used to ablate any remaining thyroid tissue after a total thyroidectomy, particularly in cases of thyroid cancer or hyperthyroidism. The goal is to destroy these remaining cells, and while effective, this process almost invariably leads to hypothyroidism. This is an expected and often desired outcome, as the patient will then be managed with levothyroxine replacement therapy to maintain normal thyroid hormone levels.

Other options:

Options A and C: Thyroid storm is a state of severe hyperthyroidism, I-131 destroys thyroid tissue, making hyperthyroidism or thyroid storm unlikely. 

Option D: Osteoporosis is not a known side effect of I-131 therapy.

questions.text: During a splenectomy for a 40-year-old patient with immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), the surgeon must ensure the complete removal of all splenic tissue, including accessory spleens, to prevent symptom recurrence. Accessory spleens are commonly found in specific anatomical locations. Where is the most likely site the surgeon should search for an accessory spleen during the operation?
questions.solution:
The splenic hilum and mesentery represent the most common location for accessory spleens. 

An accessory spleen, a supernumerary spleen, a splenule, or a splenunculus refers to splenic tissue found outside the normal spleen. Around 10% to 30% of the population have accessory spleens; with an individual having one to six accessory splenic buds. Furthermore, the size of an accessory spleen can also vary. Most accessory spleens are approximately 1 centimeter but spleens larger than a few centimeters have also been observed.

Accessory spleens are formed due to incomplete fusion of mesenchymal buds during development. 

Most of the accessory spleens are observed in the splenic hilum, the site at which blood vessels enter the spleen; this is followed by the tail of the pancreas, with about 20% of all accessory splenic tissue appearing here. The rest can be found in areas such as the gastrosplenic ligaments, the lienorenal ligaments, the wall of the stomach, the wall of the intestines, the greater omentum, the mesentery, or even the pelvis or scrotum.

Accessory spleens are of importance during procedures like splenectomies and imaging studies.

In a therapeutic splenectomy, it is necessary to remove all accessory splenic tissue for resolution of symptoms failing which symptoms will continue because an accessory spleen is a functional splenic tissue. Conditions that tend to necessitate this sort of management are hemolytic anemia and chronic idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura.

Accessory spleens are also relevant when evaluating the results of imaging studies; for example, when a patient undergoes a CT scan, accessory spleens can appear similar to lymph nodes or even a neoplastic growth.

questions.text: A carpenter presents with bilateral knee pain and fluctuating swelling in the front of the knee. There is inflammation and tenderness over his knee. MRI of knee is given. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The fluctuating swelling in the front of the knee as well as the image, both suggest Housemaid Bursitis. 

Housemaid's knee is nothing but prepatellar bursitis and is seen in the lower half of patella and upper half of ligamentum patella. Suprapatellar bursa always communicates with the knee joint.

Lower limb major bursitis:

  • Prepatellar Bursitis (Housemaid's Knee)
  • Infrapatellar bursitis (Clergyman's knee) (option C)
  • Trochanteric Bursitis (Above hip abductor) 
    The image shows a sagittal section through the left knee joint (lateral aspect) with bursae.

Other options:

Option A: Olecranon bursitis, also known as draughtsman's elbow (or student's elbow or miner's elbow). Olecranon bursitis is a chronic inflammation of the olecranon bursa, as a result of repetitive minor injuries. It is seen in people who tend to keep their elbow rubbed against the desk. The constant friction against the olecranon bursa can lead to the development of bursitis.

Option D: Gout is characterized by an inflammatory reaction that results in the formation of gouty tophi and arthropathy when monosodium urate (MSU) crystals are deposited in the soft tissue and joints. A definitive diagnosis necessitates the microscopic identification of MSU crystals through joint fluid aspiration.

questions.text: Which of the following is the pathological heart sound seen during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Diastolic murmur is considered to be a pathological change in pregnancy.

It is the ejection systolic murmur which is a physiological change.

CVS physiological changes in pregnancy:

  • Pulse rate: Increases
  • Diastolic BP: Decreases
  • S1: Loud and split
  • S2:Normal
  • S3:prominent (occasional)
  • Jugular venous distension and venous hum
  • Murmurs
    • Ejection systolic murmur at left sternal border.
    • Continous murmur at 2nd-4th intercostal space (known as mammary souffle)
  • Heart is displaced upwards and to the left
  • ECG changes
    • Left axis deviation (due to elevation of diaphragm)
    • T wave inversion, Biatrial enlargement.
    • Mild ST changes in the inferior leads.
    • Premature atrial and ventricular contractions are relatively frequent.

questions.text: A 49-year-old female from Nagaland presented with right-sided hearing loss. On examination, a dull right  tympanic membrane is noted. Enlarged lymph nodes are seen in the posterior triangle of the neck. Which of the following is the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with right-sided hearing loss, dull tympanic membrane (middle ear effusion leading to a conductive hearing loss) and enlarged lymph nodes in the posterior triangle of the neck (cervical lymphadenopathy) is indicative of nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Radiotherapy is the treatment of choice.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is extremely radiosensitive, hence treatment of local and regional disease is invariably radiotherapy. 

  • Stage I and II are treated by radiotherapy alone while
  • Stage III and IV require concomitant radiation and chemotherapy or radiation followed by chemotherapy.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is a malignant tumor of the nasopharynx. The theories for etiology include genetics, infection with Epstein-Barr virus, air pollution, and smoking.

It has three types -

  1. Keratinizing carcinoma
  2. Nonkeratinizing differentiated carcinoma
  3. Nonkeratinizing undifferentiated carcinoma. 

The most common presenting symptom is cervical lymphadenopathy, occurring in 60-90% of cases. The most common site of origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmuller. From here, it can spread extensively in any direction locally. It also can spread lymphatically to the cervical, retropharyngeal, or parapharyngeal lymph nodes. 

Symptoms include:

  • Nasal- Nasal obstruction, denasal speech, nasal discharge, epistaxis.
  • Otologic- unilateral conductive hearing loss, and serous or suppurative otitis media. 
  • Facial pain and reduced corneal reflex- cranial nerve V. (most common cranial nerve to be involved)
  • Squint and diplopia- involvement of cranial nerve VI. 
  • Exophthalmos and blindness- cranial nerve II.
  • Horner's syndrome
  • Cervical lymphadenopathy is the most common presenting symptom.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma can present with Trotter's triad, which includes:

  • Conductive deafness (eustachian tube blockage),
  • Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia due to involvement of CN V and
  • Palatal paralysis due to involvement of CN X

Enlarged lateral retropharyngeal nodes compress the cranial nerve IX, X, and XI causing jugular foramen syndrome. High-resolution contrast-enhanced CT (HR-CECT) of nose and nasopharynx is the investigation of choice.

Other Options: 

Option A: Grommet insertion + steroids would only treat the middle ear effusion symptomatically without addressing the underlying nasopharyngeal malignancy.

Option C: "Wait and watch" would be inappropriate for a suspected malignancy, as delayed treatment could lead to disease progression.

Option D: Radical neck dissection alone would be incorrect as it doesn't address the primary tumor in the nasopharynx, and NPC is primarily treated with radiotherapy rather than surgery due to its anatomical location and radiosensitivity.

questions.text: The cover-uncover test is performed to diagnose various eye conditions. Which of the following is not detected by this test?
questions.solution:
The cover-uncover test cannot detect Amblyopia.

This test consists of two parts:

  • Cover test
  • Uncover test

Cover Test: This is used to detect heterotropia (Manifest Squint) (Option B). Light is first shone and corneal reflections are observed. This is done to assess fixation in the deviating eye. The procedure for testing using an accommodative target and for distance is as follows.

  • The patient is asked to fixate on a target straight ahead.
  • The eye in which deviation is not suspected is covered first. For example, if a right eye deviation is suspected, the left eye is covered.
  • Any movement of the right eye to take up fixation is noted.
  • The following are the possible results:
Movement of the eye Suspected defect
No movements Orthotropia/ Heterotropia of the covered eye
Adduction Exotropia
Abduction Esotropia
Downward movement Hypertropia
Upward movement Hypotropia

The test is then repeated for the opposite eye.

Uncover test: This is used to detect heterophoria (latent squint)(Option A). The test is performed for both near and distant as follows.

  • The patient fixates a distant target straight ahead.
  • The examiner covers an eye for 2-3 seconds and the cover is then removed.
  • If the covered eye had deviated, a re-fixation movement is observed on being uncovered.
  • The following are the possible results based on the re-fixation movements of the eye.
Movement of the eye Suspected defect
No movements Orthophoria
Adduction (Nasal recovery) Exophoria
Abduction Esophoria
Downward/Upward movement Vertical phoria
  • The speed and smoothness of the recovery is noted as well as evidence of the strength of motor fusion.
  • The test is then repeated for the opposite eye.

Other options:

Option C: Amblyopia is a developmental defect of spatial visual processing that occurs in the central visual pathways of the eye.  Generally, a difference of two lines or more on an eye chart test of visual acuity between the two eyes or a best-corrected vision of 20/30 or worse would be defined as amblyopia.

Treatment modalities include:

  • Occlusion of the normal eye (4 to 6 hours/ day) using patches. It allows an amblyopic eye to be used.
  • Penalization: Blurring of vision using atropine. Instilling atropine into the fixing eye, forces the squinting eye to be used for seeing near objects.

Related Pearl: Cover tests in ophthalmology

Cover–uncover test:

  • To detect the presence of heterophoria: Latent squint
  • One eye is covered with the occluder, and the other eye is made to fix an object.
  • In the presence of heterophoria, the eye under the cover will deviate.
  • When the cover is removed, the eye under the cover will return back to its normal.
  • This movement is observed.
  • The direction of movement determines the type of heterophoria.

Direct Cover test:

  • Confirms the presence of manifest squint.
  • Differentiates apparent squint from a manifest squint.
  • The patient is asked to fixate on the point light.
  • The normal-looking eye is covered.
  • In manifest squint, the uncovered eye will move in the opposite direction to take fixation.
  • In apparent squint, there will be no movement of the uncovered eye.

Alternate cover test:

  • In the below image, the patient has right exotropia with left eye fixating.
  • Both eyes move each time the cover alternates from one eye to the other.
  • It reveals if the squint is unilateral or alternate.
  • It differentiates between concomitant and paralytic squint.

questions.text:
A young male presents with left-sided facial weakness. On examination, the patient is able to
wrinkle his forehead and is able to close the right eye partially, and his mouth
deviates towards the right side when smiling. Based on these findings, which of the following statements best
describes the type and location of the lesion?

choices.text: Supranuclear facial palsy on the left side
Infranuclear facial palsy on the right side
Supranuclear facial palsy on the right side
Infranuclear facial palsy on the right side

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young male presenting with weakness of the lower half of the left side of his face and presence of wrinkling on the forehead and normal eyelid closure indicates an upper motor neuron lesion (UMN). The most appropriate diagnosis is supranuclear facial palsy on the right side.

In facial palsy, the angle of the mouth deviates towards the normal side. In this patient, since the mouth deviates towards the right, the left facial nerve is affected. 

In an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion, wrinkling on the forehead and eyelid closure remains intact. In this lesion, the contralateral side of the face is affected. The first-order neurons from the right cerebral hemisphere cross over (right to left) at the cortical level and relay in the left facial nerve nucleus in the pons. From here the second-order neurons (left facial nerve) descend and supply the left side of the face. 

Hence, right UMN lesion causes paralysis of the lower half of the face on the left side and can cause drooping on the left side.

Feature UMN   LMN
Side affected Contralateral Ipsilateral
Facial muscles involved Lower Both upper and lower
Forehead wrinkling Present Absent
Emotional response Normal Affected
Corneal reflex Normal Absent
Taste Intact Affected
Atrophy Absent Present

*Note: Deviation of the angle of mouth should not be confused with drooping of the angle of mouth. Deviation of the angle of the mouth occurs on the normal side due to the action of unaffected facial muscles, while drooping occurs on the affected side.

questions.text:
What is the newly added sixth link in the chain of survival according to the latest AHA update?

AHA-American Health Association
questions.solution:
The newly added sixth link in the chain of survival according to the latest AHA update is Recovery and Rehabilitation.

The AHA (American Heart Association) Chain of Survival is a critical concept in improving survival rates for individuals experiencing cardiac arrest. It consists of a series of actions that, when performed promptly and effectively, increase the chances of survival. Traditionally, the chain includes five key links: early recognition and activation of emergency response, early CPR (cardiopulmonary resuscitation), rapid defibrillation, advanced life support, and post-cardiac arrest care. Each of these steps plays a vital role in ensuring timely intervention, restoring circulation, and providing critical care to improve patient outcomes.

In recent updates, the AHA has introduced a sixth link to the Chain of Survival: Recovery. This emphasizes the importance of long-term rehabilitation, psychological support, and follow-up care for cardiac arrest survivors. Recovery includes interventions such as physical therapy, lifestyle modifications, and emotional support to help survivors regain quality of life and reduce the risk of future cardiac events. This addition highlights the growing recognition that survival is not just about resuscitation but also about ensuring a patient's overall well-being beyond the immediate crisis.

questions.text: The earliest sign seen in pregnancy on ultrasound is?
questions.solution:
The earliest sonographic sign of pregnancy is the visualization of the gestational sac which is seen as the double decidual sign.

The double decidual sac sign (DDSS) is a useful feature on early pregnancy ultrasound to confirm an early intrauterine pregnancy when the yolk sac or embryo is still not visualised. It consists of the decidua parietalis (lining the uterine cavity) and decidua capsularis (lining the gestational sac) and is seen as two concentric rings surrounding an anechoic gestational sac. 

The double decidual sac sign differentiates normal pregnancy from the pseudo-gestational sac of an ectopic pregnancy. Pseudosac is irregular, usually centrally located in the uterus, has no double decidua sign, and the sac remains empty. The illustration below shows the difference: 

Other options:

Option C: Roberts sign shows the presence of gas shadow within the chambers of the heart and in large vessels of the fetus. It is the earliest sign of intrauterine death, seen within 12 hours of death. 

Option D: In a normal intrauterine pregnancy a gestational sac will be visible on TVS by 5 weeks of LMP and the embryonic poles can be visualized by 5.5 weeks. The fetal cardiac activity can be first visualized on TVS around 5.5-6 weeks, when the crown-rump length (CRL) is around 5mm.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones (indicated by the arrow in the image below) giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text:
The patient presents with headache, vomiting and nuchal rigidity. Guarded LP was done and shows turbid CSF. Microscopy shows 90% PMN cells with sugar of 40 mg/dL and protein of 200 mg/dl. Which is correct about the management of this case?

LP-Lumbar puncture

CSF-Cerebro spinal fluid

PMN-Polymorpho nuclear cells
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with headache, vomiting, and nuchal rigidity and a guarded lumbar puncture revealing turbid CSF with 90% PMN cells, a sugar level of 40 mg/dL, and protein of 200 mg/dL is suggestive of bacterial meningitis and the appropriate management includes treatment with ceftriaxone plus vancomycin.

The most common cause of meningitis in adults over 20 years of age is Streptococcus pneumoniae. 

The classic clinical triad of meningitis includes fever, headache, and nuchal rigidity. Other common symptoms include decreased consciousness, nausea, vomiting, photophobia, and seizures. Cutaneous signs such as petechiae, purpura, or an erythematous macular rash may be present.

Kernig's sign and Brudzinski's sign can indicate meningeal irritation. Kernig's sign is positive when there is resistance and pain in extending the knee with the hip flexed at 90 degrees. Brudzinski's sign is positive when there is involuntary flexion of the hips and knees in response to passive neck flexion. However, these signs may not be reliable in certain patient groups, such as infants, elderly individuals, or those with altered mental status.

When bacterial meningitis is suspected, blood cultures should be obtained, and empirical antimicrobial therapy should be initiated without delay. The diagnosis is confirmed by examining cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). CSF analysis shows increased polymorphonuclear leukocytes, decreased glucose concentration, increased protein concentration, and increased opening pressure. CSF bacterial cultures and Gram stain are used to identify the causative organism.

Prompt initiation of empirical antimicrobial therapy is crucial in suspected cases of bacterial meningitis. Commonly used antibiotics include third- or fourth-generation cephalosporins (such as ceftriaxone, cefotaxime, or cefepime) that cover Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, and Haemophilus influenzae and Vancomycin if there is a high suspicion of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infection. Ampicillin with metronidazole is added when Listeria monocytogenes is suspected, particularly in neonates, pregnant women, individuals over 50 years, and immunocompromised individuals.

Other Options:

Option A: Amphotericine B plus flucystosine for at least 2 weeks is used as Induction agent for Cryptococcus with CNS involvement in HIV patient.

Option B: Acyclovir is used as a drug of choice for treating Viral meningitis  especially caused by HSV and is not useful in managing bacterial meningitis.

Option D: Tubercular meningitis can be treated with Rifamapicin plus isoniazid. But they are not indicated in bacterial meningitis
