questions.text:
What is the characteristic feature seen in ectopic pregnancy?

hCG- Human chorionic gonadotropin

choices.text: Ovarian mass with thin layer of endometrium
Empty uterus with adnexal mass and fluid in pelvis
Empty uterus and adnexal mass with ground glass appearance
Trilayer endometrium without an adnexal mass

questions.solution:
An empty uterus with an adnexal mass and fluid in pelvis is the sign most suggestive of an ectopic pregnancy.

A pregnancy is considered ectopic if implantation occurs at a site outside the uterine cavity. The majority of ectopic pregnancies occur in the fallopian tube, the ampulla being the most common site.

The most appropriate management for an unruptured ectopic pregnancy is single-dose methotrexate.

Management of ectopic pregnancy: 

Expectant management: Ectopic pregnancies measuring <3 cm and with declining beta hCG levels initially <1500 mIU/mL may resolve without inter­vention and can be managed expectantly. 

Medical management with single or multiple-dose methotrexate is preferred if:

  • Hemodynamic stability
  • Serum beta-hCG ≥1500 mIU/ml and ≤5000 mIU/mL
  • Mean sac diameter <3.5cm with no fetal cardiac activity detected on transvaginal ultrasound.
  • Patients are willing and able to comply with post-treatment follow-up and have access to emergency medical services within a reasonable time frame in case of a deterioration in the clinical status.

Methotrexate(MTX) can be given as a single IM dose of 50 mg/m2 or as a multiple-dose regimen of 1mg/kg on days 1, 3, 5, and 7.

Surgical management with salpingectomy or salpingostomy is done when:

  • Criteria for expectant and medical management are not met
  • Gestational sac >3.5 cm
  • Fetal cardiac activity present
  • Beta hCG > 5000 mIU/mL
  • Significant pain and hemoperitoneum 
  • Failure of expectant or medical management
  • Clinical status of patient warrants urgent intervention
  • Doubtful compliance with medical management 

Milking of the tube through the fimbriae carries a high risk of bleeding, damage to the tube, the persistence of trophoblastic tissue, and recurrence of ectopic pregnancy. 

Other Options:

Option A: Ovarian mass with thin layer of endometrium  is suggestive of an ovarian cyst.

Option C: Empty uterus and adnexal mass with ground glass appearance is suggestive of a chocolate cyst/ ovarian endometrioma.

Option D: Trilayer endometrium without an adnexal mass is the physiological state of the uterus.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient underwent an emergency laparotomy for grossly contaminated peritonitis due to a perforated hollow viscus. On postoperative day 7, the patient developed signs of wound infection, including erythema, tenderness, and serosanguinous discharge. Subsequently, the wound showed evidence of dehiscence with exposure of underlying tissues. The patient's vital signs are stable, with no evidence of ongoing intra-abdominal sepsis. Considering the current wound status, what should be the most appropriate management strategy for the laparotomy wound?

choices.text: Vaccum assisted negative pressure wound therapy
Antibiotic irrigation of the wound followed by delayed primary closure
Initiating primary wound closure to reduce risk of further contamination

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of burst abdomen and the most appropriate management would be Vacuum-Assisted Closure (VAC) therapy.

Burst abdomen/Acute wound dehiscence is the mechanical wound failure causing separation of the closed abdominal wound associated with abdominal content evisceration. It usually occurs between the 5th and 8th postoperative days.

A sudden giving way feeling from the wound precipitated by bouts of cough, and pinkish serosanguinous discharge can be seen. Omentum or coils of the intestine are forced out of the wound.

Management includes delayed closure with initial mesh wrap or Bogota bag, placing a subcutaneous drain, suitable antibiotic therapy, and prevention of abdominal compartment syndrome as described above and VAC.

Vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) is a method of wound management, which uses negative pressure for spontaneous healing or by lesser reconstructive options. Negative pressure therapy stabilizes the wound environment by reducing wound edema and bacterial load,as well as improves tissue perfusion by angiogenesis and thereby stimulating granulation tissue formation. All this improves the possibility of primary closure of wounds and reduces the need for plastic procedures.The ideal pressure applied is 125 mm Hg. 

Indications of VAC therapy includes diabetic foot ulcers, bed sores,burn injuries,crush injuries, sternal/abdominal wound dehiscence, fasciotomy wounds and animal bites/frostbite wounds.

VAC therapy is contraindicated in patients with malignant wounds such as Marjolin’s ulcer,untreated osteomyelitis, presence of fistulae or necrotic tissue underneath the dressing.

Below is an image showing VAC.

Other Options:

Option B: Antibiotic irrigation followed by delayed primary closure is insufficient because it doesn't address the immediate need for ongoing drainage and decompression, and local antibiotics aren't effective for managing severe contamination.

Option C: Primary closure of the abdomen immediately after laparotomy would be dangerous in this scenario as it risks abdominal compartment syndrome due to ongoing edema and doesn't allow for adequate drainage of contamination; forced closure could lead to tissue necrosis and organ dysfunction.

Options D: Normal saline-soaked gauze dressing is inadequate because it doesn't provide active negative pressure, fails to effectively remove edema and inflammatory exudates, and requires frequent dressing changes that increase infection risk and nursing workload; additionally, it can lead to tissue maceration and doesn't promote wound edge approximation.

questions.text: A young boxer receives a blow near the eye during a boxing match. He presents to the ER with hematoma around eye, CT scan is shown below. Identify the radiological sign shown below?
questions.solution:
The given CT image dipicts 'tear-drop' sign and suggests a blowout fracture.

Tear-drop/ hanging drop sign is characteristic of an orbital "blow-out" fracture, which represents the orbital contents herniating through the floor of the orbit into the maxillary antrum. The most useful projection for detecting an orbital floor fracture is Water’s view.

An orbital blow-out fracture is an isolated fracture of the orbital floor when a large blunt object strikes the globe is called blow out fracture. The orbital contents herniate through the antrum. Clinical signs are periocular swelling (early stage), enophthalmos, ecchymosis and subconjunctival haemorrhage (later stages).

Initial treatment consists of observation, oral antibiotics, ice packs, and nasal decongestants. Indications for surgery in a blowout fracture include diplopia not resolving significantly in the early days after trauma, a fracture with a large herniation of tissues into the antrum, incarceration of tissues in the fracture, resulting in globe retraction and increased applanation tension on attempted upward gaze and enophthalmos. If any of these conditions are present, surgical correction is required within 2 weeks.

The below-given X-ray image in the Water's view shows a 'tear-drop' sign

The optimal time for surgery following a blow-out fracture is 10–14 days.

Indications for surgery in a "blow-out" fracture are as follows:

  • Diplopia not resolving significantly in the early days after trauma
  • A fracture with a large herniation of tissues into the antrum
  • Incarceration of tissues in the fracture, resulting in  globe  retraction and increased applanation tension on attempted upward gaze
  • Enophthalmos greater than 2 mm
     

Other options:

Option A: Panda sign: A radiological finding in sarcoidosis showing bilateral symmetrical uptake in the lacrimal and parotid glands on gallium scan, creating an appearance resembling a panda's face.

Option B: Dalrymple’s sign is the commonest and earliest sign of Grave's ophthalmopathy. It is due to overactivity of levator aponeurosis and Müller's muscle. Here the upper lid margin is at level with or above the superior limbus, causing the upper sclera to become visible (scleral show).

Option C: Munson's sign is seen in keratoconus. There is a localized bulging of the lower eyelid that can be seen in a downward-looking eye.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a 3cm sub-areolar mass in her left breast. She reports bloody nipple discharge but denies pain, redness or systemic symptoms. On examination, the mass is firm and non-tender. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of unilateral bloody nipple discharge with a palpable mass beneath the areola and histopathology showing a central fibrovascular core with papillae arborizing within the lumen are suggestive of a solitary intraductal papilloma.  

Intraductal papilloma is a benign, proliferative breast disorder without atypia. It is defined as Localized hyperplasia of the ductal epithelium within the duct. According to the ANDI (Aberrations of normal development and involution of breast tissue) classification, it is an aberration of normal epithelial turnover. It comprises a central fibrovascular core and papillary projections of the epithelium and myoepithelial cells. The papillary lesions in a duct are of three types:

  • Solitary papilloma
  • Papillomatosis: five or more papillomas
  • Juvenile papillomatosis, also called Swiss cheese disease

Intraductal papilloma is commonly seen in premenopausal women. It is the most common cause of spontaneous nipple discharge from a single duct. These papillomas are located close to the nipple and are associated with bloody nipple discharge. Sometimes, a palpable mass under the areola may be present. 

A triple assessment, consisting of clinical examination, imaging, and pathology, should be performed to exclude carcinoma. Ultrasonography may reveal a dilated subareolar duct and a papillary growth within. A ductoscopy shows a firm, palpable nodule inside the duct. Most duct papillomas are located up to a distance of 5 cm from the nipple.

The treatment for single-duct discharge is microdochectomy, which involves making a tennis racquet-shaped incision and removing the papilloma and a single duct involved. Hadfield’s procedure(cone excision of ducts) is used when multiple ducts are involved. 

Other options:

Option A. Ductal carcinoma in situ: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is a neoplastic proliferation of epithelial cells limited by the basement membrane. It involves the ducts and lobules. It is not associated with a loss of E-cadherin expression. It typically presents as a suspicious area on a mammogram rather than a palpable mass with bloody discharge.

Option C. Lobular carcinoma in situ: Histologically, LCIS consists of a monomorphic population of cells with oval or round nuclei and small nucleoli involving ducts and lobules. Mucin-positive signet ring cells are commonly present. The histological image is given below:

Option D. Fibroadenoma: This is a benign breast tumor that is usually firm, rubbery, and mobile. They occur in women in their 20s and 30s, and they are frequently multiple and bilateral. Histology shows delicate and often myxoid stroma that resembles normal intralobular stroma. The epithelium may be surrounded by stroma (pericanalicular pattern) or compressed and distorted by it (intracanalicular pattern) as shown below:

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with prostate cancer. What is the mode of spread of prostate cancer to the lumbar vertebra?
questions.solution:
In prostate cancer, metastasis to the lumbar vertebra is through the Batson's venous plexus.

Batson venous plexus is a valveless vertebral venous plexus communicating with the prostatic venous plexus. Carcinoma of the prostate metastasizes to the bone usually by the bloodstream through this Batson plexus. The bones most frequently involved are the pelvic bones and the lower lumbar vertebrae. The femoral head, ribcage and skull are other common sites. Other routes of spread of prostate carcinoma are local spread to the seminal vesicles, bladder neck, trigone, and lymphatic spread.

Carcinoma of the prostate is the most common malignancy in men above 65 years. The clinical features of prostate cancer are bladder outlet obstruction, pelvic pain, hematuria, arthritis, anaemia, and renal failure. Per rectal examination reveals a hard, nodular, irregularly indurated gland. 

Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) is useful in assessing the follow-up. PSA >10 ng/mL is suggestive of cancer and levels >35 ng/mL are diagnostic of advanced prostate cancer. The prostatic biopsy is indicated when there is a raised PSA level or suspicion of prostate cancer.

Localized cancer is treated by radical prostatectomy and radiation therapy, while in advanced cancer palliative and hormone ablation should be carried out. 
 
Options B, C and D: Arterial spread is exemplified by lung cancer's common metastasis to the brain, breast cancer's spread to brain and liver, and choriocarcinoma's predilection for lung metastases. Lymphatic spread is demonstrated by breast cancer's typical progression to axillary nodes, head and neck cancers spreading to cervical nodes, and melanoma's spread to regional lymph node basins. Direct spread occurs when cancers invade adjacent structures, such as pancreatic cancer extending into the duodenum and stomach, lung cancer invading the chest wall, or colorectal cancer penetrating through the bowel wall into nearby tissues. 

Related Pearl: Types of metastasis(osteoblastic or osteolytic) and their primary:

Predominantly osteoblastic:

  • Prostate cancer
  • Osteosarcoma 
  • Medullary carcinoma thyroid

Mixed osteoblastic and osteolytic:

  • Breast cancer(preponderance toward osteolytic)
  • Lymphoma
  • Urothelial carcinoma 
  • Lung cancer

Predominantly osteolytic:

  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Multiple myeloma 
  • Thyroid carcinoma(except medullary carcinoma thyroid)
  • Gastrointestinal tract carcinoma
  • Malignant melanoma

questions.text: Which part of the placenta is shown in this picture?
questions.solution:
Fetal side of the placenta is depicted in the picture.  

Placenta has two components - basal plate (the one on the maternal side) and chorionic plate (the one towards the fetal side which gives rise to the chorionic villi).

Usually, in a normal placenta, both basal and chorionic plates end simultaneously at the margin of the placenta. 

The fetal surface, known as the chorionic plate, creates the roof of the intervillous space and is covered by the amnion, a thin avascular membrane. This plate contains chorionic vessels that branch from the umbilical vessels and is composed of distinct layers including the amniotic epithelium, connective tissue layer, primary stem villi containing fetal vessels, and both cytotrophoblast and syncytiotrophoblast layers. This complex arrangement facilitates the crucial transfer of nutrients and gases between mother and fetus.

The placental structure, from the maternal aspect, begins with the basal plate which forms the maternal floor of the intervillous space (Option B). This critical interface contains multiple components arranged in layers, including the decidual layer (composed of decidual cells from the endometrium) (Option A), the fibrinoid or Nitabuch's layer (containing fibrin deposits marking the boundary between maternal and fetal tissues), and the cytotrophoblastic shell. The basal plate is characterized by grooves that create cotyledons and houses the spiral arteries and veins from maternal circulation, making it essential for maternal-fetal exchange  (Option D).

questions.text: A patient has been diagnosed with mitral stenosis. What is the determinant of the severity of mitral stenosis?
questions.solution:
The more severe the thickening, the earlier the opening snap occurs in diastole. Hence, decreased intervals between S2 and opening snap (OS) indicate increased stenosis severity.

The auscultatory findings which are suggestive of increased severity of murmur are:

  • Decreased interval between S2/ A2 and opening snap(OS).
  • Increased duration of the diastolic murmur.

Other options:

Option A: Loud S1 is seen in the initial stages of MS when the mitral leaflets are flexible. When there is further thickening and calcification of the leaflets, they become immobile, and the amplitude of S1 decreases.

Option B: In mitral stenosis, an S3 heart sound is typically absent due to restricted ventricular filling. However, if present, it may indicate associated heart failure or significant left atrial enlargement leading to increased early diastolic flow.

Option D: A prolonged S1 is heard in conditions like mitral stenosis, where delayed valve closure occurs due to increased left atrial pressure. It results from the stiff mitral valve remaining open longer in diastole before forcefully shutting in systole.

questions.text: A child was eating a custard apple when a seed suddenly became lodged in the throat, causing coughing and respiratory distress. On palpation, a knob-like structure was felt, and auscultation revealed an audible thud. What is the likely location of the obstruction?
questions.solution:
A history of cough, respiratory distress, a palpable knob and on auscultation, an audible thud in a child suggests a foreign body lodged in the trachea. 

The classical signs associated with tracheal foreign bodies: (1) asthmatoid wheeze (2) audible slap produced from foreign body contact with the trachea, and (3) palpable thud over the trachea.

The next step in managing this patient is to obtain a chest X-ray, followed by bronchoscopic removal of the foreign body. 

Although foreign body aspiration accounts for most cases in children, there is an approximate 20% incidence among adults. The most common site of foreign body lodging is the bronchus. Foreign body aspiration into the airway has three stages: immediate symptoms of coughing and choking, an asymptomatic interval, and later complications such as fever, atelectasis, and pneumonia.

When a patient presents with a history of choking, detailed history taking and physical examination of the nose, oral cavity, pharynx, neck, and lungs are necessary.

The next step for suspected foreign body aspiration is to obtain a chest X-ray, including the abdomen, despite most foreign bodies being radiolucent.

Secondary findings on the X-ray can indicate foreign body involvement, such as air trapping, atelectasis, obstructive emphysema, asymmetric hyperinflation, mediastinal shift, or consolidation. While a CT scan has high accuracy, it is not typically performed due to radiation risks. 

The treatment of choice for a foreign body in the airway is its endoscopic removal with a rigid instrument, usually a bronchoscope, by a specialist otolaryngologist or pulmonologist. Bronchoscopy must be performed even if there is a high suspicion of an airway foreign body despite negative or inconclusive imaging. 

Other options:

Option A:  Respiratory distress is seen if the esophageal foreign body impinges on the larynx. Inspiratory stridor would be heard due to the narrowing of the airway at the level of the vocal cords, which is critical for airflow. 

Option B:  When a foreign body is in the bronchus (typically right main bronchus due to its more vertical orientation), it characteristically causes expiratory stridor or wheeze, decreased breath sounds on the affected side, and mediastinal shift; this is because air can enter during inspiration but gets trapped during expiration, creating a ball-valve effect.

Option C:  A foreign body lodged in the esophagus will present with symptoms of choking, gagging, and coughing followed by excessive salivation, dysphagia, food refusal, vomiting, or pain in the neck and throat. When foreign bodies are lodged in the oesophagus, the flat surface of the object is seen in the anteroposterior view and the edge is seen in the lateral view. The reverse is true for objects in the trachea.

questions.text: A 26-year-old actor came with complaints of being unable to focus on his work. He worked for a short while in various occupations, before deciding he wanted to be an actor. After attending several auditions, he discovered that he was easily distracted, needed help remembering his lines, and even drifted off during reading. Identify the disorder in the given scenario.
questions.solution:
The disorder in the given scenario can be identified as Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.

Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a neuropsychiatric condition affecting children, adolescents, and adults around the world, characterized by a pattern of diminished sustained attention, and increased impulsivity or hyperactivity. They often have significant impairment in academic functioning as well as in social and interpersonal situations.

ADHD was historically believed to be a childhood condition resulting in delayed development of impulse control that would be generally outgrown by adolescence. Over the past few decades, a significant number of adults with ADHD have been found, diagnosed, and given effective treatment. Utah Criteria for Adult Attention-Deficit/ Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) include retrospective diagnosis of ADHD in childhood and evidence of current impairment from ADHD symptoms in adulthood. 

Adults with residual illness exhibit impulsivity and attention deficit symptoms, such as trouble focusing, difficulty organizing and finishing tasks, increased distractibility, and making snap decisions without considering the repercussions. Many individuals with the illness also suffer from a secondary depressive disorder, which is linked to low self-esteem as a result of their diminished performance, which has an impact on social and professional functioning.

A variety of medications and behavioural interventions are used to treat ADHD. The most widely used medications are methylphenidate and atomoxetine. A combination of medication and psychotherapy is more effective than either treatment alone.

Other options: 

Option A: Patients with chronic depression will usually have low mood and loss of interest in general and this does not fit into the given scenario.

Option B: Borderline personality disorder is characterized by extraordinarily unstable affect, mood, behaviour, object relations, and self-image. Instability in affect due to a marked reactivity of mood. It is characterized by repeated suicidal behaviour, unstable interpersonal relationships, prolonged feelings of emptiness, inappropriate, intense anger, or difficulty in controlling anger. 

Option C: Manic disorder is usually seen with grandiosity and other psychotic symptoms that do not fit into the given situation.

questions.text:
A boy comes with the history of passing of black urine during the night time, and on further investigation, CD55 and CD59 markers were negative . Which condition is the boy most likely suffering from?

ITP-Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura

AIHA-Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia

PNH-Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria
questions.solution:
The boy is most likely suffering from Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH). This condition is characterized by hemolysis and dark-coloured urine (due to hemoglobinuria), and the negative CD55 and CD59 markers indicate a deficiency of protective proteins in red blood cells, which is a hallmark of PNH.

PNH is an acquired chronic hemolytic anaemia with persistent intravascular hemolysis.

It is due to an acquired mutation in the X-linked phosphatidylinositol class A PIG-A gene causing deficiency of GPI. GPI is a glycolipid that anchors membrane protective factors such as CD59 and CD55 to the membrane. The deficiency of CD55 and CD59 makes the RBC sensitive to complement-mediated intravascular hemolysis.

PNH is characterized by hemolytic anaemia, pancytopenia, and venous thrombosis involving cerebral, hepatic, renal, portal, and abdominal veins.

Laboratory findings show-

  • Decreased haemoglobin concentration
  • Decreased haptoglobin levels 
  • Increased unconjugated haemoglobin
  • Elevated LDH 
  • Increased reticulocyte count 
  • Negative Coombs test.

PNH is diagnosed using flow cytometry.

Note-

The tendency of red cells to lyse at night is explained by a slight decrease in blood pH during sleep. This increases the activity of complement.

Other Options:

Option A: Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) occurs due to antibody-mediated destruction of platelets. Autoantibodies, most often directed against platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb–IIIa or Ib–IX are found. The patient can present with petechiae, ecchymoses, easy bruising, nosebleeds, and gingival bleeding. The disease manifests first with melena, hematuria, or excessive menstrual flow.

Option B: In Acquired Immune Hemolytic Anemia(AIHA) , autoantibodies against RBC antigens are produced which coat the RBC membrane. The Fc portion of the antibody is recognized by the Fc receptor on macrophages causing phagocytosis. RBC destruction takes place in extravascular sites where macrophages are abundant.It is divided into warm and cold subtypes.

Option D: Polycythemia vera is a chronic myeloproliferative disorder associated with a mutation of Janus kinase-2 (JAK2) which results in neoplastic proliferation of hematopoietic progenitor cells. Findings include high hemoglobin, hematocrit, or red cell count which are seen in other causes of erythrocytosis. Aquagenic pruritis is one of the most common symptoms associated with polycythemia vera. 

Related Pearl: Classification of Hemolytic Anemias

Hemolytic anemias can be classified in 2 ways:

1. Based on the type of defect:

Type  Intracorpuscular Defects Extracorpuscular Factors
Hereditary

Hemoglobinopathies

Enzymopathies

Membrane-cytoskeletal defects

 Familial (atypical) hemolytic uremic syndrome
Acquired Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH)

Mechanical destruction (microangiopathic)

Toxic agents

Drugs

Infectious

Autoimmune

2. Based on the sites of hemolysis:

Intravascular hemolysis:

  • Mechanical injury
    • Trauma caused by cardiac valves 
    • Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemias (hemolytic uremic syndrome, disseminated intravascular coagulation, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura) 
    • Repetitive physical trauma
  • Complement fixation (antibody-mediated destruction)
    • Hemolytic disease of the newborn- ABO incompatibility
    • Transfusion reaction  
    • Drug-induced 
  • Infections of red blood cells 
    • Malaria
    • Babesiosis
  • Exogenous toxic factors - clostridial sepsis

Extravascular hemolysis:

  • Hereditary spherocytosis
  • Thalassemia
  • Sickle cell anemia
  • Hemolytic disease of the newborn- Rh incompatibility

Both intravascular and extravascular hemolysis:

  • G6PD deficiency
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia

questions.text: A patient presented with abnormally dilated, tortuous veins over the leg, clinically falling into C4a category. Which of the following is the correct treatment in this patient?
questions.solution:
The most apporpriate therapy for C4a category of varicose veins is endothermal laser ablation.

Varicose veins are subcutaneous dilated, tortuous veins 3mm or more in diameter. They commonly present with a sensation of dragging pain, heaviness, itching or burning over the affected area or the whole limb, and swelling of the feet. These symptoms increase throughout the day or with prolonged standing and are relieved by elevation or compression hosiery.

Risk factors:

  • Female gender
  • Increasing age
  • Increasing body mass and height
  • Pregnancy
  • Family history
  • Smoking
  • Occupations involving prolonged standing

 According to the CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology) classification, the clinical classification of venous disease is as follows:  

  • C0: no signs of venous disease
  • C1: telangiectasia or reticular veins
  • C2: varicose veins
  • C2r: recurrent varicose veins 
  • C3: edema
  • C4: Skin changes due to chronic venous disease
  • C4a: pigmentation or eczema (including malleolar flare)
  • C4b: lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche
  • C4c: corona phlebectatica 
  • C5: healed venous ulcer
  • C6: active venous ulcer
  • C6r: recurrent active venous ulcer

The images below show C5 and C6 - healed and active venous ulcers respectively,

Duplex ultrasound is the investigation of choice for varicose veins.

The management of varicose veins is as follows:

Incompetence Management
Great saphenous vein (GSV) and saphenofemoral (SFJ) 
  • Endothermal ablation (gold standard treatment for varicose veins). It includes:
  • Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA)
  • Radiofrequency ablation (RFA)
  • Trendelenburg procedure (Flush Ligation of Saphenofemoral Junction (SFJ) after ligation of 6 tributaries) ± stripping (retrogradely up to the knee, to prevent saphenous nerve injury.)     
Short saphenous vein (SSJ) and saphenopopliteal (SPJ)
  • Flush ligation of SPJ (Stripping is not done to prevent sural nerve injury)
  • Endothermal ablation:
  • Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA)
  • Radiofrequency ablation (RFA)
Perforator 
  • Dodd and Crockett surgery - Multiple subfascial ligations
  • Subfascial endoscopic perforator surgery (SEPS) - smaller incision, so cosmetically better
  • Endothermal ablation:
  • Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA)
  • Radiofrequency ablation (RFA)

New treatment modalities:

  • Foam sclerotherapy - The Tessari method is a widely used method to prepare foam for sclerotherapy. Sclerosant: air ratio taken is 1:3 or 1:4
  • Endovenous glue therapy - endoluminal application of cyanoacrylate adhesive 
  • TriVex - Transilluminated powered phlebectomy

Other Options:

Option A: Sclerotherapy is primarily indicated for smaller veins (1-6mm in diameter), particularly reticular veins and telangiectasias, as well as residual or recurrent veins after previous surgery; it involves injecting a sclerosing agent that causes endothelial damage and subsequent fibrosis, with foam sclerotherapy being particularly effective for larger truncal veins.  

Option B: Stripping is typically reserved for cases involving the great or small saphenous veins with documented reflux, especially when the veins are large (>6mm), tortuous, or when there are significant symptoms such as pain, swelling, or skin changes.

Option D: Compression stockings serve both as primary therapy and adjunctive treatment across all stages of venous disease - they are used as conservative management for early-stage disease, pre- and post-procedurally for all interventions, and as long-term management to prevent recurrence.

questions.text:
Patient after head trauma responds to verbal stimuli with confusion, opens eyes to speech and follows simple commands and is able to localise pain. What is the GCS score?

GCS-P: Glasgow coma scale-Pupillary reactivity score
questions.solution:
The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) for the given case scenario is 12.

GCS for the given case is 12 (E3 V4 M5). 

  • E: eye opening to speech - 3
  • V: confused - 4
  • M: localizes to pain - 5

GCS is used in the assessment of patients with a head injury.

Minimum GCS value: 3

Maximum GCS value: 15

The severity of head injury based on GCS:

  • Mild- 13-15
  • Moderate- 9-12
  • Severe- 3-8

Pupillary reactivity score:

  • Both pupils unreactive to light- 2
  • One pupil unreactive to light- 1
  • Neither pupil unreactive to light- 0

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal/flexion 4
Abnormal flexion/Decorticate posturing  3
Extension/Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils Unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

Half-hourly for 2 hours,
Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
Then 2-hourly thereafter.
Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A patient presents with nasal obstruction and merciful anosmia. Greenish-black crusts were found in the nasal cavity of a patient. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of merciful anosmia and greenish-black crusts in the nasal cavity points to a diagnosis of atrophic rhinitis.

Atrophic rhinitis is a chronic inflammation of the nose characterized by atrophy of nasal mucosa and turbinate bones. The exact etiology of this condition is not known. It is more common in females and starts around puberty. 

Clinically patients present with nasal obstruction, foul odor, and merciful anosmia. Merciful anosmia is when the patient has marked anosmia and is unable to smell the foul odor coming from their nose.

On examination of the nose, greenish or greyish crusting of the nasal passage, pale nasal mucosa, atrophied nasal turbinates, and epistaxis following the removal of the crusts. The roomy nasal cavity is seen due to the resorption of bones of the turbinates.

Treatment:

  • Nasal irrigation - using warm saline or an alkaline solution composed of sodium bicarbonate 1 part, sodium biborate 1 part, sodium chloride 2 parts in 280 mL of water.
  • Local antibiotics - Kemicetine antiozena solution containing chloromycetin, estradiol, and vitamin D2. 
  • 25% glucose in glycerine, estradiol spray, systemic use of streptomycin, potassium iodide, placental extract.
  • Surgical management:
    • Young's operation: In this procedure, flaps are raised within the nasal vestibule and both the nostrils are completely closed and are opened after 6 months. During this time, the mucosa may revert to normal and the crusting is reduced.
    • Modified Young's operation: In this procedure, the nostrils are partially closed and thereby avoiding the discomfort of complete closure of the nostrils. The results are the same compared to Young's operation.
    • Narrowing of the nasal cavity can be done by submucosal injection of Teflon paste, or by insertion of fat, cartilage, or Teflon strips under the mucoperiosteum.

Other options:

Option B: Rhinitis sicca is a crust-forming disease seen in people who work in hot, dry, and dusty surroundings, e.g. bakers and iron- and goldsmiths. It usually affects the anterior third of the nose, particularly the nasal septum.  The affected areas develop crusts, which may result in bleeding, ulceration, and even septal perforation on removal.

Option C: Allergic rhinitis is associated with inferior turbinate hypertrophy and can cause chronic nasal obstruction. It is characterized by watery nasal discharge, sneezing, and itching in the nose.

Option D: Hypertrophic rhinitis is a condition characterized by the thickening of mucosa, submucosa, seromucinous glands, periosteum, and bone. It occurs as a result of recurrent nasal infections, chronic sinusitis, and chronic irritation of the nasal mucosa. Symptoms include nasal obstruction, discharge, and headache.

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Atrophic Rhinitis

  • More common in females 
  • Usually starts at puberty
  • It is a bilateral condition
  • Symptoms:
    • Foul smell from the nose
    • Nasal obstruction in spite of roomy chambers due to large crusts filling nasal cavity
    • Epistaxis on removing of the crusts
    • Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements (merciful anosmia)
  • Signs:
    • Greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum
    • After removal of crusts, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates
    • Nasal mucosa appears pale

Related Pearl: Etiology of atrophic rhinitis

Etiology of primary atrophic rhinitis:

  • Hereditary- Involves more than one member of a family
  • Endocrinal- More common in females, starts at puberty and regresses after menopause
  • Racial- More common in mongoloid and caucasian races
  • Nutritional deficiency- Vitamin A, D, iron deficiencies
  • Autoimmune- Antigens of the nasal mucosa
  • Organism- Klebsiella ozaenae

Etiology of secondary atrophic rhinitis:

  • Specific infections like syphilis, lupus, leprosy and, rhinoscleroma
  • Long-standing purulent sinusitis
  • Radiotherapy to nose
  • Excessive surgical removal of turbinates
  • Diphtheroids, Proteus vulgaris, Escherichia coli, staphylococci and streptococci

questions.text: Identify the procedure being done.
questions.solution:
The given image shows an intrauterine balloon tamponade.

A Bakri postpartum balloon may be inserted and inflated to tamponade the endometrial cavity and stop bleeding. It is used to manage refractory uterine atony.

The insertion process requires two or three team members. First-person to perform abdominal sonography during the procedure. Another to place the deflated balloon into the uterus and stabilize it. The third person instills normal saline to inflate the balloon, rapid infusion of at least 150 mL followed by further instillation over a few minutes for a total of 300 to 500 mL to arrest hemorrhage. Once the bleeding subsides, the catheter is generally removed after 12 to 24 hours.

Segstaken­ Blakemore, Rusch, and ebb balloons, Foley's catheter, and condom catheters can also be used instead.

In the technique where Foley's catheter is utilized, a 24F-30F size of the catheter with 30ml balloon is used, the tip is guided into the uterine cavity and filled with 60-80ml of saline. In some cases, if the balloon ruptures, a 34F with 60ml balloon can be used. Once the bleeding subsides, the catheter can be removed after 12 -24 hours.

Types of PPH:

Primary/early PPH: Hemorrhage occurring within 24 hours of childbirth. Causes include:

  • Atony: Primi, grand multipara, over distended uterus, hydramnios, precipitate labor, prolonged labor, uterine malformations, fibroid uterus
  • Trauma: Instrumental deliveries, episiotomy, precipitate labor, macrosomia
  • Retained tissues: retained placenta, blood clots
  • Bleeding disorders: Sepsis, Intrauterine death, HELLP syndrome.

Secondary/ late PPH: Hemorrhage occurring after 24 hours and up to 12 weeks postpartum. Causes include: 

  • Placental polyp: Retained products undergo necrosis with fibrin deposition and eventually form a placental polyp, which on detachment from the myometrium causes brisk hemorrhage.
  • Abnormal involution of the placental site.
  • Retention of placental cotyledon or products of conception.
  • Uterine artery pseudoaneurysm.
  • Endometritis
  • Coagulopathy

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not reversed with the administration of glycopyrolate?

choices.text: Muscle weakness due to neuromuscular blockade

questions.solution:
Glycopyrrolate can reverse all conditions except muscle weakness caused by neuromuscular blockade.

Anticholinergic drugs like glycopyrrolate and atropine are not used to reverse neuromuscular blockade. They only attenuate the undesirable muscarinic effects of anticholinesterase reversal agents.  

Reversal agents commonly used in clinical practice:

  • Cholinesterase inhibitors - Neostigmine (most common), edrophonium, and pyridostigmine.
  • Sugammadex, a cyclodextrin, is the first selective relaxant binding agent for rocuronium and vecuronium.
  • L-cysteine causes the inactivation of gantacurium.

questions.text: A 6-month-old child is noted to have muscle weakness. Vitals Pulse: 80/min, BP 70/50 mm Hg. The workup shows metabolic alkalosis with hypokalaemia and hypomagnesemia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 6-month-old child presenting with muscle weakness with a pulse of 80/min and BP 70/50 mm Hg (hypotension) with metabolic alkalosis, hypokalaemia and hypomagnesemia is suggestive of Gitelman syndrome.

Gitelman syndrome occurs due to a mutation of Na+/Cl- cotransporter in the distal collecting tubule (DCT). The resulting impairment of the tubular transport leads to the following features:

  • Mild natriuresis with normal-low BP.
  • Increased renin and aldosterone.
  • Hypokalemia.
  • Metabolic alkalosis.
  • Hypercalcemia and hypocalciuria.
  • Hypomagnesemia.

The clinical features of this condition are similar to the effects of thiazide diuretics. These drugs also act on the Na+/Cl- cotransporter. Hence, the response to thiazide diuretics may be blunted. Treatment is with potassium-sparing diuretics like spironolactone and amiloride.

Option A: Bartter syndrome affects the Na+/K+/Cl- channels. It causes hypocalcemia and hypercalciuria.

Option C: Conn syndrome (primary hyperaldosteronism) is caused by excessive aldosterone production, leading to hypertension and low potassium, while Gitelman syndrome is a genetic kidney disorder causing low potassium, low magnesium, and low blood pressure. Unlike Conn syndrome, Gitelman syndrome does not cause hypertension but leads to chronic electrolyte imbalances.

Option D: Dent's disease is a rare X-linked renal disorder characterized by proximal tubulopathy, leading toband progressive kidney dysfunction. It is caused by mutations in the CLCN5 or OCRL genes, affecting renal tubular function.

questions.text: The INR ratio recommended for the administration of warfarin in patients with mechanical heart valves is ______________
questions.solution:
The INR ratio recommended for the administration of warfarin in patients with mechanical heart valves is around 2.5-3.5.

Prothrombin time is sensitive to the reduction in levels of prothrombin, factor VII, and factor X. The test is performed by adding thromboplastin, which is a reagent containing tissue factor, phospholipid and calcium to citrated plasma and determining the time to clot formation.

Due to the variable sensitivity of thromboplastin, the International normalized ratio (INR) was developed to standardize the reporting of prothrombin time. In INR, the patient’s prothrombin time is divided by mean normal prothrombin time and this ratio is multiplied by the International Sensitivity Index (ISI) of the particular thromboplastin reagent.

Warfarin therapy should be monitored with INR every 3–4 weeks. The target INR is 2.0–3.0. In patients with mechanical heart valves, the target INR is 2.5–3.5.

 

Other options:

Option A: The INR range of 1.0-1.5 means the state of body is in hypercoaguable state and itis too low for beneficial effects, hence it is not recommended.

Option B: In most of the patients on regular warfarin therapy,  the  target INR is around 2.0-3.0, but it is not recommended in patients with mechanical heart valve.

Option D: INR >3.5 (3.5- 4.5)can result in increased adverse effects like bleeding and is not recommended for any condition.

questions.text: A patient with grade 4 haemorrhoids underwent surgery. Identify the instruments used during the procedure from the image below.
questions.solution:
The instruments depicted above are the components of a hemorrhoid banding kit.

Hemorrhoids are cushions of submucosal tissue containing venules, arterioles, and smooth muscle fibers that are located in the anal canal. They can be classified according to their location into 2 types:

  • Internal hemorrhoids 
  • External hemorrhoids

External hemorrhoids are distal to the dentate line and are covered with anoderm; these may engorge causing pain. Thrombosis of these external hemorrhoids causes severe pain. Internal hemorrhoids are characterized by bright red, painless bleeding, or prolapse.

Internal hemorrhoids are stratified into four grades as follows:

GRADE

SYMPTOMS AND SIGNS

First degree

Bleeding; no prolapse

Second degree

Prolapse with spontaneous reduction

Third degree

Prolapse requiring manual reduction

Fourth degree

Prolapsed, cannot be reduced

Management of external hemorrhoids: 

External hemorrhoids do not require treatment unless they become thrombosed. Acutely thrombosed external hemorrhoids cause intense pain and perianal mass during the first 24 to 72 hours. Patients who present within 72 hours of thrombosis are treated with elliptical excision performed under local anesthesia.

If the patient presents to the hospital after 72 hours, then it is treated conservatively with analgesics and a sitz bath. Once the symptoms come down, definitive surgery is performed. 

Management of internal hemorrhoids:

Bleeding from grade 1 and grade 2 hemorrhoids often improves with the addition of dietary fiber, stool softeners, increased fluid intake, and avoidance of straining.

Grade 1, grade 2, and some grade 3 hemorrhoids with only an internal component can be treated with simple procedures like rubber band ligation, sclerotherapy, infrared and laser coagulation, and cryotherapy.

Rubber band ligation involves pulling mucosa located 1 to 2 cm proximal to the dentate line into a rubber band applier. The rubber band strangulates the underlying tissue, causing scarring and sloughing off of the mass in a few days. 

Sclerotherapy involves injecting 1 to 3 mL of a sclerosing solution (phenol in olive oil, sodium morrhuate, or quinine urea) into the submucosa of internal hemorrhoids.

Surgery is indicated in: 

  1. Internal grade 3 or grade 4 hemorrhoids
  2. Hemorrhoids with a significant external component
  3. Early-grade hemorrhoids not responding to simple procedures

Surgical procedures used in the removal of internal hemorrhoids are:

1) Doppler-guided hemorrhoidal artery ligation

2) Open hemorrhoidectomy- the artery forceps are applied to the skin-covered external components of the hemorrhoid and traction is given to reveal the internal components. Dissection of the lateral pedicle is performed and finally, the pedicles are transfixed. Mucocutaneous bridges are left intact in this technique. The image below shows the procedure. 

3) Closed (Ferguson) hemorrhoidectomy- the hemorrhoid is excised with the overlying mucosa. The hemorrhoid is dissected from the underlying sphincter and the mucus defect is then closed. The image below describes the procedure.

4) Stapled hemorrhoidopexy (Longo operation)- the hemorrhoids are pulled up and a purse-string suture is placed a few centimeters above the dentate line. Then, a circumferential rectal mucosectomy is performed using a circular stapler. This technique is associated with higher chances of recurrence, however, it is quick to perform, less painful, and less traumatic. The image below shows stapled hemorrhoidopexy.

questions.text: A patient with a history of infection two weeks ago developed progressively ascending, bilaterally symmetric flaccid weakness in the lower limbs, which later involved the upper limbs. Examination reveals absent spinal cord reflexes. Based on the given findings, what could be the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with a history of infection two weeks ago who develops progressively ascending, bilaterally symmetric flaccid weakness in the lower limbs, later affecting the upper limbs and on examination absent spinal cord reflexes are seen. These findings suggest a likely diagnosis of Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (AIDP).

AIDP is the most common type of Guillain-Barre syndrome(GBS). GBS is usually associated with a history of upper respiratory infection (URI) or acute gastroenteritis (AGE) 1-3 weeks prior. The causative organisms may be Campylobacter jejuni, cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus, and Mycoplasma pneumoniae.

It presents with ascending motor paralysis, primarily affecting the lower limbs before progressing to the upper limbs. Sensory deficits may or may not be present, while deep tendon reflexes are absent. In severe cases, transient bladder dysfunction can occur. Autonomic manifestations include loss of vasomotor control, postural hypotension, and cardiac dysrhythmias.

Histological examination shows inflammation of peripheral nerves, manifested as perivenular and endoneurial infiltration by lymphocytes, macrophages, and a few plasma cells. On electron microscopy, an early effect on myelin sheaths is seen. There is segmental demyelination induced by the actions of activated macrophages.

There are several types of Guillain–Barre syndrome:

  • Demyelinating:
    • Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP) - most common.
  • Axonal:
    • Acute motor axonal neuropathy (AMAN).
    • Acute motor-sensory axonal neuropathy (AMSAN).
  • Regional GBS syndromes: Miller–Fisher syndrome (MFS).

Diagnosis is made upon clinical presentation. CSF findings of elevated protein without pleocytosis help to rule out other similar conditions. Treatment includes initiating intravenous immunoglobulins (IVIg) or plasmapheresis. IVIg is the initial therapy preferred, as it has a better safety record. In severe cases, patients may require ventilatory support.  

Other options: 

Option B: Multiple sclerosis is characterized by chronic inflammation and demyelination that causes multiple neurological symptoms such as optic neuritis, muscle spasticity, and facial weakness. The presence of oligoclonal bands on protein electrophoresis is diagnostic. 

Option C: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) differs from Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) as it involves both upper and lower motor neuron degeneration, whereas GBS is a purely lower motor neuron disorder. Additionally, ALS progresses gradually without sensory loss, while GBS has an acute onset and may involve sensory symptoms.

Option D: Transverse myelitis differs from Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) as it involves spinal cord inflammation, leading to a sensory level, bowel/bladder dysfunction, and often spasticity, whereas GBS primarily affects the peripheral nerves with ascending flaccid paralysis. Additionally, MRI shows spinal cord lesions in transverse myelitis, while GBS is diagnosed through nerve conduction studies and CSF analysis.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of Immunopathogenesis of Guillain-Barre Syndrome

The following sequence of events, takes into consideration, the development of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) associated with Campylobacter jejuni infection.

  1. B cells recognize glycoconjugates on jejuni (Cj) that cross-react with ganglioside present on Schwann cell surface and subjacent peripheral nerve myelin.
  2. Most of the B cells are activated via a partially T cell–dependent route and secrete primarily IgG autoantibodies. Some B cells, activated via a T cell–independent mechanism, secrete primarily IgM
  3. The activated B cells escape from Peyer’s patches into regional lymph nodes.
  4. Activated T cells also function to assist in the opening of the blood-nerve barrier, facilitating penetration of pathogenic autoantibodies.
  5. The earliest changes in myelin consist of edema between myelin lamellae and vesicular disruption of the outermost myelin layers.
  6. These effects are associated with activation of the C5b-C9 membrane attack complex and mediated by calcium entry; it is possible that the macrophage cytokine tumor necrosis factor (TNF) also participates in myelin damage.

Related Pearl: Antibodies seen in Guillian Barre syndrome

Type Antibody
AIDP Anti GM1
AMAN Anti GD1a
AMSAN Anti GD1a
Miller Fisher syndrome Anti GQ1b
  • AIDP-Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy 
  • AMAN-Acute motor axonal neuropathy 
  • AMSAN-Acute motor sensory axonal neuropathy

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding indirect ophthalmoscopy?

choices.text: The image produced is erect and real
Condensor needs to be kept very close to the eye

questions.solution:
An indirect ophthalmoscope produces an inverted real image of 3 to 5 times magnification.

Advantages of the binocular indirect ophthalmoscope are:

  • Visualization through hazy media is possible due to strong in built illumination system.
  • Field of view is much larger than direct ophthalmoscopy.
  • Examination of peripheral retina up to ora serrata is possible.
  • Depth perception of the lesion is possible due to stereopsis with binocular indirect ophthalmoscope.
  • Visualization of fundus in very high refractive error is also possible, where it may not be possible to focus the lesion with direct ophthalmoscope.
  • A real, Inverted image is formed (Option A).
  • There is an arms distance between the condensing lens and the patient's eye (Option C).

Other options:

Option D: 15 times magnification is seen with a direct ophthalmoscope.

Related Pearl: Difference between direct and indirect ophthalmoscopy

FEATURE DIRECT OPHTHALMOSCOPE  INDIRECT OPHTHALMOSCOPE
Condensing lens Not required Required
Examination distance As close to the patient's eye as possible At an arm's length
Image Virtual, Erect Real, Inverted
Magnification 15 times 4-5 times
Illumination Not so bright, so not useful in hazy media Bright, so useful in hazy media
Area of the field in focus About 2 disc diameter About 8 disc diameter
Stereopsis Absent Present
Accessible fundus view Slightly beyond equator Up to ora serrata
Examination through hazy media Not possible Possible

questions.text: A non-smoker patient with a history of cardiac disease suddenly develops chest pain and breathlessness. An X-ray is performed and given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given chest X-ray shows increased interstitial markings, vascular redistribution, and alveolar oedema in a butterfly pattern points to a diagnosis of pulmonary oedema. 

Acute severe hypertension, acute myocardial infarction, or exacerbation of chronic heart failure are some of the common causes of cardiogenic pulmonary oedema. It can be precipitated by the discontinuation of medications (non-compliant patient), excessive salt intake, or tachyarrhythmias. 

It presents with severe dyspnea, pink frothy sputum production, diaphoresis, and cyanosis. Auscultation reveals rales and rhonchi in all lung fields. Cardiomegaly might be seen in cases of chronic heart failure.

Management of pulmonary oedema includes the use of diuretics, nitrates, and morphine to decrease the preload. Nitroglycerin and isosorbide dinitrate have a rapid onset of action and can be given sublingually. If there is a persistence of pulmonary oedema and no hypotension, it can be administered intravenously.

Oxygen therapy to maintain a saturation of >92% is recommended. If saturation is not maintained even with supplemental oxygen, positive-pressure ventilation through a face mask or endotracheal intubation is required. A sitting position with legs hanging by the side of the bed can be used to reduce venous return in patients without hypotension.

Non-cardiac causes of pulmonary oedema are high altitude, sepsis, and disseminated intravascular coagulation. 

Heart failure is a manifestation of most chronic cardiac conditions such as hypertension, valvular heart disease, and coronary artery disease. Symptoms such as shortness of breath, orthopnea, and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea point to left heart failure due to pulmonary congestion. In contrast, symptoms such as pedal oedema, weight gain, early satiety, and hepatic congestion are characteristic of right heart failure.

Chest X-ray shows increased interstitial markings, vascular redistribution, and alveolar oedema in a bat wing/ butterfly pattern as given in the image below.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in heart failure

Drugs used in acute decompensated heart failure:
 
Intravenous vasodilators

Nitroglycerine

Nesiritide Recombinant human BNP

Dobutamine

Dopamine

Epinephrine

Norepinephrine

Enoximone

Milrinone

Levosimendan

Pimobendan

 Combined Ca2+ sensitizers and PDE3 inhibitors
 
Drugs used for rapid symptom relief

Bumetanide

Furosemide

Torasemide

 Loop diuretics- used for symptomatic treatment of severe heart failure and acute decompensation.
Morphine Opioid - to calm the patient and decreases cardiac O2 consumption
 
Drugs used in chronic heart failure:
Drugs Uses
ACE inhibitors Used as first-line therapy
ARBs Used in case of intolerance to ACE inhibitors
Beta-blockers Used as first-line therapy  

Spironolactone

Eplerenone

 Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists - first-line drugs for symptomatic heart failure.
SGLT-2 inhibitors Used as 1st line therapy- reduces mortality and morbidity
Sacubitril/Valsartan Neprilysin inhibitor/ARB(ARNI)
Ivabradine Inhibitor of If current in the sinoatrial node

Summary of Pathogenesis of Major Findings in Congestive Heart Failure

Abnormality
