Weakness, exercise intolerance, fatigue

Left ventricle output inadequate to perfuse muscles; especially, failure of output to rise with exercise

Ankle, sacral edema

Increased peripheral venous pressure →increased fluid transudation.

Hepatomegaly

Increased peripheral venous pressure →increased resistance to portal flow.

Pulmonary congestion

Increased pulmonary venous pressure →pulmonary venous distention and transudation of fluid into air spaces

Dyspnea on exertion

Failure of left ventricular output to rise during exercise → increased pulmonary venous pressure

Paroxysmal dyspnea, pulmonary edema

Probably a sudden failure of left heart output to keep up with the right heart output →acute rise in pulmonary venous and capillary pressure →transudation of fluid into air spaces.

Orthopnea

Normal pooling of blood in lungs in supine position added to the already congested pulmonary vascular system; increased venous return not put out by the left ventricle. (Relieved by sitting up, raising the head of the bed, lying on extra pillows.)

Cardiac dilation

Greater ventricular end-diastolic volume.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presented to OPD with the given presentation. On examination, it seems gelatinous in consistency. She reports fluctuation in size, mild numbness in hand and occasional pain. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history and image are suggestive of a patient with a ganglion cyst. 

Ganglion cyst arises from the leakage of synovial fluid from a joint or tendon sheath and thus contains a glary, viscous fluid.

It can appear anywhere in the wrist but the most common area is the dorsal surface of the scapholunate ligament.

Patients usually present with painless, well-defined, cystic, transillumination-positive, and non-tender swelling. If there is an impingement on a nearby nerve or structure it can cause pain.

It disappears spontaneously, but the aspiration of the swelling or operative removal can be done for reassurance or when there is pressure on the nerve. Even if treatment is done, the rates of recurrence are high.  

Other Options:

Option B: Lipomas are benign tumors of adipose tissue. It can occur anywhere and at any depth. It can be encapsulated or diffuse, superficial or deep. On examination, they are nontender and non-pulsatile. Because of the soft consistency, they may appear to be fluctuant but they are not. The slip sign is positive.

Option C: Dermoid Cyst presents as asymptomatic, slowly enlarging, painless, superficial localized swellings over the volar aspect of the hand, especially the distal portion of the digits.

Option D: An extremity hematoma is a localized collection of blood in the soft tissues of an extremity, typically occurring after trauma, surgery, or in patients with bleeding disorders. The hematoma can develop in various tissue planes: subcutaneous, intramuscular, or subfascial compartments.

questions.text: Identify the CTG pattern shown in the given image.
questions.solution:
The given CTG shows early decelerations. It is seen in fetal head compression.

In early decelerations, the onset, nadir, and recovery of deceleration coincide with the beginning, peak, and ending of uterine contraction respectively.

This finding in CTG is suggestive of fetal head compression causing vagal nerve activation.

Other options: 

Option A: The CTG given below shows late decelerations, Here the fetal heart rate begins to drop after the end of uterine contraction. It is mostly associated with uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia.

Other causes of late decelerations include:

  • Placental pathologies like- postmaturity, hypertension, diabetes, placental abruption
  • Excessive uterine contractions
  • Excessive use of oxytocin
  • Epidural anesthesia

Option B: The CTG given below shows variable decelerations as seen in umbilical cord compression.

Option D: The CTG given below shows a sinusoidal pattern. It resembles a sine wave. It is often associated with fetal anemia, fetomaternal hemorrhage, and fetal acidosis.

questions.text: Calculate the total percentage of burns depicted in the image below.
questions.solution:
The percentage of burns calculated in the given patient is between 40-50% according to Wallace’s rule of nine.

In this case, the estimation of % total burns surface area is as follows.

  • Right arm = 9%
  • Right leg/thigh = 18%
  • Front of abdomen and thorax = 18% (front trunk is 18%, as total trunk is 36% split equally between front and back)

Total burn percentage = 9% + 18% + 18% = 45% Total Body Surface Area (TBSA)

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

This formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

Note:

The goal of resuscitation is to maintain the fine balance of adequate perfusion as indicated by urine output. It is important to understand that formulas provide a starting target rate; subsequently, the amount of fluids provided should be adjusted based on a urine output target of 0.5 mL/kg/hr for adults and 1 mL/kg/hr for children weighing less than 30 kg.

Related Pearl: Degrees of Burns

  First-degree Second-degree superficial (partial-thickness) Second-degree deep (partial-thickness)

Third-degree (full thickness)

 Fourth-degree (full thickness)
Depth Epidermis Epidermis + superficial dermis Epidermis + most of the dermis (most skin appendages destroyed) Entire dermis + subcutaneous tissue Involves connective tissue, muscle, possibly bone
Colour/texture Red Red, edematous, and blistered Pale, mottled Hard, leathery Pale, dry, charred
Blanchable (capillary refill)  Yes Yes No No No
Pain Painful Painful Painful (only on pinprick) No No
Healing 5-10 days; no scar 10-14 days; no or minimal scar  4-8 weeks, often with scarring and contractures Prolonged, with scarring and contractures, requires skin grafting Requires skin grafting or even amputation.

questions.text: A patient sustained blunt trauma to the eye 6 months ago and now presents with double vision. What is the most likely condition?
questions.solution:
The given image shows iridodialysis.

Iridodialysis refers to detachment of the iris root from the ciliary body and is associated with a D-shaped pupil. A black biconvex area is seen at the periphery at the site of detachment.

The given image depicts iridodialysis and a D-shaped pupil.

Other Options:

Option A: Cycloiriditis is inflammation involving both the ciliary body and iris, leading to pain, photophobia, and decreased vision. It's characterized by cells and flare in the anterior chamber, keratic precipitates, and possible synechiae formation.

Option B: Vossius ring is a circular ring of faint or stippled opacity, seen on the anterior surface of the lens due to brown amorphous granules of pigment lying on the capsule of the lens. It is usually seen after blunt trauma to the eye and orbit.

Option D: Coloboma is a congenital anomaly, that develops due to a defect in the closure of the embryonic cleft. It is characterized by poorly developed uveal tissue. These colobomas may involve the optic nerve, choroid, retina, and iris.

questions.text: A patient underwent a forceps delivery a few hours ago and subsequently developed severe pain at the episiotomy site. Examination reveals vulvar swelling with bluish discoloration, along with hypotension (80/60 mmHg) and tachycardia. Which of the following should not be done?
questions.solution:
To remove the suture in the ward would be unadvisable since symptoms of hypotension and bluish discoloration of the vulva are indicative of a vulvar hematoma.

The vulva is the most common site for pelvic hematoma and the pudendal artery is the most common artery involved in vulval hematoma

Hematomas <5 cm can be managed conservatively with cold compress. Larger hematomas need to be explored surgically. And as the patient is already hypotensive , it suggests that hematoma is quite large in size. Hence trying to manage it in ward by removing the sutures can lead the hematoma to bleed profusely can cause further detoriation of patient's condition and should be avoided. The next best step to manage it to resuscitate the patient in OT until she can be managed surgically.

Types of pelvic hematomas:

Feature Infralevator hematoma Supralevator hematoma
Incidence Common Rare
Location Below the levator ani Above the levator ani
Causes Improper hemostasis during repair of vaginal/ perineal tears or episiotomy wound Extension of cervical laceration, lower uterine segment rupture
Presentation Severe pain with rectal tenesmus Unexplained shock with features of internal haemorrhage
Treatment Small hematomas can be conservatively managed with cold compress Laparotomy

Other Options:

Option B, C and D are warranted actions in the management of the hematoma.

Option B: Blood transfusion should be one of the steps of management as vulvar hematoma are known to cause heavy bleeding and blood transfusion has to be done as patient is already hypotensive.

Option C: Resuscitation in the OT is also a better approach as if there was failure to control the bleeding , patient can be managed surgically as soon as possible.

Option D: Any individual should inform senior staff in cases like the one given above. Vulvar Hematoma causing hypotension warrants an emergency and senior staff should be informed to take necessary action as soon as possible if needed.

questions.text: A patient scheduled for elective hip surgery in 5 days is taking aspirin, a multivitamin, enalapril, and metoprolol. What is the appropriate perioperative management for this patient?

choices.text: Stop aspirin to minimize perioperative bleeding risk
Stop metoprolol to increase cardiac output
Increase aspirin dosage for additional analgesic benefit

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, where a patient is scheduled for elective hip surgery in 5 days and is taking aspirin, a multivitamin, enalapril, and metoprolol, the recommended perioperative management includes discontinuing enalapril, as it is an ACE inhibitor.

ACE inhibitors are discontinued 24 hours before surgery due to the risk of hemodynamic instability. ACE inhibitors block the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), leading to vasodilation and reduced blood pressure. During anaesthesia, there is already vasodilation and decreased sympathetic tone → combining this with ACE inhibitors can cause severe hypotension that is resistant to fluids.
 

Aspirin can be maintained unless the patient is scheduled for neurosurgery or retinal surgery, provided the dosage remains unchanged. Metoprolol, being a beta-blocker, should always be continued.

Related Pearl: Drugs that should be discontinued prior to surgery

Drugs that should be discontinued prior to surgery 

  • Topical medications - discontinue on the day of surgery
  • Diuretics except thiazides - discontinue on the day of surgery
  • Oral hypoglycemic agents - discontinue on the day of surgery
  • Sildenafil - Discontinue 24 hours before the day of surgery
  • NSAIDs - Discontinue 48 hours before the day of surgery
  • Warfarin - Discontinue 4 days before surgery, except for patients having cataract surgery without a bulbar block.
  • Short-acting Insulins except when given by a continuous pump
  • Thienopyridines (e.g., clopidogrel, ticlopidine) except in cataract surgery, patients with metallic/drug-eluting stents
  • Aspirin should be discontinued 3 days before the surgery, in selected cases where reversal of platelet inhibition is necessary
  • MAO Inhibitors - 2 weeks prior (MAO Inhibitors are usually continued.They should be discontinued if the patient and anesthesiologist factors are not favourable to continue them)

questions.text: A patient in acute hypoxemic respiratory failure is administered oxygen using the device shown below. Name the device.
questions.solution:
The equipment shown in the image is a high-flow nasal cannula.

High flow nasal cannula (HFNC) is a mode of respiratory support used to manage conditions such as acute hypoxemic respiratory failure.

There are three components to a high-flow nasal cannula:

  • A flow generator that provides a gas flow of up to 40 liters per minute
  • An air oxygen blender that increases FiO2 from 21% to 100%
  • A humidifier

The HFNC equipment shown in the image below uses a heated humidifier, a nasal cannula (no. 2), and a ventilator (brand: vivo30).

Other options:

Option A: Mechanical ventilator

Option B: Infusion Pump

Option C: Continuous positive airway pressure(CPAP)

questions.text: A patient presents with non-pulsatile proptosis that increases when bending down. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with non-pulsatile propotosis that increases on bending down most likely has orbital varices.

Orbital varices:

  • They are venous malformations of the orbit caused by vascular dysgenesis.
  • Patients usually present with non-pulsatile, intermittent, and reducible proptosis.
  • On activities such as forward bending or lowering of the head, turning the head forcefully, hyperextension of the neck, and coughing, the varices fill up, causing proptosis, and then, they regress on shifting to a non-dependent position.

Treatment:

  • Small lesions generally do not require treatment
  • Surgical excision is technically difficult and often incomplete because the lesions are friable and bleed easily; Specialized techniques such as embolization and carbon dioxide laser surgery may be helpful.

Other options:

Option A: Thyroid eye disease (TED) is the most common cause of both bilateral and unilateral proptosis in an adult in the euthyroid state. The main features of TED include lid retraction, proptosis, periorbital edema, chemosis, and restrictive myopathy.

Option C:  In cavernous sinus thrombosis, proptosis is initially unilateral but soon becomes bilateral due to the spread of infection to the contralateral sinus through the intercavernous communication. Also, cavernous sinus thrombosis presents with high-grade fever with chills, rigor, and headache. 

Option D: Orbital cellulitis is the most common cause of unilateral proptosis in children. It refers to the acute infection of the contents of the orbit behind the orbital septum. Features include pain, lid edema, erythema, chemosis, and axial proptosis. Increased pain with movement of eyes and ophthalmoplegia (decreased ocular motility) is a classic symptom.

questions.text: A patient presents with backache, night sweats, an evening increase in temperature, and unintentional weight loss. Laboratory tests reveal an increase in CRP and ESR levels. An MRI is provided below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given spine MRI shows a patient with Pott's spine. The image depicts sagittal T1W (A) and T2W (B) images in a patient with spinal tuberculosis showing a well-defined, round lesion (arrow) with T1 hypointensity and T2 iso-hypointensity.

  • Pott's disease, also known as tuberculous spondylitis, refers to the vertebral body and intervertebral disc involvement in tuberculosis (TB).
  • The spine is the most frequent location of musculoskeletal TB, and commonly related symptoms are back pain and lower limb weakness/paraplegia.
  • The spine is involved due to hematogenous spread via the venous plexus of Batson.
  • There is usually a slow collapse of one or usually more vertebral bodies, which spreads underneath the longitudinal ligaments.
  • This results in an acute kyphotic or "gibbus" deformity.
  • This angulation, coupled with epidural granulation tissue and bony fragments, can lead to cord compression.

Radiographic Features:

Features include irregularity of both the endplate and anterior aspect of the vertebral bodies, with bone marrow edema and enhancement seen on MRI:

  • T1: hypointense marrow in adjacent vertebrae
  • T2: hyperintense marrow, disc, soft tissue infection
  • T1 C+ (Gd): marrow, subligamentous, discal, dural enhancement

The paraspinal collections are typically well-circumscribed, with fluid centres and well-defined enhancing margins.

Other options: 

Option A: Ankylosing spondylitis: shows Squaring and bridging of the vertebral body, leading to a bamboo spine appearance.

Option B: Multiple myeloma is the malignant production of plasma cells that results in bone pain or fractures, renal failure, increased susceptibility to infections, anemia, hypercalcemia, and manifestations of hyperviscosity. Radiography shows multiple well-defined, punched-out lytic lesions of various sizes scattered throughout the skull, giving the raindrop skull appearance.

Option C: Pyogenic spondylitis denotes infections impacting different components of the spine, including the vertebrae, intervertebral discs, paraspinal soft tissue, or epidural space. This umbrella term covers conditions such as vertebral osteomyelitis, spondylodiscitis, and epidural abscess.

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary use of the given imaging modality?
questions.solution:
The provided imaging modality is an endoscopic ultrasound of the oesophagus, primarily utilized for staging oesophagal carcinoma.

Esophageal carcinoma is more commonly seen in men. Tobacco use and alcohol are strong risk factors. Adenocarcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma of the oesophagus are the two most common types. The squamous cell variant usually affects the upper two-thirds and the adenocarcinoma variant usually affects the lower third. The incidence of adenocarcinoma is increasing.

Clinical features include:

  • Dysphagia (most common)
  • Regurgitation
  • Vomiting
  • Odynophagia
  • Weight loss

In the advanced stage, there can be hoarseness of voice due to recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy, horner’s syndrome, chronic spinal pain, and diaphragmatic paralysis.

Flexible endoscopy with biopsy is preferred for confirmation of diagnosis. Other investigations include barium swallow, which shows a rat-tail appearance due to irregular narrowing or ulceration. Contrast-enhanced CT and PET can be used to assess distant metastasis. Endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) is the investigation of choice to assess tumour invasion and lymph node metastasis.

TNM staging:

Primary Tumor (T)

TX

Tumor cannot be assessed

T0

No evidence of tumor

Tis

High-grade dysplasia

T1

Tumor invades the muscularis mucosa (T1a) or submucosa (T1b)

T2

Tumor invades into but not beyond the muscularis propria

T3

Tumor invades the adventitia

T4a

Tumor invades adjacent structures that are usually resectable(diaphragm and pericardium)

T4b

Tumor invades unresectable structures

Regional Lymph Nodes (N)

NX

Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed

N0

No regional lymph node metastasis

N1

Metastasis in 1-2 regional lymph nodes

N2

Metastasis in 3-6 regional lymph nodes

N3

Metastasis in ≥7 regional lymph nodes

Distant Metastasis (M)

M0

No distant metastasis

M1

Distant metastasis

questions.text: Identify the type of tympanoplasty shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The columella tympanoplasty is type 3 as per the Wullstein's classification of tympanoplasty.

While performing this procedure, the diseased ear would have already lost the malleus and incus, and hence the graft is placed over the stapes superstructure. Therefore, it is also called myringostapediopexy.

Type Defect and repair
Type I Perforation of tympanic membrane which is repaired with a graft (myringoplasty)
Type II Perforation of tympanic membrane with erosion of malleus. The graft is placed on the incus or remnant of the malleus.
Type III Malleus and incus are absent. The graft is placed directly on the stapes head (myringostapediopexy)
Type IV Only the footplate of stapes is present. The graft is placed between the oval and round windows on the stapes footplate
Type V The stapes footplate is fixed but the round window is functioning. The graft is placed in contact with a new window created on the fenestra in the horizontal semicircular canal

 

Related Pearl: Zollner and Wullstein’s classification/ Types of tympanoplasty

Type Findings Procedure
Graft placed over
Type I (or) Myringoplasty All ossicles are intact Over/ under remnant TM over the handle of malleus
Type II Malleus eroded Over the remnant malleus/ incus
Type III (or) Columella (or) Myringostapediopexy Malleus & incus absent Over stapes superstructure
Type IV (or) Cavum minor All ossicles eroded Over ET and the round window, leaving mobile footplate expose
Type V (or) Fenestration surgery Fixed footplate An opening made in the lateral semicircular canal (an alternative pathway)
Type VI (or) Sono-Inversion --- The round window is left exposed and receives sound and the oval window is covered (reversed pathway)

Type III is called columella because it resembles the middle ear of birds. They have a single ossicle. Type VI is not part of the original Zollner-Wullstein classification. It is a recent addition.

Image showing different types of tympanoplasty:

SCC: Semicircular canal.

questions.text: A patient presents with right-sided visual field defects in both eyes while central vision remains unaffected. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Visual field defect involving the right sides of each eye with central vision preserved is called bilateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing. It occurs in lesions of the occipital lobe.

Homonymous hemianopia (HH) involves loss of vision on the same side of the visual field in both eyes. HH is characteristically seen in lesions involving the visual pathway posterior to the optic chiasma.

Lesions involving occipital lobe usually shows macular sparing because macular representation is seperate and quite large as compared to peripheral vision. Moreover, macular area in occipital lobe is supplied both by posterior and middle cerebral artery. In case of vascular lesions (eg stroke) affecting occipital lobe, it is less likely to involve both these arteries.

HH may be either complete or incomplete. 

  • A complete HH is characterised by loss of entire hemifield on the same side in both eyes.
  • An incomplete HH is characterised by partial loss of visual field on the same side in both eyes. Incomplete HH is further classified as congruous or incongruous, depending on whether the extent of partial loss of visual field in both the eyes is same or different, respectively.

Other Options:

Option A: Optic Chiasm Lesion: Bitemporal hemianopia refers to loss of sight in the temporal halves of the visual field, seen in lesions affecting the optic chiasma. 

Option B: Optic Tract Lesion : Lesions at the occipital lobe, optic tract and optic radiation would all cause homonymous hemianopia, but macular sparing will occur in the setting of optic lobe damage.

Option C: Damage to the middle part of the optic chiasm affects fibres crossing at the nasal retina of each eye, leaving the uncrossed fibres from the temporal retinas intact. The resulting loss of vision is confined to the temporal visual field of each eye and this is known as bitemporal hemianopia. It is also called heteronymous hemianopia.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: A patient has visual disturbance and pain abdomen after drinking from a local shop. Which metabolite is responsible for that?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of methanol toxicity, and the metabolite responsible is formic acid.

Methanol poisoning is caused by to ingestion of illicit liquor which contains ethanol adulterated with methanol. Methanol is metabolized to formaldehyde and formic acid by alcohol and aldehyde dehydrogenases, respectively. The metabolites of methanol are responsible for the toxic effects.

Clinically, patients present with headache, vomiting, abdomen pain, uneasiness, confusion, delirium, and coma. Formic acid specifically damages the retina and optic nerve and results in blurring of vision and blindness.

Elevated levels of formic acid and other organic acids result in metabolic acidosis in arterial blood gas analysis(ABG).

Treatment of methanol poisoning includes gastric lavage with sodium bicarbonate if the patient is brought within 2 hours of ingesting methanol to combat acidosis. Ethanol infusion since ethanol is preferentially metabolized by alcohol dehydrogenase over methanol and helps by reducing the rate of generation of formaldehyde and formic acid.

Fomepizole is a competitive inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase and the drug of choice for methanol poisoning. Folate therapy with calcium leucovorin reduces blood formate levels by enhancing its oxidation. Hemodialysis is used in severe cases of methanol toxicity.

questions.text: A newborn baby brought by the mother with complaints of the left upper eyelid moving up and down during breastfeeding or thumb sucking which disappears when the baby is not being fed. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Marcus–Gunn jaw-winking phenomenon.

Marcus–Gunn jaw-winking syndrome:

  • About 5% of all cases of congenital ptosis are associated with the Marcus–Gunn jaw-winking phenomenon.
  • The vast majority are unilateral.
  • Etiology: a branch of the mandibular division of the fifth cranial nerve is misdirected to the levator muscle.
  • Signs
    • Retraction of the ptotic lid with stimulation of the ipsilateral pterygoid muscles by chewing, sucking, opening the mouth, or contralateral jaw movement.
    • Less common stimuli to winking include jaw protrusion, smiling, swallowing, and clenching of teeth.
    • Jaw-winking does not improve with age although patients may learn to mask it.

The following image shows a woman with Marcus–Gunn jaw-winking phenomenon. See how her right eyelid ptosis retracts with the opening of the mouth.

Other options:

Option A: In 3rd nerve palsy (oculomotor nerve) - Due to the involvement of the superior rectus and medial rectus, elevation and adduction will also be impaired, which is not the case here.

Option B: Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular junction (NMJ) disorder associated with a decrease in postsynaptic depolarization due to the blocking of acetylcholine receptors by autoantibodies. It is characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles. 

Option C: In lagophthalmos, there is incomplete closure of the palpable aperture when the patient attempts to close the eyes due to congenital deformity, paralysis of the orbicularis muscle, ectropion or contraction of the lid.  It may be due to a malfunction of the facial nerve. Treatment includes the management of exposure keratopathy with frequent instillation of lubricants.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency room following a bike accident. Examination reveals the right upper limb in abduction and external rotation. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The upper limb in abduction and external rotation and radiograph are both suggestive of anterior dislocation of the shoulder. 

The AP view radiograph shows the disturbed articulation between the humeral head and glenoid fossa. The humeral head is seen below and medial to the glenoid socket. This suggests anterior dislocation of the shoulder joint. In young adults, the common cause for anterior dislocation is athletic injuries, while in older adults, falls are a more common cause. 

Anterior dislocation is the most common among shoulder dislocations. It occurs due to a fall on the hands. The head of the humerus is driven forwards and tears the capsule resulting in an avulsion in the glenoid labrum (Bankart lesion). Sometimes, the posterolateral part of the head of the humerus is crushed resulting in the Hill-Sachs lesion.

The clinical features include severe pain and the patient usually supports his dislocated arm with the opposite arm. On examination, the arm is usually abducted, externally rotated and the lateral outline of the shoulder may be straightened and sometimes a prominent acromion process or a bulge below the clavicle may be appreciated.

The anteroposterior radiograph shows the humeral head lying below and medial to the glenoid socket. It may also show the Bankart lesion and the Hill-Sachs lesion.

Other Options:

Option A: Luxatio erecta is also known as inferior dislocation of shoulder. This is caused due to severe hyperabduction. The radiograph shows that the head of the humerus is present below the glenoid and the shaft is in an abducted position.

Option B:  Light bulb sign is seen on AP radiographs in the posterior dislocation shoulder. In posterior dislocation of the shoulder, the humerus rotates internally. This causes changes to the normal radiographic contour of the head of the humerus. The humerus appears similar to a lightbulb in AP views. 

Related Pearl: Tests for anterior shoulder dislocation

Bryant’s test: Anterior axillary fold is at a lower level on the dislocated side.

 

Dugas test: The patient is made to place the hand on the opposite shoulder. The examiner then applies gentle pressure on the flexed elbow to make it touch the chest. In shoulder dislocation, the elbow cannot be made to touch the chest. 

 

Hamilton ruler test: In a normal shoulder, a ruler (scale) placed on the lateral side of the arm will not touch the lateral condyle of the humerus and the acromion at the same time.

In anterior shoulder dislocation, the ruler will simultaneously touch the lateral condyle of the humerus and the acromion. 

 

 

Callway Test: The vertical circumference of the axilla is increased on the dislocated side as compared to the normal side. 

Related Pearl: Methods of reduction of shoulder dislocation

Kocher's technique - TEAM (Traction → External Rotation → Adduction → Medial Rotation) 

Hippocratic method- Surgeon applies a firm and steady pull on the semi-abducted arm by keeping his foot on the axilla against the chest wall. The foot is used as the fulcrum.

Stimson's gravity technique: Patient is left prone and weight is attached to the elbow or wrist on the affected side. Gravity stretches the muscle and reduction occurs in 15-20 minutes.

questions.text: A patient came to the hospital with complaints of breathlessness and is diagnosed with a Pancoast tumor. Which of the following findings is not typically associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Pancoast syndrome is associated with Horner's syndrome, resulting in ptosis, miosis and anhidrosis. It is not associated with exophthalmus.

Horner syndrome is also called oculosympathetic paresis. It can be produced by a lesion anywhere along the sympathetic pathway that supplies the head, eye, and neck. It is characterized by:

  • Ptosis - usually due to weakness of Muller’s muscle (Option D).
  • Miosis - due to unopposed action of sphincter pupillae leading to anisocoria (Option C). 
  • Anhidrosis - reduced ipsilateral sweating (Option B).
  • Heterochromia iridis- seen in congenital and long-standing disease. The affected eye is lighter in color. 
  • Anisocoria that is accentuated in dim light
  • Enophthalmus

Pancoast syndrome/superior sulcus tumor results from a local extension of a tumor growing in the apex of the lung, with the involvement of C8, T1, and T2 nerve roots.

It presents with pain that radiates to the ulnar distribution of the arm, often with the destruction of the 1st and 2nd ribs. Patients with the central or endobronchial growth of the primary tumor may present with a cough, hemoptysis, wheeze, stridor, dyspnea, or post-obstructive pneumonitis.

Regional spread of the tumor can cause:

  • Tracheal obstruction, esophageal compression with dysphagia
  • Recurrent laryngeal paralysis with hoarseness
  • Phrenic nerve palsy with the elevation of the hemidiaphragm and dyspnea
  • Sympathetic nerve paralysis with Horner’s syndrome (enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and anhydrosis).

The below images show chest X-ray and management of the Pancoast tumor.

Related Pearl: Horner's syndrome

Horner's Syndrome:

Horner's syndrome occurring due to occulo-sympathetic paresis is characterized by the classic triad of:

  • Mild ptosis (due to paralysis of Muller's muscle).
  • Miosis (due to paralysis of dilator pupillae).
  • Reduced ipsilateral sweating (anhydrosis).

Other features include:

  • Mild enophthalmos,
  • Loss of cilio-spinal reflex,
  • Heterochromia, i.e., the ipsilateral iris is lighter in colour,
  • Pupil is slow to dilate, and there occurs slight elevation of lower eyelid.

Cocaine test (2% to 4%): Small pupils fail to dilate in Horner's syndrome.

In congenital Horner's syndrome, the additional features seen are heterochromia iridis and unilateral straight hair.

questions.text: Identify the type of epiphysis.
questions.solution:
The image depicts the distal end of the tibia which is an example of a pressure epiphysis.

The distal tibial epiphysis, near the ankle joint, is a pressure epiphysis because it primarily bears weight and compressive forces rather than muscular forces.

Pressure epiphysis is articular in nature and takes part in the transmission of weight. Examples are the head of the femur, the lower end of radius, etc.

Other options:

Options A: Tubercles of humerus and trochanters of femur are examples of traction epiphysis because these are the site of major muscle attachments.

Option C: An avulsion epiphysis is a small, separate ossification center that develops at sites where major tendons or ligaments attach to bone, forming due to the pulling forces (traction) of these attachments - common examples include the lesser trochanter of the femur (where psoas major attaches), greater trochanter (gluteal muscles attachment), and tibial tuberosity (patellar tendon attachment).

Option D: An aberrant epiphysis is an accessory ossification center that appears near a main epiphysis but remains separate and typically doesn't contribute to longitudinal growth - examples include the os trigonum behind the talus, os subfibulare near the lateral malleolus, and os tibiale externum at the navicular tuberosity; the key distinction is that avulsion epiphyses form due to mechanical forces at attachment sites.

questions.text: Which  of  the following platinum based drugs are used in cervical cancer along with  radiotherapy?
questions.solution:
Cisplatin is the drug of choice for chemotherapy for cervical cancer.

The primary management for cervical cancer is chemoradiation therapy. This involves the combination of external beam radiation therapy, brachytherapy, and chemotherapy (usually with cisplatin). This approach has been shown to improve overall survival and reduce the risk of local and distant recurrence compared to radiation therapy alone.

Following chemoradiation, patients should be closely monitored for treatment response and potential side effects or complications. This includes regular physical examinations, Pap tests, and imaging studies as needed. The prognosis for stage IIB cervical cancer depends on various factors, such as the size of the tumor, lymph node involvement, and the patient's overall health. With appropriate treatment, the 5-year survival rate for stage IIB cervical cancer is around 58-63%.

Other Options:

Option A: Chemotherapy with doxorubicin is used in case of very aggressive recurrent tumors and residual tumors.

Option B: Trastuzumab is indicated for adjuvant therapy in early and metastatic HER2 positive breast cancer. 

Option D: Bleomycin is an anticancer antibiotic used for the treatment of squamous cell cancer and Hodgkin lymphoma.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with difficulty in hearing. A pure-tone audiogram was obtained, which is shown below. What is the interpretation of this audiogram?
questions.solution:
The given audiogram is suggestive of left-sided mixed hearing loss. 

Interpretation of the audiogram:

  • Blue colour indicates the left ear.
  • > indicates bone conduction (BC), and the threshold is >25 dB. Hence, BC is abnormal, which implies that the abnormality is in the sensorineural pathway.
  • × indicates air conduction (AC), and the threshold is >15 dB. Hence, AC is abnormal.
  • Both AC and BC are abnormal. It indicates sensorineural hearing loss.
  • In addition, the air-bone gap is present, which implies conductive hearing loss.
  • Hence, the interpretation is left-mixed hearing loss.

A mixed type of hearing loss presents with defects in both conductive and sensorineural pathways. This type of hearing loss is seen in chronic suppurative otitis media and otosclerosis.

questions.text:
The risk of cancer that can be reduced with OCP use are all, except?

OCP- Oral contraceptive pills
questions.solution:
Oral contraceptive pills (OCP) are not protective against breast cancer.

OCPs have no effect on the incidence of Breast Cancer.

OCPs protect against ovarian cancer (Option A). Oral contraceptives cause prolonged suppression of gonadotropin stimulation of ovary on long term use. This may account for lower incidence of ovarian malignancy noted in contraceptive users.

Other benefits of oral contraceptive pills:

  • Lesser incidence of endometrial carcinoma due to progestin component in OCP (Option D).
  • Regularisation of menstrual cycles results in relief of dysmenorrhea and menorrhagia.
  • Reduced incidence and relief of fibrocystic breast disease and ovarian cysts.
  • Endometriosis and pelvic inflammatory disease are improved.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented to the casualty with severe upper abdominal pain and vomiting. A nasogastric tube insertion was tried but it was unsuccessful. Chest X-ray showed the following findings. Which of the following episodes of vomiting corresponds to this illness?

choices.text: Forceful vomiting against a closed glottis

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a 30-year-old patient presenting with severe upper abdominal pain and vomiting with the inability to pass a nasogastric tube and a chest X-ray showing a gas-filled viscus in the upper abdomen is suggestive of gastric volvulus. It is associated with severe recurrent retching with the production of minimal vomitus.

Gastric volvulus is the rotation of the gastric fundus occurring on the longitudinal (organoaxial) or vertical (mesenteroaxial) axis of the stomach. This occurs due to the laxity in the peritoneal attachment of the stomach.

Patients present with the characteristic Borchardt's triad which comprises of:

  • Sudden-onset severe upper abdominal pain
  • Recurrent retching with minimal vomitus
  • Inability to pass a nasogastric (NG) tube

Organoaxial gastric volvulus is a torsion that occurs along the longitudinal axis of the stomach It is the most common type and often occurs acutely. It is associated with a diaphragmatic defect.

Mesenteroaxial gastric volvulus is a torsion that occurs along the vertical axis. It is partial (<180 degrees) and recurrent. It is not associated with a diaphragmatic defect.

Chest X-ray shows a gas-filled viscus in the upper abdomen due to rotation of gastric fundus on the axis of the stomach. Gastric volvulus can be confirmed by a barium study. In barium study, the stomach may be inverted with greater curvature above the lesser curvature, or as the pylorus above the cardia. 

Emergency surgery is indicated for acute volvulus which includes decompression, reduction, and prevention of recurrence. The surgical intervention includes simple gastropexy with diaphragmatic hernia repair. 

Other options:

Option B: Forceful vomiting against a closed glottis is most commonly associated with Boerhaave's syndrome. It results in full-thickness perforation of the lower oesophagus.

Option C: Vomiting of undigested food particles is commonly seen in achalasia cardia which occurs as a result of impaired relaxation of the LES due to loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Patients usually present with the classic triad of dysphagia, regurgitation, and weight loss.

Option D: Projectile non-bilious vomitus is seen in congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.

questions.text: The following sign is seen in a patient presenting with rhinorrhea following a skull base fracture. Identify the sign.
questions.solution:
The given image shows the Double target sign or Halo sign or Target sign seen in CSF rhinorrhoea and suggests basal skull fracture due to trauma in this case.

Double target sign is seen patients with CSF rhinorrhea. The nasal discharge in a patient with CSF rhinorrhea after head trauma is mixed with blood. When this discharge is collected on a filter paper, it shows a double target sign with a central red spot and a peripheral lighter halo. 

The following features help in differentiating CSF rhinorrhoea from nasal secretions:  

Features CSF Fluid Nasal Secretions

History

Nasal or sinus surgery, head injury, or intracranial tumor

Sneezing, nasal stuffiness, itching in the nose, or lacrimation

Flow of discharge

A few drops or a stream of fluid gushes down with bending forward or straining

cannot be sniffed back

Continuous and no effect with bending forward or straining.

Can be sniffed back

Character of discharge

Thin, watery, and clear

Slimy (mucus) or clear (tears)

Taste

Sweet

Salty

Sugar content

More than 30 mg/dL

Less than 10 mg/dl

Presence of β2 transferrin

Always present

 Always absent

Note: Nasal discharge stiffens the handkerchief because of the presence of mucus.

A basilar skull fracture occurs due to direct impact behind the ear or crush injuries of the head and present with the following features:

  • Hemotympanum
  • Battle sign: bruising behind the ear
  • Racoon eyes
  • CSF rhinorrhoea

Related Pearl: Features of CSF rhinorrhea

  • Reservoir sign - In CSF rhinorrhea, the fluid which had collected in the sinuses, particularly sphenoid, empties into the nose.
  • Double target sign or Halo sign or Target sign - CSF is mixed with blood and collected on a piece of filter paper. It shows a central red spot (blood) and a peripheral lighter halo.
  • CSF can’t be sniffed back.
  • CSF doesn’t stiffen the handkerchief.

Note: Reservoir sign is also seen in acute mastoiditis/ coalescent mastoiditis where mastoid acts as a reservoir of pus and pus reappear in EAC immediately after cleaning.

questions.text: Identify this sign in pregnancy.
questions.solution:
The image dipicts Hegar's sign.

Hegar's sign: the examiner performs a bimanual examination. Two fingers of one hand are placed in the anterior fornix of the vagina and the fingers of the other hand are placed, over the abdomen and behind the uterus. The abdominal fingers and the vaginal fingers appear to oppose each other below the body of the uterus. This can be elicited between 6-10 weeks.

This sign is based on the fact that the lower part of the body of the uterus is empty and extremely soft, and the upper part is enlarged by the growing fetus.

Other options :

Option A- Palmer's sign is regular rhythmic uterine contraction during the bimanual examination, which is seen as early as 4-8 weeks.

Option C- Osiander's sign is increased pulsation felt through lateral fornix by 8 weeks.

Option D- Goodell's sign is softening of the cervix by the 6th week.

Related Pearl: Clinical Signs in Obstetrics

  • Chadwick’s Sign: Bluish hue to the vestibule and anterior vaginal wall. Seen in the first trimester of pregnancy. The cause is increased blood flow to the pelvic organs. Also known as Jacquemier’s Sign. /
  • Cullen Sign: Bluish discoloration of the skin around the umbilicus. Occurs due to intraperitoneal hemorrhage. Seen in ruptured ectopic pregnancy
  • Goodell Sign: Marked softening of the cervix in contrast to a non-pregnant state. Also due to increased blood flow
  • Hegar Sign: An indication of Pregnancy. The softening of the lower parts of the uterus enables the approximation of vaginal and abdominal fingers on bimanual pelvic examination.
  • Kustner’s Sign: Sign of placental separation. On pushing the uterus upwards does not move the cord with it due to the separation.
  • Ladin’s Sign: Softening in the midline of the uterus anteriorly at the junction of the uterus and cervix. It occurs at about 6 weeks gestation
  • Osiander’s Sign: Pulsations in the lateral fornix due to the increased vascularity.
  • Palmer’s Sign: Regular rhythmic contractions of uterus felt as early as 6-8 weeks. It is a sign of pregnancy
  • Piskacek’s Sign: Asymmetric growth occurs to the uterus in the initial stages of pregnancy due to the lateral implantation of the blastocyst. The area of implantation feels soft compared to the other parts.
  • Schroeder’s Sign: A sign of placental separation. Uterus rises up when the separated placenta is passed downwards
  • Stallworthy’s Sign: Slowing of fetal heart rate on pressing the head down into the pelvis and prompt recovery on the release of pressure is termed Stallworthy’s sign. This sign is suggestive of posterior placenta praevia.
  • Turtle Sign: This is when the fetal head suddenly retracts back against the mother's perineum after it has emerged from the vagina. This retraction of the fetal head is caused by the baby's anterior shoulder being caught on the back of the maternal pubic bone, preventing delivery of the remainder of the baby.
  • Von Braun-Fernwald's Sign: Irregular softening and enlargement of the uterine fundus during early pregnancy. It occurs at 5-8 weeks gestation.

questions.text: A young male presents with a painless swelling in the right testis, which he noticed two months ago. On examination, the swelling is firm and non-tender, with no transillumination and the contralateral testis appears normal. An ultrasound reveals a hypoechoic mass in the right testis. Further imaging shows enlargement of the para-aortic and pre-aortic lymph nodes. Tumor markers, including AFP, β-hCG, and LDH, are elevated. The physician suspects testicular cancer.  What is the next appropriate step in management?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the raised AFP, β-hCG, and LDH levels are suggestive of testicular cancer and the next best step in management is high inguinal orchidectomy.

Clinical features of testicular carcinoma:

  • Painless testicular lump is the most common presenting feature.
  • Epididymo-orchitis.
  • Severe pain and acute enlargement of the testis because of haemorrhage into the tumour.
  • Intra-abdominal spread may cause abdominal or lumbar pain.
  • Lung metastases are usually silent but they can cause chest pain, dyspnoea and haemoptysis in the later stages of the disease.

Although testicular cancers often spread to the retroperitoneal lymph nodes, including the pre-aortic nodes. A biopsy of the scrotal mass or the lymph nodes is generally not the first step.  

A high inguinal approach is crucial because it allows for removal of the testicle along with the spermatic cord, minimizing the risk of further spread. This is the standard initial management for suspected testicular cancer. After removal of the affected testis, metastatic workup should be done with CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis.

Early-stage tumors don't require additional treatment after orchidectomy, while late-stage tumours are given combination chemotherapy with bleomycin, etoposide, and cis-platinum (BEP chemotherapy). They are highly sensitive to combination chemotherapy with BEP. So chemotherapy is given to high-risk cases and low-risk cases with a good prognosis are managed by surveillance protocols.

Other Options:

Option A: Lymph node biopsies, while sometimes necessary, are usually performed after a diagnosis of testicular cancer is established to assess the extent of spread.

Option B: Scrotal biopsies for testicular mass risk seeding the scrotal skin with cancer cells, potentially worsening the prognosis.

Option D: Repeating hormone markers while potentially useful for monitoring the disease after a diagnosis is made is not the priority when a suspicious scrotal mass and concerning lymphadenopathy are present.

Related Pearl: WHO 2016 classification of testicular tumors

I. Germ-cell tumors (GCTs) derived from germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Germ-cell neoplasia in situ
  • Seminoma
  • Non-seminomatous GCTs
    • Embryonal carcinoma
    • Yolk sac tumor, postpubertal-type
    • Choriocarcinoma
    • Teratoma, post-pubertal type
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

II. Germ-cell tumors unrelated to germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Spermatocytic tumour
  • Teratoma, prepubertal type
  • Yolk sac tumor, prepubertal type
  • Mixed

III. Sex cord stromal tumors

  • Leydig cell tumor
  • Sertoli cell tumor
  • Granulosa cell tumor
  • Fibroma–thecoma

IV. Tumor containing both germ-cell and sex cord-stromal elements

  • Gonadoblastoma

V. Hematolymphoid tumors

Related Pearl: Tumor Markers in Testicular Germ Cell

 

AFP

b-hCG

LDH

Seminoma

 -

+

++

Yolk sac tumor

+++

+

+

Choriocarcinoma

 -

+++

Embryonal carcinoma

 -

 Note:

 Alpha-fetoprotein AFP:

  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Yolk sac tumor
  • Teratocarcinoma
  • Mixed germ cell tumor
  •  AFP is never raised in pure seminomas or pure choriocarcinoma

human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG): Only the β subunit is measured by the most commonly available serum assays. Can be raised in

  • Choriocarcinoma
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Teratocarcinoma
  • Seminoma
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

 Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH):

  • LDH has limited sensitivity and specificity for seminoma, but LDH levels >2000 U/L are more consistent with bulky disease, and rising levels are an accurate indicator of recurrence.
  •  In non-seminomatous germ-cell tumors (NSCGT), LDH is directly related to tumor burden.

questions.text: For infants and children under the age of 2, which of the following samples are the best to diagnose UTI?
questions.solution:
For infants and children under age 2, suprapubic aspiration and urethral catheterization are the preferred methods due to their high reliability and minimal contamination risk.

Clinical features in UTI neonates include fever, vomiting, diarrhea, poor weight gain, and lethargy. If the child cries during voiding or has a weak urine stream with a palpable bladder, it implies urinary obstruction. High fever (>39ºC), persistent vomiting, dehydration, renal angle tenderness, or raised creatinine is considered a complicated UTI.

 The chief cause of UTI in children is Escherichia coli, others include Klebsiella, Enterobacter, and Staphylococcus saprophyticus. Risk factors for recurrent UTI are age <6 months, obstructive uropathy, female sex, vesicoureteric reflux (VUR), bladder dysfunction, constipation, and repeated catheterization. Bowel and bladder dysfunction increases the risk of recurrence, and micturating cystourethrogram (MCU) is done in children with recurrence of UTI.

A colony count of >105/mL of a clean catch sample is considered significant bacteriuria. Any colonies on suprapubic aspiration and >50,000/mL on urethral catheterization are considered significant. Patients with recurrent UTIs need to be evaluated with ultrasonography, DMSA scan (dimercaptosuccinic acid), and MCU. 

Evaluation following the first episode of UTI is given below: 

Age Evaluation
<1 year USG, MCU, DMSA renal scan
1 to 5 years USG, DMSA scan. MCU is done if USG is abnormal
>5 years USG. If USG is abnormal,  MCU and DMSA are done.

Third-generation cephalosporins or aminoglycosides are preferred empirical antibiotics for urinary tract infections (UTIs). Treatment duration is 7-10 days for simple UTIs and 10-14 days for complicated UTIs. Asymptomatic bacteriuria doesn't require treatment. Infants <3 months and those with complicated UTIs should receive parenteral antibiotics. 

Cotrimoxazole, nitrofurantoin, cephalexin, and cefadroxil are given as prophylaxis to prevent recurrent UTIs. Cotrimoxazole and nitrofurantoin can be given in infants >3 months of age. 

Other Options:

(Options A and C): For toilet-trained children (typically over age 2-3), a clean-catch midstream urine specimen is the recommended method. This involves proper cleaning of the perineum, spreading the labia in girls or retracting the foreskin in uncircumcised boys, and collecting the middle portion of urination. 

(Option D): Perineal bag collection, while convenient, has an unacceptably high false-positive rate (85-99%) due to contamination and should never be used to diagnose UTI - a negative bag specimen can help rule out UTI, but a positive culture requires confirmation with a more reliable method.

questions.text: The presence of edematous villi, a 46 XX karyotype, and negative p57Kip2  suggests a diagnosis of ___________________.
questions.solution:
Edematous villi with 46 XX chromosome and a negative p57Kip2 immunostaining is suggestive of Complete Mole.

Hydatidiform moles may be either partial or complete:

Complete moles:

  • They occur due to the fertilization of an egg that has lost its female chromosomes.
  • In about 90% of the cases, the genetic material of one sperm is duplicated, resulting in a diploid 46, XX karyotype.
  • In the remaining 10% of the cases, the empty egg is fertilized by two sperms, resulting in a diploid karyotype, which is either 46, XX, or 46, XY.
  • In complete moles, the embryo usually dies early in the development, and hence, cannot be identified. 
  • p57Kip2 immunostaining is negative.

Partial moles (Option C):

  • They occur due to the fertilization of an egg with two sperms.
  • The karyotype is usually triploid (69, XXY) or occasionally tetraploid (92, XXXY).
  • Fetal tissues are typically present.
  • They are associated with an increased risk of persistent molar disease but are not associated with choriocarcinoma.
  • p57Kip2 immunostaining is positive.

Option A: Ectopic pregnancy is one in which the fertilized ovum is implanted and develops outside the normal endometrial cavity. The majority of ectopic pregnancies occur in the fallopian tube, the ampulla being the most common site.

Option B: Choriocarcinoma is the neoplasm of trophoblastic cells. It secretes large quantities of hCG hormone, which is used as a tumor marker in the diagnosis and management of the tumor. 

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Feature Partial mole Complete mole
Karyotype 69 XXX or 69 XXY 46 XX or 46 XY
Diagnosis Missed abortion Molar gestation
Uterus size Small for date Large for date
Theca-lutein cysts Rare 25–30% of cases
Initial hCG levels <1 lakh mIU/ml >1 lakh mIU/ml
Medical complications Rare Uncommon
Rate of subsequent GTN 1–5% 15–20%
Embryo-fetus  Often present Absent
Amnion, fetal erythrocytes Often present Absent
Villous edema  Focal Widespread
Trophoblastic proliferation Focal, slight to moderate Slight to severe
Trophoblast atypia Mild Marked
p57KIP2 immunostaining Positive Negative

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with anasarca is found to have proteinuria >4g/day, oedema and hypoalbuminemia, which is consistent with nephrotic syndrome. What is the recommended management for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and investigations are highly suggestive of minimal change disease in nephrotic syndrome and the initial treatment of choice is with steroids.

Minimal change nephrotic syndrome is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome. It is seen in ages 2-6 years with a clinical picture of nephrotic syndrome, that is, heavy proteinuria, oedema, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia. They may be asymptomatic or can present with peripheral oedema. Renal biopsy is not required for confirmation and treatment can be initiated if the child fits the standard clinical picture of nephrotic syndrome.

They show excellent response to steroid therapy with prednisone or prednisolone. A daily dose of 2mg/kg (max 60mg) for 6 weeks followed by an alternate dose of 1.5mg/kg (max 40mg) for the next 6-8 weeks is recommended.

Alternative drugs used in steroid-dependent patients, frequent relapsers, steroid-resistant patients, and those with severe corticosteroid toxicity are as follows:

  • Cyclophosphamide
  • Calcineurin inhibitors: Cyclosporine and Tacrolimus
  • Mycophenolate
  • Levamisole
  • Rituximab (chimeric monoclonal antibody against CD20)

Related Pearl: Nephrotic and nephritic syndromes

 

Nephrotic Syndrome

Nephritic Syndrome (Glomerulonephritis)

Primary pathology

Damage and dysfunction of glomerular filtration barrier, causing significant leakage of plasma proteins without much glomerular inflammation

Significant inflammatory injury of the glomerulus resulting in passage of RBCs, inflammatory cells & plasma proteins

The principal site of glomerular injury

 Visceral epithelial cell (Podocyte) Endothelial cells, glomerular basement membrane (GBM), Mesangial cells, Parietal epithelial cells (>Crescents)

Clinical features

Hallmark:

Heavy Proteinuria: 3.5 g/24 h or Urine protein:creatinine ratio >3) 

Hypoalbuminemia, 

Edema

Lipiduria, Hyperlipidemia

Microscopic hematuria

Hypertension

Hypercoagulability                                                    

Hallmark:

Hematuria (RBC casts/dysmorphic RBCs)

Varying degrees of proteinuria and pyuria

Renal dysfunction

Hypertension

Associated Glomerular pathology

Minimal change disease (Primary and secondary)

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) (Primary and secondary)

Membranous-nephropathy (Primary and secondary)

Diabetic nephropathy

Amyloidosis

Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (crescentic)

IgA nephropathy (Berger disease)

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis

Alport syndrome

These syndromes, however, are not mutually exclusive. Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythromytosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: A female presents with hirsutism, delayed periods & obesity. USG findings are given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the ultrasound image given below showing an enlarged ovary with multiple follicles in the periphery(a string of pearls) is indicative of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).

PCOS is an endocrinopathy seen in women of reproductive age, affecting multiple systems. The Rotterdam criteria are used to diagnose PCOS. The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS:

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne)
  • Menstrual abnormalities (oligo/amenorrhoea), anovulation, infertility
  • Polycystic ovaries on ultrasonography.

Sonographic criteria for polycystic ovaries include ≥ 12 small cysts, an increased ovarian volume (> 10 mL) or both. 

Management:

  • Weight reduction alone is beneficial in mild hirsutism and lifestyle changes (like smoking cessation) are advised in the management of PCOS.
  • Oral contraceptive pills (OCP), preferably fourth-generation pills with 30 mcg E2 and 2-3 mg drospirenone are used to treat menstrual abnormalities. It also reduces acne and further hirsutism.
  • Anti-androgens are useful in treating hirsutism. OCP with cyproterone acetate is prescribed for PCOS patients with hirsutism. 
  • Patients with PCOD are more prone to developing insulin resistance which can be controlled with metformin. Acarbose can be used if metformin is contraindicated
  • Patients presenting with infertility are treated by inducing ovulation using clomiphene as a first-line drug, along with dexamethasone and letrozole.

Surgical options include laparoscopic ovarian drilling or puncture of not more than four cysts in each ovary. This is done either by laser or by unipolar electrocautery. It restores the endocrine levels and improves fertility.

Surgery is indicated only if,

  • Medical therapy fails
  • Hyperstimulation occurs
  • Infertile women
  • Previous pregnancy losses

Other Options:

Option B: Molar Pregnancy will produce a characteristic Snowstorm appearance on ultrasound.

Option C: Enlarged ovaries meeting in the midline having large cysts are suggestive of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome.

Option D: The image below depicts multiple theca lutein cysts.

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 - 70 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

questions.text: What is the important area depicted in the given image?
questions.solution:
The image above shows the computed tomography (CT) scan of the ostiomeatal complex.

The following image gives an explanation of these structures.

The coronal CT scan demonstrates key components of the ostiomeatal unit:

  1. Ethmoid bulla, indicated by a white arrow
  2. Maxillary sinus ostium, marked by a white arrowhead
  3. Middle meatus, denoted by asterisks
