  6. Ethmoid infundibulum, traced by a dashed line

questions.text: In developed countries, which kind of screening saved the most lives ?
questions.solution:
Cervical cancer screening has been the most successful cancer screening program in medical history for developed countries.

According to WHO, widespread use of screening in high-income countries has resulted in a dramatic decline in cervical cancer mortality over the last three decades. Moreover, IARC concludes that there is sufficient evidence that cervical cancer screening can reduce cervical cancer mortality by 80% or more among screened women.

The introduction of the Pap smear by Dr. George Papanicolaou led to a dramatic reduction in cervical cancer mortality, with death rates declining by more than 70% since its implementation in the 1950s. This success is due to the test's ability to detect precancerous changes (cervical intraepithelial neoplasia) before they become invasive cancer, allowing for early intervention and prevention. WHO suggests that, in high resource settings, cytology (pap smear) is the most widely used screening test. A

The key distinction is that Pap smear screening not only detects early cancer but can prevent it entirely by identifying precancerous changes, making it uniquely effective among cancer screening programs.

Other options:

Option B: Breast cancer screening, while important, has shown more modest mortality reduction (around 20-30%) and has generated controversy regarding overdiagnosis and false positives;

Option C: Oral cancer screening has not demonstrated significant population-level mortality benefits in developed countries, partly due to its lower incidence and the lack of a standardized screening program;

Option D: Prostate cancer screening with PSA testing has been particularly controversial due to concerns about overdiagnosis, overtreatment, and unclear mortality benefit, with some studies showing minimal impact on overall survival.

questions.text: A patient with a history of pneumonia develops pleural effusion. What is the expected finding in the pleural fluid analysis for parapneumonic effusion?

choices.text: Pleural protein ratio less than 0.5 of serum protein
Pleural LDH less than 2/3rd of serum LDH
Pleural LDH less than 0.6 of serum LDH

questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario of a patient with a history of pneumonia who develops a pleural effusion, the expected finding in the pleural fluid analysis for parapneumonic effusion is pleural pH less than 7.2.

Pleural effusion refers to the pathological accumulation of fluid in the pleural space due to:

  • excess fluid formation from the interstitial spaces of the lung, parietal pleura or peritoneal cavity
  • decreased fluid removal by the lymphatics

Pleural effusion may present with:

  • dyspnea
  • pleuritic pain
  • dry cough
  • associated symptoms like fever, weight loss, oedema, and ascites depending on the aetiology.

On examination, there may be:

  • tachypnea, in a large effusion
  • dullness to percussion
  • decreased/absent breath sounds at the base(s)
  • other signs present vary with the underlying aetiology.

The aetiology of pleural effusion can be:

  • Exudative: Due to a disruption in pleural fluid formation and drainage because of local factors.
  • Transudative: Due to a disruption in pleural fluid formation and drainage due to systemic factors.

Light’s criteria can be used to differentiate between transudative and exudative pleural effusions. Exudative effusions will meet at least one of the following criteria:

  1. Pleural fluid protein/serum protein >0.5.
  2. Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH >0.6.
  3. Pleural fluid LDH is more than two-thirds of the upper limit of normal for serum and pleural pH less than 7.2.

Recommended tests for all diagnostic thoracocentesis include:

  • Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and protein
  • Microscopy and culture
  • Cytology and differential count
  • Glucose, pH, triglycerides, amylase, hematocrit, AFB culture, and PCR can be done if a particular aetiology is suspected.

If the difference between the protein levels in the serum and the pleural fluid is > 3.1 g/dL, it is likely to be transudative pleural effusion. If the glucose levels are less than 60mg/dL, then the effusion is likely due to exudative causes like malignancy, bacterial infections (parapneumonic effusion), and rheumatoid pleuritis.

If the pleural fluid cytology, culture, glucose, and staining do not yield any result, perform spiral CT to rule out pulmonary embolism and assess the markers of tuberculosis.

Related Pearl: Types of pleural effusion

Transudative Pleural effusion

  • Congestive heart failure
  • Cirrhosis
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Peritoneal dialysis
  • Superior vena cava obstruction
  • Myxedema 
  • Urinothorax

Exudative Pleural effusion 

  • Neoplastic disease: metastatic disease and mesothelioma
  • Infectious disease
  • Pulmonary embolization
  • GI: Esophageal perforation, pancreatic disease, intraabdominal abscess etc.,
  • Collagen vascular disease: SLE, rheumatoid pleuritis, Wegener's, Churg Strauss syndrome etc.,
  • Post coronary bypass surgery
  • Asbestos exposure
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Drug-induced pleural disease: nitrofurantoin, dantrolene, bromocriptine, amiodarone etc.,
  • Radiation therapy
  • Hemothorax
  • Chylothorax

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to ER after a car accident. He had multiple injuries and a femoral shaft fracture. He was treated and stabilized. But 48 hours later, he suddenly develops breathing difficulty, increased heart rate and petechial rashes.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
History of sudden onset breathlessness and rashes on 3rd day of admission after femoral shaft fracture should raise suspicion of fat embolism.

Fat embolism is the presence of fat globules in vital organs and peripheral circulation after fracture of the long bone or other major trauma.

Pathogenesis- release of free fatty acids by the action of lipases on the neutral fats and actual obstruction of small pulmonary vessels by fat globules.

Clinical features:

  • Early signs are fever and tachycardia
  • Presenting features are of 2 types- Cerebral type: drowsiness, restlessness, disorientation or Pulmonary type: tachypnoea, tachycardia
  • Other features: petechial rash in front of neck/anterior axillary fold/ chest/ conjunctiva

The classical clinical triad consists of respiratory distress, neurological abnormalities, and petechial haemorrhages

Treatment of fat embolism is mainly supportive:

  • Respiratory support (oxygen)
  • Heparinization (increases lipoprotein lipase activity)
  • Intravenous low molecular weight dextran
  • Corticosteroids: To avoid pneumonitis
  • Prompt stabilization of long-bone fractures 

Other Options:

Option A: Beck's triad (hypotension, distended neck veins, and muffled heart sounds) is seen in cardiac tamponade. 

Option B: Pneumothorax can cause sudden, sharp chest pain and difficulty breathing, but it often presents with hyper-resonant percussion (tapping on the chest) and decreased breath sounds on the affected side.

Option C: Sudden onset dyspnoea and bilateral fine basal crackles are signs of Pulmonary edema.

Related Pearl: Gurd's criteria for diagnosing fat embolism syndrome

Major criteria
  • Axillary or subconjunctival petechiae
  • Hypoxemia with PaO2 <60 mmHg, FIO2 < 0.4
  • CNS depression disproportionate to the hypoxemia
  • Pulmonary edema

Minor criteria

  • Tachycardia (HR >110 beats per minute)
  • Pyrexia (temp >38.50C)
  • Emboli visible in retina
  • Fat globules in urine
  • Fat globules in sputum
  • Unexplanied drop in hematocrit or platelet count 
  • Increased ESR

 At least one major criterion and four minor criteria are required to make a diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome.

questions.text: An abdominal X-ray of a baby presenting with abdominal distension and hematochezia reveals air in the bowel wall. What is the greatest risk factor for the development of this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a baby presenting with abdominal distension and hematochezia, with X-ray findings of pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall) is suggestive of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). Prematurity is the greatest risk factor for developing NEC.

NEC is the most common life-threatening gastrointestinal disorder in newborns. It is characterized by mucosal or transmural inflammation resulting in necrosis of the intestinal tract. It most commonly affects the distal ileum and proximal colon. Three major risk factors implicated are prematurity (the greatest risk factor), formula feeding, and bacterial colonization of the intestine.

Babies usually present within the 2nd or 3rd week of life with abdominal distension and tenderness, feed intolerance, and occult/gross blood in the stool. Systemic features include hypotension, bradycardia, lethargy, and temperature instability.

Diagnosis can be made with a plain abdominal X-ray. The important signs are pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall), portal vein gas, and pneumoperitoneum (indicates perforation).

The given X-ray shows pneumatosis intestinalis (black arrows).

Management of NEC includes supportive measures like keeping the baby nil per oral (NPO), nasogastric decompression, intravenous fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and inotropic support if indicated. Perforation is an absolute indication for surgery. The most effective preventive strategy is the use of human milk.

questions.text: Identify the imaging modality.
questions.solution:
The image depicts a retrograde pyelogram.

Retrograde Pyelogram is particularly valuable when IVP/CT is contraindicated and excels at providing detailed imaging of the collecting system, especially for evaluating ureteral strictures and filling defects, making it especially useful in surgical planning. 

Other Options:

Option B: In Retrograde urethrogram, the urethra is visualized with the instillation of contrast into the anterior urethra (penile urethra and bulbar urethra). It helps diagnose anterior urethral abnormalities. The following image shows an image of retrograde urethrogram contrast leakage at the membranous urethra.

Option C: Intravenous Pyelography (IVP) provides comprehensive visualization of the entire urinary collecting system, useful for detecting stones, tumors, and anatomical abnormalities, though it's becoming less common with the advent of CT urography and has limitations in patients with renal insufficiency or contrast allergies. 

Option D: Antegrade Pyelography, performed through a nephrostomy tube, is particularly useful when retrograde access isn't possible and helps evaluate obstruction below the kidney, often being employed in patients with existing nephrostomy tubes. The image shows an antegrade pyelogram of grade III hydronephrosis with obstruction at the ureterovesical junction.

questions.text: A patient presents with diffuse abdominal pain, and on examination, there is generalised tenderness along with board-like abdominal rigidity. An X-ray of the abdomen is provided. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the chest radiograph showing air under the diaphragm are suggestive of a hollow viscus perforation resulting in perforation peritonitis.

Perforation of a viscus is a life-threatening condition that occurs following the rupture of the alimentary tract. This leads to the leakage of the enteric contents, thereby leading to acute bacterial peritonitis. Peritonitis is the generalized or localized inflammation of the peritoneum either due to the free spillage of fluids into the peritoneal cavity or secondary bacterial infection.

Clinical features of hollow viscous perforation occur due to the developed peritonitis and the features include abdominal pain and distension, nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, tenderness, rebound tenderness, decreased or absent bowel sounds, and guarding on palpation. Fever may be present. Sometimes, features of septic shock can be seen at later stages.

Investigations include estimating the white blood cell count, urea, serum electrolytes, and an erect abdominal radiograph showing free gas under the diaphragm. A supine radiograph may show dilated gas-filled loops of the bowel, suggestive of paralytic ileus. The below image shows a hollow viscus perforation.

Management of a hollow viscous perforation is mainly resuscitation, analgesics, intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics, and emergency laparotomy. Peritonitis is managed by nutritional support, pain relief, correction of fluid loss and circulating volume, urinary catheterization with or without gastrointestinal compression, antibiotics, analgesics, and specific surgical treatment of the cause.

Other Options: 

Option A: Clinical presentation of acute pancreatitis is characterized by epigastric pain radiating to the back which is relieved by bending forward, nausea, and vomiting. 

Option C: Duodenal ulcer pain occurs 1.5 to 3 hours after a meal and is frequently relieved by antacids or food. Gastric Ulcer pain/discomfort may be precipitated by food. Nausea and weight loss are common.

Option D: A hiatal hernia occurs when a portion of the stomach pushes through the diaphragm into the chest cavity. It can cause symptoms such as heartburn, regurgitation, and chest pain, and may require medical or surgical treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following hormone is responsible for the following natural process?
questions.solution:
Oxytocin helps in the ejection of milk by myoepithelial contraction which can be felt as cramps.

     Functions of oxytocin are:

  • Milk ejection (Myoepithelial contraction)
  • ADH like action in high doses (reduces urine output)
  • Uterine contraction

Hormones acting on breast

Function Definition Hormone
Mammogenesis Breast growth and development

Estrogen (Ductal growth)

Progesterone (Alveolar growth)
Lactogenesis Inititation of milk secretion Prolactin
Galactokinesis Ejection of milk Oxytocin
Galactopoiesis Maintanence of lactation Prolactin

questions.text: A child presents with eyelid crusting and a gritty sensation between the eyelashes. He also has difficulty in opening eyelids. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the presenting symptoms - eyelid crusting, gritty sensation between eyelashes, and difficulty opening eyelids - the most likely diagnosis is chronic blepharitis. 

Blepharitis is characterized by inflammation of the eyelid margins and typically presents with these exact symptoms, particularly the crusting and difficulty opening eyes in the morning due to accumulated debris.

Additional typical findings seen in Chronic Blepharitis are:

  1. Redness of lid margins
  2. Collarettes around eyelash bases
  3. Mild conjunctival injection

Types:

  • Posterior blepharitis
    • Inflammation of the inner portion of the eyelid (more common)
    • Caused by meibomian gland dysfunction
    • Associated with acne rosacea
  • Anterior blepharitis
    • Inflammation of the base of eyelashes
    • Two types
      • Seborrhoeic type which is associated with dermatitis. This is characterized by dandruff-like skin changes and greasy scales.
      • Staphylococcal type is characterized by fibrinous scales and crust around the eyelashes caused by colonization of the eyelids by Staphylococcus aureus and CoNS

Parasitic causes of blepharitis

  • Blepharitis acarica caused by Demodex folliculorum - A key clinical feature of this infestation is the presence of dandruff-like scaling at the base of eye-lashes.
  • Phthiriasis palpebrarum caused by crab louse.

Other options:

Option A: Conjunctivitis primarily affects the conjunctiva with redness and discharge, it doesn't typically cause significant eyelid crusting between the lashes.

Option C: Dry eye syndrome mainly presents with burning, foreign body sensation, and tearing but lacks the characteristic eyelid margin involvement and crusting.

Option D: Meibomian gland dysfunction (MGD) can be associated with blepharitis but primarily presents with tear film instability and evaporative dry eye.

questions.text: Soon after the administration of an epidural block with 1.5 % lignocaine with epinephrine, your patient went into bradycardia, hypotension, and apnea. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Bradycardia, hypotension, and apnea soon after the administration of an epidural block suggests accidental subarachnoid (intrathecal) injection resulting in total spinal anaesthesia.

Salient features of total spinal anesthesia:

  • Occurs following attempted epidural/caudal anesthesia if there is accidental intrathecal injection
  • Rapid onset, as the anesthetic required for epidural and caudal anesthesia, is 5–10 times that required for spinal anesthesia
  • High spinal anesthesia extends to involve cranial nerves
  • Accompanied by hypotension, bradycardia, apnea, and loss of consciousness

Prevention:

  • Careful aspiration for CSF (to rule out intrathecal placement) and blood (to rule out intravascular placement) before injecting the local anesthesia
  • Use of a test dose with lidocaine and adrenaline
  • Incremental injection techniques instead of a bolus dose

Treatment:

  • Maintaining an adequate airway and ventilation and supporting the circulation

Other options: 

Option A - Accidental subdural injection manifests after 15-20 minutes with features similar to a high spinal blockade.

Option C - Accidental intravascular injection manifests as systemic toxicity with CNS and CVS symptoms.

Option D - Allergic manifestation presents with hives, angioedema, and bronchospasm.

questions.text: What is correct about first-degree heart block?

choices.text: Normal PR and prolonged RR interval
Prolonged PR and normal RR interval
Short PR and normal RR interval

questions.solution:
The correct statement about the first-degree heart block is the ECG shows prolonged PR and normal RR interval.

First-degree heart block is characterized by a fixed, prolonged PR interval without any dropped beats. It indicates a delay in conduction through the AV node, but all atrial impulses still reach the ventricles. It is most often asymptomatic. Canon waves are observed in JVP. It carries a very good prognosis and no treatment is needed.

A heart block is caused by an interruption of impulse conduction within the conducting system of the heart. It may be sinoatrial, atrioventricular, or intraventricular. Atrioventricular blocks are further divided into type I, type II and type III blocks. The type II blocks are subdivided into Mobitz type I and Mobitz type II blocks. 

First Degree Heart Block: It occurs due to slowing of conduction through the AV junction. It is characterized by prolonged PR > 0.2s and equal RR intervals.

 

Second Degree Heart Block: It occurs due to the intermittent failure of electrical impulse conduction from the atrium to the ventricle. It is characterized by a missed QRS. It is of two types:

  • Mobitz type 1/ Wenckebach occurs due to the decremental conduction of electrical impulses in the AV node. It is characterized by a progressive PR elongation leading to an eventual drop in the QRS complex. This may be seen in young athletes.

 

  • Mobitz type 2 occurs in the distal or infra-His conduction system and is often associated with intraventricular conduction delays.  It is characterized by an intermittent failure of conduction of the p wave without any change in the preceding impulses. On ECG there is a fixed PR interval and missed QRS.

 

Third Degree Heart Block/Complete Heart Block

It occurs when none of the impulses from the atria are conducted to the ventricles. It is characterized by

  • Escape rhythm
  • RR equal, PP equal
  • P waves > QRS waves
  • No relationship between P & QRS.

Related Pearl: Types of Heart block

Related Pearl: Normal ECG waves and intervals

ECG wave/interval

Physiological correlates

P wave

Atrial depolarization

QRS complex (up to 0.10s)

Ventricular depolarization

T wave

Ventricular repolarization

U wave

Repolarization of ventricular myocytes with long action potential

PR interval  (0.12-0.2s) 

Atrial depolarization and conduction through AV node

QT interval  (up to 0.43s)

Ventricular depolarization and Ventricular repolarization

ST interval (Average 0.32s)

(QT minus QRS)

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential+ Ventricular repolarisation

ST segment

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential

questions.text: A man underwent vasectomy recently.  The surgeon advises the patient to abstain from sexual activity for a certain period after the procedure before confirming the success of the vasectomy. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation regarding the duration of abstinence post-vasectomy?

choices.text: 3 months and after semen analysis is done
1 month and after semen analysis is done

questions.solution:
A patient who has undergone a vasectomy should abstain from sexual activity for 3 months and undergo a semen analysis afterwards.

Vasectomy is a permanent sterilization procedure done in males, where a segment of the vas deferens is resected and ligated bilaterally.

This procedure is done under local anesthesia. A small incision is made in the scrotum. The vas deferens are divided on both sides, disrupting the passage of sperms. The no-scalpel technique has been now adopted. One single incision is made with special forceps and a skin stitch is not required. Clips and plugs can be applied over the vas instead of cutting. The failure rate of vasectomy is 0.15%.

It is a relatively simple procedure with low rates of complications. A patient who had a vasectomy is not sterile immediately after the procedure as semen is stored in distal channels of the vas deferens for varying periods.

Hence, for this reason, it is estimated that at least 20 ejaculations or 3 months are required to empty the stored semen. During this time, additional contraceptive measures should be used.

questions.text: A 28-year-old lactating female presents 2 weeks after delivery, with a 3 cm subareolar mass in her right breast. The mass is associated with redness, tenderness, and mild warmth. She reports no fever but mentions difficulty in breastfeeding from the affected breast. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lactational mastitis.

Lactational mastitis is caused by a local bacterial infection when the breast is most vulnerable due to cracks and fissures in the nipples.

Mastitis occurs due to a combination of factors such as inadequate milk drainage and the introduction of bacteria present on the skin. The cracks in the nipple serve as an entry point, thus resulting in infection. The most common organism causing acute mastitis is Staphylococcus aureus.

Acute bacterial mastitis typically occurs during the 1st month of breastfeeding (lactational breast abscess). 

Staphylococcal acute mastitis typically results in localized abscesses. Signs and symptoms of this condition involve:

  • Fever and malaise
  • Localized pain and tenderness 
  • Redness and swelling of the affected breast
  • Fluctuation test positive due to pus in the abscess. It is a late sign.

Management includes analgesia, continued expression from the breast, antibiotics such as amoxiclav, and repeated aspiration of pus. In case of aspiration and antibiotics failure, incision and drainage can be done.

Other Options:

Option A: Mondor’s disease is characterized by thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast and anterior chest wall.

Option B: Breast abscess is a sequela of untreated bacterial mastitis, which occurs due to the growth of staphylococcus or streptococcus due to breast milk stasis. Patients usually present with fever and malaise, localised pain and tenderness, redness and swelling of the affected breast and fluctuation test positive due to pus in the abscess, which is a late sign of breast abscess. 

Option C: A galactocele is a milk-filled cavity in the breast of a woman who is usually lactating. It can be caused due to lactation problems, prolactin stimulation by drugs, or duct obstruction. It presents as a palpable, round, well-circumscribed, and freely mobile mass with no fever, pain, or inflammation. It is usually subareolar and unilateral.

questions.text: Graham Steell murmur is heard in _____
questions.solution:
Graham Steell murmur is the early to mid-diastolic murmur heard in pulmonary regurgitation.

Graham Steell murmur is a high-pitched murmur heard best at the left second intercostal space and is often louder with inspiration. This murmur occurs due to pulmonary regurgitation, which in this case, is secondary to pulmonary hypertension. It can also be seen in patients with COPD due to the development of cor pulmonale leading to pulmonic hypertension.

Other options:

Option A: Pulmonary stenosis is a narrowing of the pulmonary valve or artery, obstructing blood flow from the right ventricle to the lungs. It is associated with a harsh systolic ejection murmur heard best at the left upper sternal border, often with a systolic thrill.

Option C: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is a condition where the heart muscle thickens, often affecting the interventricular septum. It is associated with a systolic ejection murmur that increases with the Valsalva manoeuvre and decreases with squatting.

Option D: A ventricular septal defect (VSD) is a congenital heart defect where there is an abnormal opening in the septum between the left and right ventricles. It is typically associated with a holosystolic murmur heard at the left lower sternal border.

questions.text: A lady came to the hospital after fighting with her husband. She reports that she is unable to speak. However, all neurological and physical examinations are normal, and she does not seem concerned about her condition. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
La-belle indifference is seen in conversion disorder. It is the absence of concern towards one’s problem despite the apparent severe disability.

Conversion disorder is also called functional neurological symptom disorder, and there is no bodily cause involved in this condition. A conversion reaction is an acute and temporary loss or alteration in motor or sensory function triggered by psychosocial stress. Most of the patients have a history of a traumatic event in childhood. The symptoms or deficits of conversion disorder are not intentionally produced. It is more commonly seen in females.

Primary gain refers to keeping internal conflicts outside of awareness and the relief from stress. Secondary gain refers to the attention gained by the patient (from bystanders) as a result of being sick. If the secondary gain is intentional, then it would lead to the diagnosis of malingering. A related phenomenon is la belle indifference, in which the patient is not concerned about the serious symptoms.

Symptoms of conversion disorder:

  • One or two neurologic symptoms affecting the voluntary or sensory function
  • Must have psychologic factors associated with the onset or exacerbation of the symptoms.
  • Mutism, blindness, and paralysis are the most common symptoms.
  • Sensory system: Anesthesia and paresthesia
  • Motor system: Abnormal movements, gait disturbance (astasia abasia), weakness, paralysis, tics, jerks, etc.
  • Central nervous system: Pseudo-seizures

Other Options:

Option A: Adjustment reaction is a psychological response to an identifiable stressor that results in the development of clinically significant emotional or behavioral symptoms. The condition develops within 3 months of exposure to the stressor and lasts no longer than 6 months after the stressor or its consequences have ended. Notably, the emotional or behavioral symptoms must be out of proportion to the stressor when considering cultural and contextual factors.

Option B: Somatic symptom disorder is the presence of one or more somatic symptoms for more than 6 months in the absence of an organic cause is suggestive of somatic symptom disorder. It is characterized by the fear of having a serious illness based on the person's misinterpretation of bodily symptoms.

Option C:Malingering is the intentional falsification of physical or psychological symptoms to achieve some practical gain such as financial compensation, avoidance of criminal responsibility or military service, or leave from work. 

Related Pearl: Conversion Disorder

Conversion disorder: Also called functional neurological symptom disorder.

Common presenting symptoms:

  • Weakness and/or paralysis
  • Non-epileptic seizures
  • Movement disorders
  • Speech or visual impairment
  • Swallowing difficulty
  • Sensory disturbances
  • Cognitive symptoms

Diagnostic criteria:

  • Symptoms of altered neurological function-voluntary motor or sensory
  • Often precipitated by a psychological stressor (the temporal relationship between stressor and symptoms is present)
  • Not feigned or intentionally produced (as in factitious disorder or malingering)
  • Findings incompatible with a recognized neurological condition
  • Symptoms cause significant social or occupational impairment

Other important features:

  • Presence of primary and secondary gain
  • La-belle indifference: refers to an absence of concern towards one’s problem despite severe disability

Management options:

  • First-line: Education and self-help technique
  • Second-line: Cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Physical therapy for motor symptoms

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms does the term 'affective flattening' imply ?
questions.solution:
Affective Flattening denotes the negative symptoms associated with Schizophrenia.

The two-syndrome concept as formulated by T. J. Crow: He classified schizophrenia into 2 types:

Feature Type I Type II
Presentation Acute Chronic
Symptoms Positive symptoms Negative symptoms
Response to neuroleptics Good response Poor response
CT/MRI Normal Abnormal like enlarged ventricles, small hippocampus and temporal lobe

Negative symptoms of schizophrenia:

  • Affective flattening/Blunting - Inability to understand or recognize displays of emotion from others and an inability to express emotion. It is an important predictor of functional impairment in schizophrenia.
  • Alogia - Decrease in verbal communication, or “poverty of speech,”
  • Avolition/apathy - Loss of will or drive
  • Anhedonia - Loss of the ability to find or derive pleasure from activities or relationships and may be the most persistent of the negative symptoms.
  • Attention impairment

Positive symptoms of schizophrenia (Option B): hallucinations, delusion, bizarre behavior, positive formal thought disorder

Schizophrenia is a psychosis, a type of mental illness characterized by distortions in thinking, perception, emotions, language, sense of self, and behavior.

The DSM-5 criteria to diagnose schizophrenia require a total duration of 6 months. Within this 6-month period, there must be at least 1 month of active-phase symptoms (overt psychotic symptoms) where 2 or more of the following have to be present, with at least one among the symptoms a, b, or c: 

a. Delusion
b. Hallucination
c. Disorganized speech (or formal thought disorder)
d. Disorganized behavior
e. Affective flattening or other negative symptoms

Affective or mood symptoms and cognitive symptoms are not included in the diagnostic criteria for schizophrenia.

questions.text: How much time delay should there be between the delivery of the head and delivery of the shoulder in the case of shoulder dystocia?
questions.solution:
Shoulder dystocia is defined as head to shoulder delivery time more than 60 seconds.

Shoulder dystocia, defined as a head-to-body delivery time >60 seconds, occurs when either the anterior or the posterior (rare) fetal shoulder impacts on the maternal symphysis or the sacral promontory respectively.

Risk factors

Prelabour (Mnemonic: DOPE) Intrapartum

D: Diabetes Mellitus

 Prolonged 1st and 2nd stage of labour
O: Obesity Instrumental delivery

P: Postdatism and prior history

 Augmentation of labour with oxytocin
E: Excessive weight gain during pregnancy  

Management of labour in case of shoulder dystocia includes the following.

  • Gentle downward traction of the fetal head with suprapubic pressure (not fundal).
  • Mc. Roberts manoeuvre involves the flexing of the legs against the abdomen with concurrent suprapubic pressure. Below is a diagram depicting the Mc. Roberts manoeuvre.

Woods corkscrew manoeuvre involves the pro­gressive rotation of the posterior shoulder by 180 degrees in a corkscrew fashion to release the impacted anterior shoulder. Below is a diagram depicting the Woods corkscrew manoeuvre.

Zavanelli manoeuvre: It involves the replacement of the fetal head into the pelvis followed by cesarean delivery.
Other manoeuvres include Rubin's maneuver (rocking fetal shoulders side to side) Gaskin maneuver (All fours maneuver), Symphysiotomy (cutting the symphyseal carti­lage and ligamentous supports) and cleidotomy (fracture of the clavicle using an instrument). Below is a diagram depicting the cleiodotomy procedure.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with persistent swelling and discomfort over the dorsal aspect of the index finger. He gave a history of penetrative trauma to the area a few days ago. On examination, there is a firm, tender mass with limited mobility of the distal interphalangeal joint. The image is shown below. If left untreated, what is the most likely complication?

choices.text: Gangrene of the fingertip due to compromised vascular supply
Secondary infection requiring removal of the nail bed
Frog-like deformity of the finger caused by chronic inflammation and tendon dysfunction
Injury to blood vessels during wound cleaning leading to ischemia

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of penetrating trauma followed by swelling over the dorsal aspect of the index finger that could progress to a "frog-like" deformity, making this the correct answer.

A "frog-like" finger refers to a Boutonnière deformity - a condition where the middle joint of a finger is bent inward while the tip joint is bent excessively outward, creating a distinctive appearance similar to a frog's leg bent at the knee; essentially, the finger looks like it's making a "buttonhole" shape. 

The progressive tendon dysfunction leading to the frog-like deformity represents the natural history of untreated cases due to the anatomical relationship between the central slip of the extensor tendon and the dorsal aspect of the middle phalanx where the infection is located.

This deformity occurs when chronic inflammation and infection of the extensor tendon mechanism leads to destruction of the central slip at the dorsal aspect of the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint. This results in the characteristic deformity where the PIP joint becomes flexed while the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint becomes hyperextended.

Other Options:

Option A: Gangrene of the fingertip is unlikely as the vascular supply to the digit remains intact in these cases unless there's significant compartment syndrome, which would present with more severe symptoms.

Option B: Removal of the nail bed would not be necessary as the pathology is centred over the phalanx rather than the nail complex. 

Option D: Injury to blood vessels during wound cleaning is not a natural complication of the condition itself but rather an iatrogenic possibility.

questions.text: Identify the structure in the given image.
questions.solution:
The arrow is pointing at Blastocyst.

Around the 4th/5th day of development, the morula becomes the blastocyst. Fluid passes into the morula from the uterine cavity and converts it to a blastocyst with a fluid-filled cavity called blastocoele. This fluid partially separates the cells of the inner cell mass from the outer cell mass.

Cell masses in the blastocyst:

  • The outer cell mass is called the trophoblast and forms a major part of the placenta
  • The inner cell mass is called the embryoblast and forms the embryo proper

The blastocyst normally implants in the functional layer of the uterine endometrium.

Timeline of implantation:

  • 3-4 days after fertilization: The morula (12-16 cells) enters the uterus.
  • 4th day after fertilization: The advanced morula reaches the uterine lumen.
  • 4-5 days after fertilization: The early blastocyst stage is seen.
  • 6-7 days after fertilization: The blastocyst implants in the uterus. Implantation corresponds to 20-22 days of the menstrual cycle.

questions.text: What is the accommodative amplitude of a patient with a near point at 20 cm and a far point at infinity?
questions.solution:
The amplitude of accommodation for the above patient would be 5 dioptres.

Near point of accommodation (NPA) is the closest distance at which the near object is clearly focussed without blur.

Amplitude of accommodation is the maximum power of the lens that permits clear near vision without blur. Its unit is dioptre (D). The amplitude of accommodation is the reciprocal of near point of accommodation (NPA) in meters.

20 cm is 1/5th of a metre. Therefore, the accommodative amplitude is its inverse, that is, 5D.

Note:

The NPA is measured clinically using a scale device such as the Prince, Berens, or Royal Air Force (RAF) ruler.

questions.text: A person presents with complaints of clawing of the 4th and 5th fingers. Along with it, there is sensory loss at tips of these fingers. What structure is most likely to be damaged?
questions.solution:
The given description is of a clawing of 4th and 5th finger with loss of sensation in the tips of these fingers are classically seen in case of an ulnar nerve injury.

The ulnar nerve supplies the medial two lumbricals, adductor pollicis, interossei, and hypothenar muscles in the hand. The lumbricals are primarily responsible for the extension at the interphalangeal joints. Therefore, in ulnar nerve palsy, there is clawing of the medial two fingers.

In ulnar nerve palsy, only the medial two fingers develop clawing, while in a combined median and ulnar nerve palsy, all four fingers develop clawing. 

The following tests are done to test the integrity of the ulnar nerve:

  • Egawa's test - In a positive test, due to the weakness of the dorsal interossei, side-to-side movements of the middle finger is weak.
  • Book test or Froment's sign - The patient is asked to hold a book between the thumb and index finger while the examiner attempt to pull it forcefully. In case of an ulnar nerve injury, the adductor pollicis is paralyzed and the patient attempts to hold the book with the flexor pollicis longus muscle supplied by the median nerve.
  • Card test - In the case of weak palmar interossei, the examiner can pull out the card with ease. 

Other options

Option B - In radial nerve palsy, the patient presents with a wrist drop due to paralyzed wrist extensors. In high lesions, there is sensory loss on the dorsum of the hand over the anatomical stuff box. 

Option C - In median nerve injury, paralysis of opponens pollicis muscle leads to ape thumb deformity. A pointing finger deformity can also be seen due to paralyzed flexors of the fingers.

Option D - The anterior interosseous nerve supplies the flexor digitorum profundus muscle of the index finger and damage to the nerve prevents flexion of the index finger.

Related Pearl: Seddon's classification of nerve injuries

Seddon's classification includes 3 groups

  1. Neurapraxia
  2. Axonotmesis
  3. Neurotmesis

Neurapraxia:

Reversible physiologic conduction block. Occurs due to mechanical pressure causing segmental demyelination.

E.g.,Saturday night palsy, torniquet, and crutch palsy

Axonotmesis: 

Axonal interruption. Conduction is lost but the nerve is in continuity and neural tubes are intact.

E.g.,Closed fractures and dislocations

Neurotmesis: 

Division of the nerve trunk. Endoneurial tube destruction also occurs.

E.g., Complete section of nerve in open fractures

questions.text: An obese patient presented with pain in the right hypochondrium. He has a history of unhealthy food consumption. On examination, the liver was palpable below the costal margin. On USG, grade 2 fatty liver was diagnosed. What will be the initial management for this patient?
questions.solution:
In this clinical scenario, an obese patient presents with right hypochondrial pain and a history of poor dietary habits. Examination reveals a palpable liver, and ultrasound confirms Grade 2 fatty liver, suggesting Non-Alcoholic Steatohepatitis (NASH). The initial management involves weight reduction and lifestyle modifications, including a healthier diet and regular physical activity.

Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is associated with diabetes and obesity. The fatty change may also be caused by the effect of toxins (including certain medications), protein malnutrition, dyslipidemia, and anoxia. Bleomycin, Methotrexate, Doxycycline, and L-asparaginase are other drugs causing hepatic steatosis.

Nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) is characterised by hepatic steatosis which is complicated by histologically evident hepatocyte death and inflammation. Currently, biopsy is the best investigation to establish the diagnosis.

The current approach to NAFLD management focuses on treatment to avoid or decrease the risk factors for NASH (like obesity, insulin resistance, metabolic syndrome, and dyslipidemia) and lifestyle changes as initial management.

Alpha-tocopherol or vitamin E is the first-line treatment considered for non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH). In many studies, vitamin E was well-tolerated and showed modest improvements in AST levels, radiographic features of hepatic steatosis, and/or histologic features of NASH.

  • Vitamin E should only be considered as the first-line pharmacotherapy for non-diabetic NASH patients.
  • Dose: 800 IU/day.

questions.text: During a laproscopic surgery while inserting a lateral trocar for surgery which of the following is most prone to injury ?

choices.text: Both superior and inferior epigastric artery

questions.solution:
The most common source of bleeding during laparoscopic surgery is through both superior and inferior epigastric arteries. 

These vessels run vertically in the posterior rectus sheath along the lateral border of the rectus abdominis muscle, creating a high-risk zone for trocar placement. The superior epigastric artery descends from the internal thoracic (mammary) artery, while the inferior epigastric artery ascends from the external iliac artery, and they anastomose within the rectus muscle. Their consistent anatomical location and the fact that they run in a relatively superficial plane within the anterior abdominal wall makes them particularly vulnerable during trocar insertion.

To avoid injury, surgeons must carefully identify the lateral border of the rectus muscle and place trocars either medial or significantly lateral to this zone, and transillumination of the abdominal wall can help identify these vessels.

Injury to these arteries can result in significant bleeding, making it the most common source of haemorrhage in this type of surgery. Proper identification and careful dissection are essential to avoid this complication.

questions.text:
A child with short stature and developmental delay comes to your clinic. On investigation, low calcium, high phosphate and very high PTH are found. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

PTH-Parathyroid hormone
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical scenario of a child with short stature and developmental delay with low Calcium, high Phosphate and very high PTH, the most likely diagnosis is Pseudohypoparathyroidism (PHP)

Pseudohypoparathyroidism (PHP) is a condition where the body is resistant to parathyroid hormone (PTH) despite its excessive production. This leads to low calcium, high phosphate, and very high PTH, as the kidneys and bones do not respond to PTH signals. The associated short stature and developmental delay are characteristic of Albright’s hereditary osteodystrophy (AHO), a subtype of PHP.

In hypoparathyroidism, there is low PTH, leading to low calcium and high phosphate. However, in this case, the child has very high PTH, which suggests that the parathyroid glands are producing enough hormone, but the body's tissues are not responding to it properly.

Pseudohypoparathyroidism is an inherited disorder that is characterized by hypocalcemia and characteristic skeletal features, known as Albright's hereditary osteodystrophy (AHO). It is due to the loss of function mutation in genes encoding the alpha subunit of the stimulatory G-protein Gsα. This blocks the action of PTH, leading to reduced serum calcium and increased serum phosphate. AHO features include short stature, short metacarpals and metatarsals (brachydactyly), round facies, intellectual impairment, and heterotropic calcifications.

Although serum calcium is low and serum phosphate is high (like hypoparathyroidism), PTH levels are also found to be elevated, and thus this disorder is termed pseudohypoparathyroidism. Urinary cAMP excretion is low because PTH is unable to act on its downstream pathways.

Other Options:

Option A: Hypoparathyroidism is due to the decreased production of parathormone from the parathyroid glands. It is characterized by low calcium and low parathormone levels with elevated phosphate. Clinical features of hypocalcemia due to hypoparathyroidism include paresthesias, seizures, carpopedal spasm, bronchospasm, laryngospasm, and prolongation of the QT interval.

Option B: Hypothyroidism generally presents with symptoms such as fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, and dry skin. It does not typically cause elevated parathyroid hormone levels or the specific constellation of symptoms seen in this patient (recurrent kidney stones, abdominal pain, and altered mentation).

Option D: Rickets occurs due to inadequate intake of dairy products rich in vitamin D, lack of vitamin supplementation, and decreased sunlight exposure. It results in a mild decrease in calcium levels, elevated parathormone levels due to secondary hyperparathyroidism, and low phosphate levels.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a 3 cm soft, non-tender, and fluctuant swelling on the upper back. The lesion has been present for several months and occasionally drains a foul-smelling, cheesy material. What is the most appropriate management for this condition?

choices.text: Complete surgical excision including the capsule
Surgical excision of the cyst content leaving behind a portion of the wall
Incision and drainage of the cyst

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of a sebaceous cyst and the best management is complete surgical excision including the capsule.

A sebaceous cyst is derived from hair follicle infundibulum or traumatic inclusion. The most common site of a sebaceous cyst is the postauricular sulcus or below and behind the ear lobule. Malignancy is rare. 

Clinical features of a sebaceous cyst include:

  • Benign swelling that is mobile, fluctuant, and fixed to the skin. It presents with a central punctum in about 70% of cases. 
  • It is generally an asymptomatic, non-tender swelling. It can be painful and red if inflamed.
  • It may ooze out a foul-smelling, cheese-like discharge.

Treatment depends on the clinical state of the cyst. When inflamed or infected, they should be incised and drained initially. After the inflammation subsides, a total surgical excision of the cyst is performed. If the cyst wall is not removed, there is a risk of recurrence. Perilesional triamcinolone injection helps with inflammation resolution but not cyst eradication.

The complications include sebaceous horn, cock’s peculiar tumor, and abscess formation. The treatment involves the excision of the cyst along with normal skin using an elliptical incision.

Below is an image showing an inflamed sebaceous cyst with a central punctum:

Other Options:

Option A: Topical application of antibiotics wont be correct choice for the given case scenario beacuse Antibiotics alone are not indicated for management of sebaceous cyst.

Option C: Surgical excision of the cyst content leaving behind a portion of the wall is also not indicated as it may lead to high rate of recurrence.

Option D: Only Incision and drainage is also not enough .When cyst is inflamed or infected, they should be incised and drained initially. After the inflammation subsides, total surgical excision of the cyst is performed.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient who suffers from prinzmetal angina requires a formulation of nitroglycerine which has the most rapid onset of action. Which of the following formulations of nitroglycerin can be administered to the patient?
questions.solution:
The sublingual route of administration has a very rapid onset of action (1-3 mins). The onset of action is more rapid when administered as a spray when compared to a tablet. 

The sublingual route is used for the termination of attacks. Oral extended-release capsule and transdermal patch are used for prophylaxis. The onset of action is approximately ≥60 min.

Topical nitroglycerine ointment can be used to provide symptomatic relief in patients with anal fissures.

Summary of Pathogenesis of Major Findings in Congestive Heart Failure

Abnormality

Cause

Weakness, exercise intolerance, fatigue

Left ventricle output inadequate to perfuse muscles; especially, failure of output to rise with exercise

Ankle, sacral edema

Increased peripheral venous pressure →increased fluid transudation.

Hepatomegaly

Increased peripheral venous pressure →increased resistance to portal flow.

Pulmonary congestion

Increased pulmonary venous pressure →pulmonary venous distention and transudation of fluid into air spaces

Dyspnea on exertion

Failure of left ventricular output to rise during exercise → increased pulmonary venous pressure

Paroxysmal dyspnea, pulmonary edema

Probably a sudden failure of left heart output to keep up with the right heart output →acute rise in pulmonary venous and capillary pressure →transudation of fluid into air spaces.

Orthopnea

Normal pooling of blood in lungs in supine position added to the already congested pulmonary vascular system; increased venous return not put out by the left ventricle. (Relieved by sitting up, raising the head of the bed, lying on extra pillows.)

Cardiac dilation

Greater ventricular end-diastolic volume.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman complains of fatigue, dry skin and cold intolerance since 2 weeks. She was started on amiodarone 1 month ago for persistent atrial fibrillation. Tests show high TSH (15 mU/l) and low free T4 levels. How would you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Thyroxine supplementation is indicated for amiodarone induced hypothyroidism which is characterized by symptoms of hypothyroidism (fatigue, dry skin, cold intolerance) and lab findings (elevated TSH, reduced free T4) following amiodarone use.

Amiodarone-induced hypothyroidism (AIH) can occur shortly after (as early as 2 weeks) amiodarone use due to iodine induced thyroid suppression (Wolff Chaikoff effect). It is characterized by clinical features of hypothyroidism and lab findings of elevated TSH and reduced free T4. It occurs more frequently in women and those with positive thyroid peroxidase antibodies. It is managed by thyroxine supplementation, without the need to discontinue amiodarone (Option A).

Amiodarone is an iodine-containing compound that is structurally related to thyroid hormone. It is a class III antiarrhythmic drug, which increases the duration of an action potential by blocking potassium channels, thereby increasing the time taken for repolarization. It is used to maintain normal sinus rhythm in atrial fibrillation.

Amiodarone can cause hypothyroidism due to the Wolff-Chaikoff effect, where excessive iodine leads to transient inhibition of organification and synthesis of thyroid hormones. Patients with underlying autoimmune thyroid disease are at increased risk of amiodarone-induced hypothyroidism.

Other adverse effects of amiodarone include hypotension, bradycardia, myocardial depression, photosensitization, corneal microdeposits (corneal verticillata), pulmonary fibrosis, and peripheral neuropathy.

Other options: 

Option C: Corticosteroids would be indicated in amiodarone induced thyrotoxicosis and not amiodarone induced hypothyroidism.

Option D: Patients who are asymptomatic, with subclinical hypothyroidism following amiodarone use can be managed by observation and regular monitoring with thyroid function tests. Subclinical hypothyroidism is characterized by TSH level > 4.5 and ≤ 10 mU/l, normal FT4 and absence of clinical features of hypothyroidism.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions shown in the given CT is associated with the Holman-Miller sign?
questions.solution:
The given CT showing the Holman-Miller sign is associated with nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.

Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a benign but locally invasive tumor predominant in adolescent males aged 10-20 years. It arises from the posterior part of the nasal cavity, close to the superior margin of the sphenopalatine foramen. These patients have a hamartomatous nidus of vascular tissue in the nasopharynx that grows to form angiofibroma under the influence of testosterone. Therefore, it is thought to be testosterone-dependent.

Angiofibroma can extend into the nasal cavity causing obstruction, epistaxis, paranasal sinuses, pterygomaxillary fossa, infratemporal fossa, cheek, orbits causing proptosis, frog-face deformity, and cranial cavity. The clinical features include:

  • Profuse, recurrent, spontaneous epistaxis - most common; Internal maxillary artery is the most common source artery of nasal bleeding followed by ascending pharyngeal artery and external, internal, and common carotid arteries.
  • Progressive nasal obstruction and denasal speech - due to mass in the postnasal space
  • Conductive hearing loss and otitis media with effusion - due to obstruction of the eustachian tube
  • Sessile, lobulated, or smooth mass in the nasopharynx
  • Other clinical features include the broadening of the nasal bridge, proptosis, cheek swelling, involvement of IInd, IIIrd, IVth, and VIth cranial nerves

Diagnosis typically involves contrast-enhanced CT scans, which reveal the tumour's size and any bony destruction, along with characteristic signs such as anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus known as the Antral sign or Holman-Miller sign (shown in the image below). Biopsy of the mass is generally avoided due to the risk of severe bleeding.

Surgical excision remains the mainstay of treatment, with various approaches depending on tumour extent. Common surgical techniques include:

  • Transpalatine approach
  • Lateral Rhinotomy
  • Endoscopic Techniques: minimally invasive
  • Maxillary Swing Approach: larger tumours.
  • Intracranial-Extracranial Approach: significant intracranial extension

Other Options:

Option A: Haller cells are a type of ethmoidal cells that are situated on the roof of the maxillary sinus. Sometimes they may enlarge and block the opening of the maxillary sinus leading to maxillary sinusitis.

Option C: Antrochoanal polyp is a type of non-neoplastic nasal polypoidal masses of edematous nasal or sinus mucosa which arises from the mucosa of the maxillary antrum near its accessory ostium. The clinical features include unilateral nasal obstruction, mucoid nasal discharge, and a hyponasal voice.

Option D: Unilateral obstruction of the nasal cavity due to the presence of mass and nasal bleeding is suggestive of the diagnosis of rhinosporidiosis. Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi. It is most prevalent in rural districts, among persons bathing in public ponds or working in stagnant water, such as rice fields.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is correct regarding intrinsic acute kidney injury?

Fractional excretion of sodium (FENa)
questions.solution:
The correct statement regarding intrinsic acute kidney injury is BUN: Creatinine < 20:1

AKI (acute kidney injury) is defined as a decline in kidney function within 7 days, resulting in the accumulation of nitrogenous waste and other toxic metabolites usually excreted in the urine. It includes a variety of conditions that share some common features such as elevated creatinine levels and reduced urine output. It is broadly divided into three categories:

  • Prerenal azotemia 
  • Intrinsic parenchymal disease
  • Postrenal obstruction

Intrinsic causes can further be divided into acute tubular necrosis, acute glomerulonephritis, and acute interstitial nephritis. Ischemia and nephrotoxins are the main causes of acute tubular necrosis. Nephrotoxins can be exogeneous such as vancomycin, cisplatin, and iodinated contrast agents used for CT imaging. Endogenous toxins include myoglobin, uric acid, and haemoglobin. Crush injuries, heat stroke, and myopathies can result in rhabdomyolysis releasing large amounts of myoglobin. The urine/plasma creatinine ratio is usually ≤ 40.

In acute tubular necrosis, urinary sodium is >20 mEq/L. 

Prerenal azotemia arises due to a reduced renal plasma flow. Common causes include hypovolemia, liver failure, and congestive heart failure. The urine/plasma creatinine ratio is ≥ 40 and urinary sodium is usually <20mEq/L.

Bladder outlet obstruction, urethral obstruction, and benign prostatic hyperplasia lead to postrenal azotemia. Urinary sodium can be variable.

The factors that can help differentiate prerenal and renal causes of AKI are as follows:

Indices Prerenal Renal
Spot urine sodium (mEq/L) <20 >40
Fractional excretion of sodium (FENa) <1% >2%
Fractional excretion of urea (FEUrea) <35% >35%
Urine osmolality (mOsm/kg) >500 <350
BUN to serum creatinine ratio >20:1 <10:1
Urine creatinine/plasma creatinine >40:1 <20:1
Urinary sediment Nil or hyaline casts only Renal tubular epithelial casts, muddy brown granular casts

More causes of AKI are given below:

questions.text: Chvostek's sign is seen in?
questions.solution:
The Chvostek's sign is seen in Hypocalcemia.

Chvostek's sign is a clinical indicator of hypocalcemia, seen in conditions like hypoparathyroidism and vitamin D deficiency. It is elicited by gently tapping the facial nerve just anterior to the ear, which triggers involuntary twitching of the facial muscles, particularly around the mouth and eye.

While a positive Chvostek's sign suggests neuromuscular excitability due to low calcium levels, it is not always specific, as mild twitching can also occur in healthy individuals. This sign is often assessed alongside Trousseau's sign to confirm hypocalcemia. Trousseau’s sign is a clinical indicator of hypocalcemia, where inflating a blood pressure cuff above systolic pressure for a few minutes induces carpal spasm (involuntary contraction of the hand and fingers). It signifies increased neuromuscular excitability due to low calcium levels.

Symptoms and signs of hypocalcemia include mild circumoral or digital numbness, paresthesia, laryngeal spasms, and cardiac arrhythmias. 
Chvostek's sign and Trousseau's sign, as shown in the image below.

The given image shows Bohler Braun splint used for unilateral leg traction.
