questions.text:
A patient presented with nasal congestion and upon examination, nasal polyps were observed. A coronal CT scan finding of the patient is given below. Which of the following sinus drainage pathways is likely to be affected?

 CT - Computed Tomography
questions.solution:
In this patient with rhinosinusitis and nasal polyps, the CT scan indicates that the maxillary sinus is likely affected, as evidenced by the presence of a polyp in this sinus.

Antrochoanal polyp is a type of non-neoplastic nasal polypoidal masses of edematous nasal or sinus mucosa. It arises from the mucosa of the maxillary antrum near its accessory ostium, comes out of it, and grows in the choana and nasal cavity. It is usually single and unilateral which are more commonly seen in children and young adults. 

It has 3 parts namely

  • Thin antral stalk,
  • Round and globular choanal part, and
  • Flat nasal part.

The clinical features include unilateral nasal obstruction, mucoid nasal discharge, and a hyponasal voice.

Anterior rhinoscopy may miss the antrochoanal polyp when it starts to grow posteriorly. A large polyp may protrude from the nasal cavity and may appear pink and congested. It is soft and can be moved with a probe. Posterior rhinoscopy may reveal a globular mass filling the choana and hanging down behind the soft palate. 

X-ray (lateral view) of soft tissue nasopharynx, reveals a globular swelling in the postnasal space, it is differentiated from angiofibroma by the presence of a column of air behind the polyp known as Dodd sign or crescent sign.

Diagnosis is made by radiograph of the paranasal sinuses reveals opacity of the involved antrum. Non-contrast CT scan reveals the extent of the polyp. Endoscopic examination reveals the antrochoanal polyp hidden posteriorly in the nasal cavity.

Endoscopic sinus surgery is the treatment of choice. Recurrence is uncommon after the complete removal of the polyp.

questions.text:
The patient is admitted with low urine output, and lab reports show BUN: 140 mg/dL, serum creatinine: 8.0 mg/dL, and 2+ protein on urine dipstick. Which of the following is most useful for distinguishing acute kidney injury (AKI) from chronic kidney disease (CKD)?

BUN-Blood urea nitrogen
questions.solution:
In a patient admitted with low urine output, BUN of 140 mg/dL, serum creatinine of 8.0 mg/dL, and 2+ protein on urine dipstick, the most useful criterion for differentiating acute kidney injury (AKI) from chronic kidney disease (CKD) is creatinine clearance.

Acute kidney injury (AKI) is defined as an increase in serum creatinine by 1.5 times of baseline value over 7 days.

Acute kidney injury is defined as an abrupt (within hours) decrease in kidney function, which encompasses both injury (structural damage) and impairment (loss of function). It is characterized by abrupt deterioration in kidney function, manifested by an increase in serum creatinine level with or without reduced urine output.

AKI is defined as any of the following:

  • Increase in serum creatinine to ≥1.5 times baseline (50% higher), which is known or presumed to have occurred within the prior 7 days.
  • Increase in serum creatinine by ≥0.3 mg/dL from baseline within 48 hours.
  • Urine volume of <0.5 ml/kg/h for 6 hours.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best non-invasive tool for assessing fetal anaemia?

choices.text: Middle cerebral artery doppler peak systolic velocity (MCA PSV)

questions.solution:
Middle Cerebral Artery Doppler peak systolic velocity (MCA PSV) is the best non-invasive way of monitoring fetal anemia.

MCA PSV is used for the monitoring of fetuses of Rh-negative sensitized mothers, and if it exceeds 1.5 MoM and the gestational age less than 34 or 35 weeks, fetal blood sampling followed by transfu­sion is considered.

Serial mea­surements of the peak systolic velocity of the fetal MCA is reliable, noninvasive, and the recommended test to detect fetal anemia. Blood gets shunted to the brain to maintain adequate oxy­genation. A rise in cardiac out­put and a fall in blood viscosity enhance the peak systolic velocity in the MCA.

The threshold value to identify fetuses with anemia is 1.5 multiples of the median (MoM) for gestational age and is 100% sensitive. 

For an MCA PSV between 1.0 and 1.5 MoM, weekly Doppler monitoring to be done. If MCA PSV exceeds 1.5 MoM and the gestational age is lesser than 34 or 35 weeks, fetal blood sampling followed by fetal transfusion to be done if needed. 

Beyond 34 weeks, the false-positive rate of MCA peak systolic velocity increases due to the normal increase in cardiac output that develops at this gestational age.

Middle cerebral artery velocimetry is more accurate than and has replaced amnionic fluid spectral analysis and is not associated with the risks of increased alloimmunization and amniocentesis. It is also applied clinically to evaluate fetal growth restriction.

 

Other Options:

Option A: Biophysical profile, aka Modified Manning score, is a screening test for uteroplacental insufficiency. The fetal CNS is highly sensitive to diminished oxygenation and helps plan the next course of action.

Option B: If the MCA peak systolic velocity > 1.5 MoM and the gestational age is <34 or 35 weeks, fetal blood sampling should be considered and followed by fetal transfu­sion if needed. But it will fall under invasive method.

Option C: Amniocentesis is the most common prenatal diagnostic procedure. It is performed using an aseptic technique, under direct sonographic guidance, using a 20–22 gauge spinal needle.Approximately 20 to 30 mL of fluid is collected for fetal karyotyping or chromosomal microarray analysis.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man is rushed to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, abdominal distension, and obstipation. His erect X-ray abdomen is as shown. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 64-year-old man with severe abdominal pain, abdominal distension, and obstipation along with the radiograph showing the coffee bean sign is likely to be sigmoid volvulus.

Sigmoid volvulus is a condition that occurs when the sigmoid colon twists on the sigmoid mesocolon.

A sigmoid volvulus can be differentiated from a cecal volvulus by swirl sign, location of the obstructed loop, and anatomical appendages. The swirl with sigmoid volvulus is located on the right quadrant while the swirl with cecal volvulus is located at the pelvic brim. 

Other options:

Option B: Colonic diverticulosis refers to the condition where multiple outpouchings occur along the gastrointestinal tract without any inflammation. The barium enema given below shows multiple outpouchings in the ascending, transverse, and descending colon resembling a saw-tooth. 

Option C: Cecal volvulus is more common in females in the 4th to 5th decade. It is characterized by ischemia. 

Option D: Paralytic ileus occurs secondary to neuromuscular failure. This leads to the failure of transmission of peristaltic waves. It mainly occurs following laparotomy. The image given below is an X-ray of a patient with a paralytic ileus.

Differences between the small bowel and large bowel obstruction:

Features Small bowel Large bowel
Valvulae conniventes Present in jejunum Absent
No of Loops Many Few
Distribution of loops Central Peripheral
Haustra Absent Present
Diameter 3-5 cm >5 cm
Solid feces Absent Present

questions.text: Identify the condition depicted in the laparoscopic image.
questions.solution:
The laproscopic image above depicts multiple miliary nodules on the uterine and peritoneal surfaces. This guides us towards the diagnosis of female genital tuberculosis (FGTB).

Genital Tuberculosis is caused by M. tuberculosis and almost always occurs secondary to primary infection elsewhere in the extragenital states. Most common route of spread is hematogenous and the most common site is bilateral fallopian tubes (most common part affected is ampulla and most common pathology encountered is endosalpingitis). 20-30 years age group is affected the most. Infertility is the most common symptom.

Site of genital TB % involved
Fallopian tubes 90-100
Uterus 50-60
Ovaries 20-30
Vagina/vulva 1-2

Other signs of Genital Tuberculosis include:

  • Tobacco-pouch appearance: Tubes appear dilated with fimbrial end open and pouting
  • External surface: Greyish with tubercles
  • On cut section: Lumen has yellowish-grey caseous matter or serosanguinous fluid (Tuberculous hematosalpinx) and pyosalpinx.

Other Options:

Option A: Hydrosalpinx is depicted in the image below.

Option D: A chocolate cyst is depicted below.

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic patient presents to you with severe pain and swelling of the left leg. He gives a history of sustaining a thorn prick to his left foot while hiking 5 days ago. The examination of his leg is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of cellulitis.

Cellulitis is a painful, diffuse infection of the dermis and the subcutaneous tissue. It is characterized by poorly demarcated areas of marked edema, dilated superficial capillaries, and extravasation of red blood cells and inflammatory cells into the dermis. Constitutional symptoms like fever and malaise are also present.

It is most commonly caused by beta-haemolytic Streptococci, Staphylococci, and Clostridium perfringens. The point of entry may be a traumatic or surgical wound. Lower limbs are the commonest site of cellulitis and any wound, including tinea pedis or bacterial infection, is a possible site of entry. The face is the next common site of infection.

Parenteral penicillin is the treatment of choice. Other regimens may include antistaphylococcal penicillins, cefazolin, ceftaroline, and ceftriaxone.

Other options:

Option A: Erysipelas is an infection of the superficial epidermis. It presents as an erythematous raised lesion with sharply demarcated edges that differentiate it from the surrounding skin. The given image shows erysipelas.

Option B: Lymphangitis will be evident with visible erythema tracking along lymphatic channels.

Option D: Necrotizing fasciitis is a rapidly progressive necrosis of the subcutaneous tissues and fascia. The source of the infection is either the skin following trauma or a surgical incision. Diabetes mellitus is the most common comorbidity associated with the condition. 

Local symptoms and signs are pain, erythema, edema, warmth, crepitus, blisters, bullae, greyish drainage (dishwater pus), necrosis, and gangrene. Systemic features are fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, shock, coagulopathy, and multiorgan failure. 

Treatment involves appropriate intravenous antibiotics with urgent radical surgical debridement.

The following image shows surgical debridement being done for a case of necrotizing fasciitis.

questions.text: A child with a history of intubation presented to the OPD with shortness of breath while playing, approximately six weeks later. X-ray finding is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis in this child with a history of intubation and shortness of breath with X-ray showing the 'steeple sign' due to subglottic narrowing is acute laryngotracheobronchitis.

Acute laryngotracheobronchitis is caused by the parainfluenza virus. The age of presentation of laryngotracheobronchitis ranges from 6 months to 6 years. The clinical features include barking cough, inspiratory stridor, hoarseness, and low-grade fever.

Management:

  • Racemic epinephrine nebulization rapidly improves upper airway obstruction. Epinephrine constricts pre-capillary arterioles in the upper airway mucosa and decreases capillary hydrostatic pressure, leading to fluid resorption and improvement in airway oedema.
  • Dexamethasone is administered by the least invasive route (Oral > IV > IM ) for all grades of croup.
  • Oxygen should be administered to children who are hypoxemic (SpO2 <92 %).

Antibiotics are not indicated in acute laryngotracheobronchitis.

Other options: 

Option A: Acute epiglottitis is a medical emergency presenting in children with a rapidly progressive course of fever, sore throat, dyspnea, and respiratory obstruction, followed by a toxic appearance and drooling. The neck is hyperextended and stridor is a late finding. Radiography shows a classic thumb sign as given in the image below.

Option C: In children with acute bronchitis, chest radiographs typically show minimal to non-specific findings. The most common radiological features include hyperinflation of lung fields, indicating air trapping and bronchial wall thickening.

Option D: Laryngomalacia is a congenital laryngeal anomaly presenting in children with low-pitched inspiratory stridor exacerbated by exertion. The laryngoscopy image showing omega-shaped epiglottis is given below.

Related Pearl: Acute stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane, and un-immunized
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: A doctor asks a patient about her age, and the patient responds, "You know doctor, I'm from a village, I was married at a very young age of 12 years and my husband was just 5 years older than me. Then I had two kids when I was around 18 or something. Now I am 38, but I look like their older sister". What is most likely thought disorder displayed by patient?
questions.solution:
The thought disorder known as circumstantiality best describes this patient's thought disorder.

Circumstantiality refers to a formal thought disorder in which a patient gives irrelevant and unnecessary details. This is before finally getting to the point or the correct answer. It may be seen in schizophrenia, obsessional distur­bances, and certain cases of dementia. An example is given below.

Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"

Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper, and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

A formal thought disorder is a disturbance in the formulation of thoughts and their expression. It is characterized by loosened associations, illogical constructs, and neologisms. Derailment, neologism, perseveration, and thought blocking are some examples.

Other options:

Option A: Clang association is a formal thought disorder where the thoughts are associated with the sound of words through rhyming, rather than the meaning of the words. It is usually seen in schizophrenia or mania. An example is "I am Sam...I like jam...I travel in a tram"

Option B: Flight of ideas refers to a rapid succession of multiple associations, where the thoughts appear to abruptly shift from one idea to another. It is usually seen in mania. An example is "I like mangoes, the weather is nice, India is great"

Option D: Tagentiality is a formal thought disorder where the patient says something that is related to the general topic. Although, the actual answer is not given. An example is as below.

Doctor: "How has your appetite been lately?"
Patient: "I usually have dinner with my wife, but now I eat alone"

Related Pearl: Disorders of thought and perception

DISORDERS OF THOUGHT
 

DISORDER OF STREAM OF THOUGHT

(A) Disorder of tempo

(i) Flight of Ideas

Continuous flow of rapid speech that jumps from topic to topic

  • "I like mangoes, the weather is nice, India is great"

(ii) Retardation of thinking

Slow speed of speech and a prolonged latent period before a response

  • "I went to the market (pause)......... the shop was closed"

(iii) Circumstantialities

Inclusion of irrelevant details and going on in a roundabout manner, but their thought ultimately reaches the answer

  • Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"

  • Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

(iv) Clang associations

Jumping from one word to another irrelevant rhyming word

  • I am Sam...I like jam...I travel in a tram"

(B) Disorder of continuity

(i) Perseveration

Repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas beyond the point of relevance.

  • Q1. What's your name?: "Rahul"

  • Q2. Where are you from?: "Rahul"

  • Q3. How old are you?: "Rahul"

(ii) Thought blocking

A sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas

  • "I went to the market (extreme silence)...................."
 

DISORDER OF FORM OF THOUGHT

(i) Tangentiality

In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

  • Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?"
  • Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa"

(ii) Derailment

A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.

  • "Some people just don't understand why I had breakfast in America during the first world war"

(iii) Neologisms

Bringing in new words that do not exist.

  • The world is not 'gooder' for people like me"

(iv) Desultory thoughts

Speech is grammatically correct, however, sudden unrelated ideas force their way in from time to time.

  • My actual problem is that the people never understand me and my stomach feels like an empty bucket"

(v) Word salad

Using a mixture of unintelligible meaningless words and sentences

  • Tree bus rain food home car tiger"
 
 

DISORDER OF POSSESSION OF THOUGHT

(A) Obsession and compulsion

(i) Obsessions

Recurrent and persistent thoughts, impulses. or images that cause distress to oneself.

  • Fear of dirt or contamination
  • Fear of becoming ill
  • Constant thoughts of a certain number
  • Need for symmetry or exactness
  • Worry about whether something has been done "right"
  • Forbidden sexual or religious thoughts

(ii) Compulsions

Repetitive behaviors or actions that the person feels driven to perform in response to an obsession

  • Washing hands
  • Blinking eyes
  • Counting items, such as currency
  • Checking to see if doors are locked
  • Arranging items in a certain way
  • Requiring constant approval from people around them
(B) Thought alienation

(i) Thought insertion

Thoughts are being inserted into the patient's mind and they recognize them as being foreign and coming from without any stimulus

  • "I have repeated thoughts of killing my neighbors and I believe aliens are putting these ideas into my head at night"

(ii) Thought withdrawal

Delusion that someone or something is removing from one's mind and the patient has no power over this.

  • "Lately, I am losing all my memories and I believe that the 'government agents' are stealing them when I go to sleep"

(iii) Thought broadcasting

Belief that one's thoughts are quietly escaping from one's mind and that other people might be able to access them and hear or see them.

  • "I believe my exact thoughts appear on the TV and the internet and I think I can broadcast them globally" 

(iv) Thought echo

Patient hears the 'echo' of his own thoughts in the form of a voice after he has made the thought.

  • "I thought of making a sandwich in the morning and surprisingly a voice, from nowhere, told me to make a sandwich out loud"
 

DISORDER OF CONTENT OF THOUGHT

(i) Phobias

Persistent fear of an object or situation, typically disproportional to the actual danger posed, in which the sufferer goes to great lengths in avoiding it

  • Arachnophobia - fear of spider
  • Barophobia - fear of gravity
  • Cynophobia - fear of dogs
  • Hemophobia - fear of blood
  • Nosocomephobia - fear of hospitals

(ii) Religious preoccupations

Thoughts involving religious themes or subject matter.

  • "I get instructions from God on how to make my country great"

(iii) Ideas of hopelessness

Thoughts of complete despair where the patient strongly believes that the circumstances will never get better for him.

  • "I am never going to pass my final exams, no matter how hard I study"

(iv) Antisocial urges

Thoughts of indulging in some behaviors or actions that harm or lack consideration for the well being of others.

  • "I have these urges to go rob a bank or blackmail my neighbors for their money"

(v) Derealization

Alteration in the perception or experience of the external world so that it seems unreal

  • "The world and everything around is nothing but just a dream"

(vi) Depersonalization

Feeling as if one is disconnected from reality, feeling detached from one's own thoughts and one's own physical body

  • "I sometimes drift into a dream-like state where I lose contact with my own self"

(vii) Delusions

False beliefs that are strongly held and unchangeable in the face of refuting evidence and that are not consistent with the person's educational, social and cultural background.

The three main criteria for a belief to be considered a delusion are:

  • Certainty (held with complete confidence)
  • Incorrigibility (not changeable by proof to the contrary)
  • Impossibility or falsity of content (implausible, bizarre or patently untrue)

 

DISORDERS OF PERCEPTIONS

  • Illusion: Misinterpretation of real external stimuli.

  • Hallucination: False sensory perception, externally.

  • Pseudohallucination: False sensory perception from within and having an insight.

questions.text: In which of the following scenarios is this instrument contraindicated?
questions.solution:
The image shows Piper's forceps, identified by its distinct perineal curve. It is contraindicated in obstructed labour.

Piper forceps is a specialized forceps, used to assist the delivery of the after-coming head of the breech (Option A). It can also be used in cases of occipito-posterior position and caesarian delivery (Options B and C). It has a cephalic curve, reverse pelvic curve, and long parallel shanks that permit the baby’s body to rest against it during head delivery.

Related Pearl: Obstetrics forceps

Commonly used forceps: 

1) Simpson forceps

  • The most commonly used types of forceps in outlet delivery.
  • Has elongated cephalic curve.
  • These are used when there is substantial molding of the fetal head.

2) Elliot forceps

  • Has an adjustable pin for regulating the lateral pressure on the handles.
  • They are used most often when there is minimal molding.
  • More suitable for outlet delivery.

3) Kielland forceps

  • Has small pelvic curve and a sliding lock.
  • Suitable for head with little molding.
  • The most common forceps used for rotational delivery.
  • Helps correct asynclitism.

4) Piper forceps

  • Distinct perineal curve.
  • Allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

5) Tucker-McLane forceps

  • Suitable for fetal head with little molding.
  • Used in rotational delivery.

6) Barton forceps and traction handle

  • Used in rotational delivery.
  • Most importantly used for delivery of occipitotransverse positions in a platypelloid pelvis.
  • It is an obsolete procedure.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a patient presenting with a bone tumor showing a sunburst appearance on imaging?
questions.solution:
A bone tumor with a sunburst appearance on imaging is most likely osteosarcoma.

Osteosarcoma is the most common non-hematologic primary malignancy of bone. It occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. It is typically metaphyseal. The distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus are the commonly involved sites.

In osteosarcoma, the tumor lifts the periosteum and incites an intense periosteal reaction. The periosteal reaction is irregular and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance on X-ray.

Other options:

Option A: Osteoclastoma or Giant cell tumor is commonly seen in the age group of 20-40 years with a slight female preponderance. The distal end of the femur is the most common location followed by the proximal tibia and distal radius. 

Radiographic findings: 

  • Eccentrically located solitary lytic lesion in the epiphysis
  • Soap bubble appearance
  • Periosteal new bone formation is absent.

Option B: Osteoid Osteoma

The image shows presence of metadiaphyseal cortical osteoid osteoma involving the upper end of the femur with radiolucent nidus surrounded by cortical sclerosis.

Nidus of osteoid osteoma is present in the cortex and hence CT scan will be the best investigation to diagnose osteoid osteoma.

Image:

  • Black arrow - Nidus
  • White arrow - Cortical sclerosis

Option D: Ewing's sarcoma is a primary malignant tumor of the bone commonly involving the age group of 4-25 years involving the diaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, fibula, and humerus.

X-ray shows onion-peel appearance due to deposition of periosteal reaction in layers is the typical finding.

Decade

decade

decade

Decade

questions.text:
A 6-year-old girl came to your clinic with refractive power of +1D in right eye and -2D in left eye. Fundus examination reveals normal acuity and retinal findings. What is the correct diagnosis?

D - dioptre
questions.solution:
The history of defective vision and 2 different refractive errors of the eyes suggests a diagnosis of anisometropia.

Anisometropia occurs when the total refraction of both eyes are unequal. A difference of 1D in the two eyes causes a 2% difference in the size of retinal images formed. A difference up to 2.5D is well-tolerated, but beyond 4D cannot be tolerated. Anisometropia can occur as a combination of emmetropia, myopia, hypermetropia, and astigmatism.

It is diagnosed after retinoscopic examination and autorefractometry. 

Treatment includes the usage of spectacles (it can be tolerated up to a maximum difference of 4D), contact lenses, intraocular lenses (for uniocular aphakia), refractive corneal surgery, or refractive lens exchange methods (used in high degree anisometropia).

Other options: 

Option B: Myopia (Short-sightedness): The parallel rays of light coming from infinity are focused in front of the retina when accommodation is at rest.

Option C: Hypermetropia(Long-sightedness): The parallel rays of light coming from infinity are focused behind the retina when accommodation is at rest.

Option D: Amblyopia or 'lazy eye' is a developmental defect of spatial visual processing that occurs in the central visual pathways of the eye.

Related Pearl: Causes of Myopia

Myopia

Etiology

Axial myopia

(Most common)

Increase in the anteroposterior length of the eyeball.

Curvatural myopia

Increased curvature of the cornea, lens, or both

Positional myopia

Anterior placement of the crystalline lens in the eye

Index myopia

Increase in the refractive index of crystalline lens

Nocturnal myopia

Due to spherical aberration and accomodation

questions.text: Identify the area marked in the given image.
questions.solution:
The arrow in the image points to the rectovesical pouch.

The peritoneum covering the anterior surface of the rectum is reflected anteriorly to cover the posterosuperior surface of the bladder in males, forming a rectovesical pouch. This is the lowest part of the peritoneal cavity in males and an important site for pelvic fluid collection.

Other options:

Option B: Rectouterine pouch- The peritoneum which covers the anterior surface of the rectum is reflected anteriorly to cover the posterior surface of the posterior fornix of the vagina and the uterus, forming a rectouterine pouch.

Option C: Vesicouterine pouch- The peritoneum covering the fundus and body of the uterus, is reflected anteriorly to cover the posterosuperior surface of the bladder forming a vesico uterine pouch

Option D: Pouch of Morrison (hepatorenal recess) - The peritoneum covering the posterior surface of the right lobe of the liver is reflected posteriorly to cover the anterior surface of the right kidney and right suprarenal gland, forming a deep, vertical groove. This is the deepest peritoneal recess in the supine position and an important site for fluid collection.

questions.text: A nulligravida presents to the OPD with uterine prolapse. No cystocele or rectocele were noted. What procedure will you perform?
questions.solution:
For a nulligravid woman with uterine prolapse and no cystocele or rectocele, we will perform an abdominal sling surgery.

Abdominal sling operations are designed for women with type II or III degree prolapse and who are desirous of retaining childbearing function and menstrual function.

Abdominal sling surgeries: Young women desirous of retaining menstrual and reproductive functions are ideal candidates. These surgeries use tapes as slings to prevent organ descent. These include:

  • Abdominal wall cervicopexy (modified by Purandare and Mathre): sling attached to cervix posteriorly near uterosacral ligaments. 
  • Shirodkar's sling surgery: the sling fixes the cervix to the lumbosacral fascia.
  • Khanna's sling surgery: - sling fixed to the anterior superior iliac spine, strengthening the Mackenrodt's ligament. 

Other options :

Option A: Le fort's repair - is done in patients who satisfy the following criteria:

  • Very elderly menopausal patient with an advanced prolapse
  • Do not wish to retain sexual function
  • Medically unfit for major surgeries

Option B: Fothergill surgery - Also known as Manchester's operation is suitable for women under 40 years who are desirous of retaining their menstrual and reproductive functions. It involves anterior colporrhaphy with amputation of the cervix. The mackenrodt ligaments are sutured in the front of the cervix and colpoperineorrhaphy is done. It increases the risk of cervical incompetence leading to recurrent abortions and preterm deliveries. Shirodkar's modification of Fothergill's repair avoids cervical amputation, hence subsequent pregnancy complications are avoided.  

Option D: Shirodkar sling surgery - the sling fixes the cervix to the lumbosacral fascia.

Related Pearl: Management of Uterine prolapse

Congenital/ Nulliparous (young) uterine prolapse: Sling/ cervicopexy

Uterovaginal uterine prolapse:

Age/condition Desire for pregnancy Desire for menstruation Surgery
<40 No Yes Fothergill's operation
>40 No No  Ward Mayo's vaginal hysterectomy
>60(medically unfit for hysterectomy)        -      - Le Forts repair
Prolapse during pregnancy /puerperium     -       - Ring Pessary

Related Pearl: Degrees of vault prolapse

  • First degree: The vaginal apex is visible at the introitus
  • Second degree: The vault protrudes through the introitus
  • Third degree: The entire vagina is outside the introitus

questions.text:
A patient has multiple blood clots in the urine following a TURP procedure. Which catheter should be used for irrigation in this patient?

Transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP)
questions.solution:
22 French Foley's 3-Way Catheter is the most appropriate choice for this patient with blood clots after a TURP procedure.

The 3-way Foley catheter includes an additional channel for continuous bladder irrigation, making it essential for managing gross hematuria, post-prostate surgery care, and clot evacuation; this third channel allows for simultaneous inflow of irrigation fluid while maintaining continuous drainage.

Three-way Foley catheter, shown below, is used for irrigation and helps in preventing clot retention following surgeries like TURP.

Other options:

Option B: A 22 French 2-way Foley catheter, the most commonly used type, has two channels - one for urine drainage and one for balloon inflation, making it suitable for routine bladder drainage and post-operative care.

Option C: A 22 French 4-way Foley catheter, less commonly used, has an extra channel typically used for pressure monitoring or additional irrigation capabilities, particularly useful in complex urological procedures or when precise pressure monitoring is required.

Option D: The McKonly catheter, distinct from the Foley types, is specifically designed for suprapubic placement and features a curved tip and specialized drainage system; it's particularly useful for long-term bladder drainage in patients who cannot have urethral catheterization or require extended catheterization periods, though it requires surgical placement through the abdominal wall.

Related Pearl: Foley's catheter

A Foley catheter is a thin, sterile tube inserted into the bladder to drain urine. Because it can be left in place in the bladder for a period of time, it is also called an indwelling catheter.

French scale corresponds to the external circumference in millimetres. French size divided by 3 will give the outer diameter of the catheter. 

Fr. size = 3 x d, where d is the outer diameter in mm. 

A 3 Fr. catheter will have a circumference of approximately 3 mm and a diameter of 1 mm. 

Note:

Colour of the foleys is the colour at the baloon port as shown in the figure below

questions.text: A 61-year-old hypertensive male patient presents with back pain. He has been smoking for the past 30 years. On physical exam, he has an enlarged pulsatile mass over his abdomen. His CT scan is shown below. Which of the following is an indication for elective surgical repair in this patient?

choices.text: Presence of a pulsatile mass on physical exam

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describing a smoker with abdominal/back pain, history of hypertension and smoking, physical examination revealing a pulsatile mass, and CT findings showing dilation of the abdominal aorta is indicative of abdominal aortic aneurysm(AAA). Abdominal aortic aneurysm ≥5.5 cm is an indication for elective surgical repair of AAA. 

The following are indications for elective surgical repair of AAA:

  1. Asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm ≥5.5 cm
  2. Rapid expansion >1 cm in 1 year.
  3. Symptomatic patients/ patients with a ruptured aneurysm
  4. AAA associated with peripheral arterial aneurysm (eg, iliac, popliteal) or symptomatic peripheral artery disease (eg, iliac occlusive disease) undergoing revascularization


Surgical options for the repair of aortic aneurysms are endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) and open aneurysm repair. EVAR is preferred over open aneurysm repair in current practice.

Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is the most common type of large vessel aneurysm. The most important risk factor to develop AAA is atherosclerosis. In the majority of cases, it occurs below the renal arteries.

Risk factors for AAA are age, male sex, atherosclerosis, smoking history, hypertension, and connective tissue disorders like Marfan syndrome or Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

The patients may be asymptomatic or may present with symptoms of abdominal pain or back pain. They might have a pulsatile abdominal mass on palpation. The patients are hemodynamically stable in case of an intact aneurysm. A ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm should be suspected in a patient with the triad of severe abdominal/back pain, hypotension, and a pulsatile abdominal mass. Lower limb ischemia may be present in advanced cases.

It is diagnosed by ultrasonography, which is the screening modality of choice. CT scan is the gold standard for determining the anatomic eligibility for endovascular repair.

questions.text:
What is the most likely cause when a patient under general anaesthesia develops left lung collapse after intubation, with breath sounds heard only on the right side during auscultation?

PPV-Positive pressure ventillation

choices.text: Mucus secretions obstructing the endotracheal tube
Pneumothorax on the left side due to PPV

questions.solution:
The most likely cause of left lung collapse after intubation, with breath sounds heard only on the right side, is endobronchial intubation of the right main bronchus.

Endobronchial intubation is first indicated by a sudden rise in peak inspiratory pressure.
Capnography and detection of end-tidal CO2 is the confirmation for an advanced airway placement, but it does not differentiate endotracheal from endobronchial intubation.

Signs of endobronchial intubation:

  • Elevated peak inspiratory pressure (first sign)
  • Asymmetric chest expansion
  • Unilateral breath sounds
  • Drop in oxygen saturation (hypoxemia)

Other options:

Option A: Mucus secretions obstructing the endotracheal tube- will lead to diminished breath on both sides.

Option B: Pneumothorax on the left side due to PPV- less likely to occur immediately after intubation. It may be seen after prolonged PPV, post-intubation. It is a serious complication of mechanical ventilation. It is rare in intubated patients with normal lungs and most patients with pneumothorax related to mechanical ventilation (PRMV) have underlying lung diseases that range from primary obstructive lung disease to secondary pneumonia and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Excessive airway pressure during mechanical ventilation can rupture alveoli, leading to air leakage into the pleural space → pneumothorax.

Option C: Intraoperative bronchospasm is usually manifested as wheezing, increasing peak airway pressure, and a slowly rising waveform on the capnograph.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing breast surgery. Some structures are being retracted during surgery. Identify the arrow-marked muscle in the image.
questions.solution:
The muscle marked by the arrow is the serratus anterior.

During a modified radical mastectomy, the boundaries typically seen include: clavicle superiorly, sternal border medially, the lateral border of the pectoralis major muscle (or the anterior margin of the latissimus dorsi) laterally and the inframammary fold inferiorly.

Injury to the long thoracic nerve can occur during radical mastectomy which paralyzes the serratus anterior muscle. This muscle can be tested by raising the arm above the head on the affected side.

Serratus anterior plane block is a relatively novel technique that can block the lateral cutaneous branches of the intercostal nerves as well as the long thoracic nerve. It can be used as one of the modalities for managing the pain of patients undergoing MRM surgery. This procedure was effective in reducing the need for post-operative opioid usage, and better patient satisfaction with fewer side effects like postoperative nausea and vomiting. 

About Modified radical mastectomy:  Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + axillary lymph nodes (levels I + II ± III) dissection

  • Patey’s: Pectoralis minor is removed
  • Scanlon’s: Pectoralis minor incised
  • Auchincloss: Pectoralis minor only retracted

questions.text: A young female presents with vomiting episodes for the past few days. Interpret the ABG report of pH: 7.53, pCO2 48 mm Hg and HCO3: 33 meq/L.
questions.solution:
This ABG pattern is consistent with metabolic alkalosis secondary to prolonged vomiting, leading to the loss of hydrogen ions (H⁺) and chloride (Cl⁻) from gastric secretions.

The primary disturbance is metabolic alkalosis (high HCO₃⁻ and elevated pH). This is likely caused by excessive vomiting, which leads to loss of gastric acid (HCl), increasing bicarbonate levels.

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: The pH of 7.53 is above the normal limits (7.35–7.45) and thus implies the presence of alkalosis.

Step 2: Plasma HCO3- is 33 mEq/L and is higher than the normal limits (22–28 mEq/L). This implies that the alkalosis is due to an increase in the plasma HCO3- and is thus metabolic in origin. The only cause of metabolic alkalosis from the given options is vomiting.

The compensatory response is respiratory, where the body retains CO₂ (hypoventilation) to counteract the alkalosis. This explains the elevated pCO₂ 48 mmHg [normal limits (35 - 45 mmHg)]. However, compensation is incomplete, as the pH remains alkalotic.

On the contrary, normal plasma HCO3- with a decrease in pCO2 levels would point to a respiratory cause of alkalosis.

Related Pearl: Causes of Acid-Base Disorders

Metabolic acidosis

Metabolic alkalosis

Respiratory alkalosis

Ketoacidosis

Lactic acidosis

Chronic renal failure

Salicylate intoxication

Methanol/formaldehyde intoxication

Ethylene glycol intoxication

Vomiting

Loop or thiazide diuretics

Opiates, sedatives, anesthesia

Guillain- Barre syndrome, Polio, ALS, multiple sclerosis

Pneumonia, pulmonary embolism

High altitude
