questions.text: A patient with diabetes mellitus has a fasting blood sugar of 180 mg/dL and HbA1c of 8.5%. The treatment was started on Tab metformin 500mg, and his blood sugar has come down to 140 mg/dL, but his HbA1c remains above 7.3%. What is the next step in management?"

choices.text: Continue metformin at the same dose

questions.solution:
The next step in management is increasing the dose of Metformin to 1000mg. 

Increasing the dose of Metformin is the first step in improving the glycemic control of patients with type 2 diabetes whose HbA1c levels are > 6.5% while receiving a dose of less than 2000 mg daily which is the maximum tolerable dose by which we can benefit from increasing dose, confirming that the efficacy of metformin is dependent upon dosage.

According to American Diabetes Association (ADA) Standards of Medical Care in Diabetes , Metformin is the preferred first line therapeutic agent for type 2 Diabetes unless contraindicated or not tolerated by the patient. Other hypoglycemic agents are added considering patient preferences, hypoglycemia risk and other comorbidities.

Antidiabetic Drugs that pose a risk of leading to hypoglycemia (insulin secretagogue):

  • Sulfonylureas
  • Meglitinides: Nateglinide, Repaglinide

The following drugs are not directly responsible for stimulating insulin secretion and hence do not cause hypoglycemia:

  • Metformin
  • Alpha-glucosidase inhibitor
  • Pioglitazone
  • DPP-4 inhibitor: Sitagliptin

Note:

While alpha-glucosidase inhibitors themselves do not cause hypoglycemia, the risk of hypoglycemia is increased when they are taken along with insulin or insulin secretagogues.

Management of diabetes mellitus
Intervention Advantages Disadvantages
Lifestyle changes Reduced complications and mortality Insufficient for most patients within 1st year
Metformin Weight neutral

GI side effects

Contraindicated when GFR < 45 ml/min
Insulin

Rapidly effective

Lowers HbA1c more than other drugs (by 1.5-3%)

Weight gain

Hypoglycemia
GLP-1 agonists

Weight loss

Reduces cardiovascular complications

 GI side effects
Pramlintide

Weight loss

Lowers postprandial glucose

GI side effects

Hypoglycemia when used with insulin
Sulfonylureas Rapidly effective

Weight gain

Hypoglycemia
Thiazolidinediones Lowers insulin requirements

Weight gain, edema, CHF, fractures
Meglitinides Rapidly effective

Weight gain

Hypoglycemia
SGLT-2 inhibitors

Weight loss

Better cardiovascular and renal outcomes

UTI, vulval candidiasis

Dehydration

Euglycemic DKA
DPP-4 inhibitors Weight neutral Angioedema, urticaria
Alpha-glucosidase inhibitors Weight neutral

GI flatulence

Rise in LFT

Other Options :

Option A: Increasing the dose of Metformin and titrating up to it's maximum tolerable dose is preferred over adding another drug as Glipizide which has other potential side effects of hypoglycemia and weight gain.

Option B:  Continue metformin at the same dose cannot be a correct choice as the current dosage is not enough to reduce his current HbA1c levels below 7. 

Option C: IV insulin can be used but as a last resort. If HbA1c is not decreased even after using a combination of oral hypoglycemic drugs, IV Insulin can be used.

questions.text: A patient presents with a unilateral throbbing headache in the temporal region and light sensitivity associated with photophobia, nausea and vomiting. She reports that each episode lasts for a maximum of 24 hours, which was relieved by giving triptans. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of throbbing unilateral headache, light sensitivity associated with photophobia, nausea and vomiting and responsiveness to triptans indicates a diagnosis of migraine.

Migraine is the second most common cause of headaches, after tension headaches. It is characterized by unilateral and throbbing headaches of moderate to severe intensity. Other features of migraine include deep-seated pain and sensitivity to environmental and sensory stimuli. The headache can be triggered by glares, bright lights, sounds, hunger, stress, physical exertion, hormonal fluctuations during menses, lack of or excess sleep, or alcohol.

Management of migraine includes nonpharmacologic management and pharmacologic measures. Triggers unique to the patient should be avoided. Lifestyle modifications to avoid excessive caffeine and alcohol, and to maintain a healthy sleep cycle are necessary.

Pharmacological treatment can be divided into abortive treatment of acute attacks and prophylaxis to prevent acute attacks. Acute attacks can be treated with acetaminophen, aspirin NSAIDs, antiemetics and triptans. Triptans (Sumatriptan, Zolmitriptan) are used in moderate to severe migraine or when simple analgesics have not been effective. Prophylaxis with beta-blockers like propranolol, valproate, and topiramate.

Migraine is associated with the release of calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) within the trigeminal nucleus. Hence, newer therapies using CGRP antagonists and monoclonal antibodies to CGRP and its receptor are effective in treating and preventing migraine. They are considered to be as effective as triptans and are better tolerated. 

Other options:

Option A: Anxiety primarily involves psychological symptoms like excessive worry, restlessness, and rapid heartbeat, while migraines are neurological and present with severe headaches, nausea, and sensitivity to light and sound. Anxiety can sometimes trigger migraines, but they are distinct conditions with different underlying causes.

Option B: Hypertension is a chronic condition characterized by persistently high blood pressure, often without immediate symptoms, while migraines are episodic and involve severe headaches with nausea and sensory sensitivity. Unlike migraines, hypertension can lead to long-term complications like heart disease and stroke.

Option D: Tension headache is a common type of headache characterized by a dull, bilateral, pressing or tightening pain, often described as a "band around the head." It is typically triggered by stress, poor posture, or muscle tension and does not involve nausea or sensitivity to light and sound.

Related Pearl: Simplified diagnostic criteria for migraine

Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4-72 h in patients with a normal physical examination, no other reasonable cause for the headache, and

At Least 2 of the following features

  • Unilateral pain
  • Throbbing pain
  • Aggravation by movement
  • Moderate or severe intensity

Plus at Least 1 of the following features

  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Photophobia and phonophobia

questions.text: A 4-year-old-boy was brought to emergency department with complaints of acute radiating pain in right iliac region and during surgery the following structure was found. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and the image are both suggestive of Meckel's Diverticulum.

Meckel’s diverticulum is a true diverticulum, which extends from the antimesenteric side of the small bowel. The diverticula which contain all the layers of the intestine are called true diverticula. It is caused by a failure of normal regression of the vitelline duct that develops during weeks 5-7 of gestation.

The rule of 2's (Mnemonic for Meckel’s diverticulum) :

  • 2 types of heterotopic mucosa (gastric & pancreatic)(Option d).
  • 2% incidence
  • located within 2 feet of the ileocecal valve
  • approximately 2 inches in length
  • Usually symptomatic by 2 years of age

The most common presentation is painless, massive, lower GI bleed in children younger than 5 years. Meckel's diverticulum can be the lead point for ileoileal or ileocolic intussusception.

A bleeding Meckel's diverticulum may be confirmed by a 99 mTc-pertechnetate isotope scan to detect ectopic gastric mucosa. 

Surgical treatment is the definitive therapy for Meckel’s diverticulum. A simple V-shaped diverticulectomy with transverse closure of the ileum is the ideal surgical approach.

The following diagram shows the various anomalies that arise as a result of the failure of normal regression of vitellointestinal duct:

Other Options:

Option A: The most common tumor of the appendix is the well-differentiated neuroendocrine (carcinoid) tumor. This neoplasm, which is almost always benign, most frequently forms a solid bulbous swelling at the distal tip of the appendix.

Option B: Adenocarinoma of  the appendix is very rare, accounting for 0.5% of all gastrointestinal cancers. They are detected in 0.08 to 0.1% of appendectomy specimens. Mucinous is a subtype of the adenocarinoma of  the appendix.

Option D: In bowel loop obstruction, the obstructed bowel loops are centrally located and lie transversely. In cases of jejunal obstruction, valvulae conniventes, which are mucosal folds that span the entire diameter of the bowel, create a ladder effect. Additionally, a distended cecum may exhibit a gas shadow in the right iliac fossa.

questions.text: Following denotes which sign of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The sign seen, giving a dusky bluish discoloration of the anterior vaginal wall is known as Jacquemier’s or Chadwick’s sign. The discoloration is due to local vascular congestion.

Some other signs seen in pregnancy are given in the image below:

Related Pearl: Uterine Signs in Pregnancy

questions.text: A man was brought to the ER after being involved in a fistfight with a bartender, presenting with severe chest pain, dyspnea, distended neck veins, and hypotension (80/50 mmHg). He subsequently collapsed. On examination, percussion revealed hyper resonance in the infraclavicular region with absent breath sounds on the left. A chest X-ray showed a tracheal shift to the right. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray features showing a well-demarcated area devoid of lung markings on the left side with tracheal deviation and the mediastinal shift to the right side, along with the clinical scenario is suggestive of tension pneumothorax. 

Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis, and treatment should never be delayed while waiting for radiological confirmation. Imaging modalities used are ultrasound–extended focused assessment with sonar for trauma (eFAST), chest x-ray, and spiral CT.

A tension pneumothorax develops when there is a tear either in the parietal or visceral pleura. This tear acts as a one-way valve i.e., air enters from the lung or chest wall through it during inspiration but has no way to escape during expiration. This ultimately leads to the collapse of the affected lung.

It usually occurs following penetrating or blunt chest trauma, iatrogenic lung injury, or mechanical positive pressure ventilation.

It is characterized by:

  • Chest pain
  • Tachypnea and acute dyspnea
  • Sudden onset hemodynamic compromise (tachycardia, hypotension, low O2 saturation, loss of consciousness)
  • Neck vein distention
  • Tracheal deviation away from the side of the injury
  • Decreased chest movements on the affected side
  • Hyper-resonance on percussion on the affected side
  • Absence or decreased breath sounds on the affected side

The X-ray below shows a left-sided tension pneumothorax. There is a large, well-demarcated area devoid of lung markings on the left side. The yellow arrows are pointing towards the tracheal deviation and the mediastinal shift to the right side.

Management of tension pneumothorax:

  • Immediate management- needle decompression or needle thoracostomy i.e. insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line
  • Definitive management- tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety, identified as a triangle that lies anterior to the midaxillary line above the nipple, below, and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.

Other Options:

Option B: Pleural effusion may present with dyspnea, pleuritic pain, dry cough, and associated symptoms like fever, weight loss, oedema, and ascites depending on the aetiology. On examination, there may be tachypnea, dullness on percussion and decreased/absent breath sounds at the base(s).

Option C: Constrictive pericarditis symptoms may include swelling in the legs, fatigue, and discomfort, but it's not directly associated with reduced breath sounds or hyperresonance.

Option D: Pneumomediastinum presents with clinical features include severe substernal chest pain (may or may not radiate to the neck and arms) and subcutaneous emphysema over the suprasternal notch.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic male patient presents to the emergency department with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, nausea, and vomiting. On examination, his abdomen is tender in the epigastric region, and there is no palpable mass. Which of the following is the most specific and reliable marker for diagnosing acute pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
The scenario is reflective of acute pancreatitis, the enzyme most reliable for the diagnoss is serum lipase.

Acute pancreatitis is diagnosed on the basis of clinical findings + an elevated levels of pancreatic enzyme in the plasma. If the elevation of amylase and lipase levels is threefold or higher, then the diagnosis of pancreatitis is confirmed.

Serum lipase levels is a more sensitive indicator to establish the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis in patients who present 48 hours after the onset of symptoms. Lipase is also a more specific marker of acute pancreatitis because serum amylase levels can be elevated in a other conditions, like peptic ulcer disease, mesenteric ischemia, salpingitis, and macroamylasemia. 

Other options:

Option A - Serum creatinine, primarily a marker of kidney function, can be affected in severe pancreatitis due to complications like dehydration or kidney injury. However, it's not directly reflective of the pancreatic inflammation itself.

Option B - Serum amylase, while often measured, lacks sensitivity and specificity. It can be elevated in other conditions like salivary gland problems, bowel obstruction, or even kidney disease.

Option D - Serum bilirubin is elevated in acute biliary pancreatitis.

Related Pearl: Clinical features of acute pancreatitis

Symptoms:

  • Acute onset of epigastric pain, which is severe, constant, and refractory to usual doses of analgesics.
  • Typically radiates to back
  • Relieved in the sitting forward position
  • Nausea, repeated vomiting, retching, and hiccups

Signs:

  • Hypotension, tachycardia, and tachypnea
  • Grey Turner sign (A): bluish discoloration of the flanks
  • Cullen’s sign (B): bluish discoloration around the umbilicus
  • Fox sign: discoloration below the inguinal ligament
  • Pleural effusion (left > right): dullness on percussion, decreased breath sounds

Related Pearl: Laboratory findings in acute pancreatitis

  • Elevated serum amylase and serum lipase
    • Serum amylase level rises immediately and peaks in few hours and returns to normal in 3–5 days
    • Serum amylase level lacks specificity.
    • Serum amylase levels do not correlate with the severity of pancreatitis.
    • Serum lipase is more specific, and it is more useful when the patient presents 24–48 hours later.
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hypocalcemia, hypoalbuminemia
  • Leukocytosis
  • Elevated serum levels of hepatic enzymes like alanine aminotransferase (ALT).
  • Azotemia, due to prerenal acute renal failure in case of severe fluid loss

Related Pearl: X-Ray Findings in Acute Pancreatitis

Radiographic findings of acute pancreatitis are non-specific.

Sentinel loop sign: Generalized or local ileus, with isolated dilation of a segment of the gut (sentinel loop) consisting of jejunum, transverse colon, or duodenum adjacent to the pancreas

Colon cut-off sign: Functional spasm at the splenic flexure due to the extension of inflammation to phrenicocolic ligament via transverse mesocolon.

 

Renal halo sign: Edema around the kidney due to the involvement of paranephric fat resulting in:

  • Obliteration of psoas shadow
  • Localised ground-glass appearance

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with irregular periods, acne & excessive hair growth. What is the first line management?
questions.solution:
The first line of treatment for this woman with signs and symptoms of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) such as irregular periods, acne & excessive hair growth (hirsutism) is lifestyle modification.

PCOS is an endocrinopathy seen in women of reproductive age, affecting multiple systems. A weight loss of 10% through lifestyle modifications such as diet and exercise are considered first-line.

The Rotterdam criteria are used to diagnose PCOS. The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS:

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne)
  • Menstrual abnormalities (oligomenorrhea/amenorrhea), anovulation, infertility
  • Polycystic ovaries on ultrasonography.

Sonographic criteria for polycystic ovaries include ≥ 12 small cysts or an increased ovarian volume (> 10 mL) or both. 

Management:

  • Weight reduction and lifestyle changes are considered the first-line treatment for infertility in obese women with PCOS.
  • Clomiphene citrate is the first-line pharmacological choice for ovulation induction in PCOS (Option B).
  • Gonadotropins are second-line.(Aromatase inhibitors like letrozole are now not used to treat infertility in these patients)
  • Patients with PCOD are more prone to developing insulin resistance which can be controlled with metformin (Option C). 
  • Oral contraceptive pills (OCP), preferably fourth-generation are used to treat menstrual abnormalities. It also reduces acne and further hirsutism (Option D).
  • Anti-androgens are useful in treating hirsutism. OCP with cyproterone acetate is prescribed for PCOS patients with hirsutism. 

Surgical options include laparoscopic ovarian drilling or puncture of not more than four cysts in each ovary. It restores endocrine levels and improves fertility. Surgery is indicated only in the case of

  • Failure of medical therapy
  • Hyperstimulation
  • Infertile women
  • Previous pregnancy losses

questions.text: Which hormone plays a major role in home based pregnancy tests?
questions.solution:
Beta Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is the basis of home-based pregnancy tests.

hCG is produced by the syncitiotrophoblasts of the placenta. It is a glycoprotein hormone with two subunits. The alpha-subunit is similar to LH, FSH and TSH. The beta-subunit is specific and is measured by pregnancy tests.

hCG can be detected in maternal blood 8 days after fertilisation. Thus, it can help in diagnosis of pregnancy even before the period is missed. Its levels nearly doubles every 48 hours in early pregnancy reaching a maximum of 50000 - 100000 IU/L by 60-70 days of gestation. Then the level starts falling reaching a minimum at 16 weeks, which continues throughout pregnancy.

The various placental hormones and their functions are given below. 

Placental hormones Functions 

Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)

Structurally similar to - LH, FSH, TSH
  • Maintains corpus luteum function
  • Regulates testosterone secretion from fetal testes
  • Stimulates maternal thyroid

Placental lactogen (PL)

Structurally similar to - GH, Prolactin
  • Helps the mother adapt to fetal energy requirements

Corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH)
  • Vascular and myometrial smooth muscle relaxation
  • Initiation of parturition
  • Stimulates placental ACTH production 

Placental adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) 

 Stimulates fetal and maternal adrenal glucocorticoid production

Other placental hormones include:

  • GnRH, TRH, GHRH, Growth hormone variant (hGH-V)
  • Parathyroid hormone-releasing protein (PTH-rP)
  • Inhibin 
  • Activin
  • Relaxin

questions.text: In a 30-year-old male who underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the bile duct was injured. The area of injury is shown in the image below. Which type of bile duct injury does this belong to, according to Strasberg’s classification of bile duct injuries?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a bile leak from the cystic duct stump. According to Strasberg’s classification, the image given belongs to type A bile duct injury.

Biliary injury may occur during a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The most common site of bile leak following cholecystectomy is the cystic duct.

MRCP is the gold standard for complete morphological evaluation of the biliary tree. MRCP with magnetic resonance angiography is more useful in cases of associated vascular injury. HIDA scan can be used to confirm the presence of a bile leak or biliary obstruction. 

The Strasberg classification of bile duct injury is a widely used system to anatomically define bile duct injuries.

Classification

questions.text: A female patient presents with difficulty ingesting liquids more than solids. What is the most likely characteristic finding on imaging?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a female patient having more difficulty swallowing liquids than solids suggests achalasia cardia, with the characteristic imaging finding being the Rat tail sign.

Achalasia is a primary oesophagal motility disorder. It is characterized by the absence of oesophagal peristalsis and impaired lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation in response to swallowing. These abnormalities cause a functional obstruction at the gastroesophageal junction. 

Esophageal manometry shows:

  • Incomplete LES relaxation in response to swallowing.
  • High resting LES pressure.
  • Absent esophageal peristalsis.

On performing a timed barium study, barium will be retained for more than five minutes. The fluoroscopic examination will reveal a dilated oesophagus that tapers to form a bird's beak at the gastroesophageal junction as seen in the image above. Endoscopy and biopsy are usually carried out to rule out cancer. 24-hour pH monitoring is used in the diagnosis of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

Medical management with sublingual nitroglycerin, nitrates, and calcium-channel blockers for symptomatic relief. Pneumatic dilatation and Botox injection

Surgical management is the treatment of choice :

  • Laparoscopic Heller's myotomy is the definitive management - The major complication associated with this procedure is gastro-oesophageal reflux. So it is best to combine it with partial anterior fundoplication (Heller–Dor operation).
  • Peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM) is a recently introduced, advanced natural-orifice approach for myotomy.
  • Open Esophageal Myotomy - rarely done.

Other options:

Option A: Apple core sign is characteristically seen in the barium enema of carcinoma colon as shown below.

Option B: Barium enema radiograph of diverticulosis shows multiple barium-coated outpouchings from the colonic wall and gives the appearance of a saw-tooth as shown below.

Option C: Crohn's disease is an inflammatory bowel disease that shows the string sign of Kantor on barium enema as shown below.

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus.

Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.

Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease

Clinical features:

  • dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • regurgitation
  • chest pain
  • weight loss
  • bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, Chagas’ disease, and pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation and Heller myotomy

Related Pearl: Manometric findings in oesophageal disorders

Manometric Findings in Nutcracker Esophagus

  • Peristaltic esophageal contractions 2 standard deviations above normal
  • Amplitude > 180 mmHg and duration > 7seconds.
  • Normal peristaltic sequence

Manometric Findings in Diffuse Esophageal Spasm

  • Simultaneous, multipeaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mm Hg) or long duration (>2.5 sec)
  • These erratic contractions occur after more than 20% of wet swallows.
  • Intermittent normal peristalsis

Manometric Findings in Hypertensive Lower Esophageal Sphincter-

  • Elevated LES pressure > 26mmHg and normal relaxation of LES
  • The esophageal body may be hyper-peristaltic or normal.

Manometric findings in Achalasia Cardia

  • Incomplete LES relaxation
  • Aperistalsis in the esophageal body
  • Elevated LES pressure ≥26 mmHg
  • Increased intraesophageal baseline pressures relative to gastric baseline

Manometric findings in ineffective esophageal motility disorders

  • Decreased or absent amplitude of esophageal peristalsis (<30 mmHg)
  • Increased number of non-transmitted contractions

questions.text: A patient received a tubal block and is scheduled for laparoscopy. Identify the instrument used in this procedure.
questions.solution:
Veress needle is used to produce pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgery.

The closed method using the Veress needle has a small but significant potential for intestinal or vascular injury on the introduction of the needle or trocar. Proper placement of the needle can be determined by the inability to re-aspirate injected saline. The normal insufflation rate is 4-6 litres/min.

Insufflation of the abdomen is accomplished with a Veress needle held at its serrated collar with the thumb and forefinger.
Because the linea alba is fused to the umbilicus, the abdominal wall is grasped with fingers or penetrating towel clip to elevate the abdominal wall away from the underlying structures. (As shown below)

Other options:

Option A: The image given below is that of a Hasson trocar which is used in the open method of creating pneumoperitoneum.To achieve this, a 1 cm vertical or transverse incision is made at the level of the umbilicus, stay sutures are applied, and the fascia is dissected. Free penetration into the abdominal cavity is confirmed by the gentle introduction of a finger. A Hasson trocar, shown below, is inserted and anchored, and pneumoperitoneum is created. This is the Hasson or modified Hasson approach. This avoids the morbidity related to a blind puncture. 

Option C: Leech Wilkinson's Cannula is dipicted below.It can be identified by the spiral cone at the tip and is used for hysterosalpingography.Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is a technique used for visualization of the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes by the injection of a radiopaque dye, and visualization of the dye by fluoroscopy as it passes through the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes.

Option D: Whitacre Needle dipicted below and it is a Dura Splitting Needle. Dura-splitting needles include Sprotte, Whitacre, and Greene. They have a pencil-point, rounded and conical tip which splits the layers of dura. Thus, the loss of CSF is reduced and PDPH is lesser with these needles

questions.text: A patient with a history of breast cancer underwent tele cobalt-60 radiotherapy. She now presents with respiratory distress, and imaging shows bilateral perihilar ground glass opacities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A patient with a history of breast cancer who previously received Tele cobalt-60 radiotherapy now presents with respiratory distress. Imaging shows bilateral perihilar ground glass opacities, suggesting a likely diagnosis of radiation pneumonitis.

Radiation pneumonitis is an inflammatory reaction in the lungs that occurs as a result of radiation therapy, commonly seen in patients treated for breast cancer, lung cancer, or lymphomas. It typically develops within weeks to months after radiation exposure and presents with symptoms such as cough, fever, chest pain, and progressive shortness of breath. The condition arises due to damage to the alveolar and capillary structures, leading to increased vascular permeability, inflammatory infiltration, and pulmonary oedema. Imaging findings, particularly on CT scans, may show areas of ground-glass opacities, consolidation, or haziness, often in the radiation field.

If left untreated, radiation pneumonitis can progress to pulmonary fibrosis, causing long-term respiratory complications. Management involves corticosteroids to reduce inflammation and supportive care, including oxygen therapy if needed.

Prevention strategies include limiting the radiation dose, using advanced radiotherapy techniques to minimize lung exposure, and closely monitoring high-risk patients. Early recognition and intervention are crucial to improving outcomes and preventing long-term lung damage in affected individuals.

questions.text: Which of the following is the safest hysterectomy surgery to minimise the risk of ureteric injury on the OT table?
questions.solution:
Vaginal hysterectomy is the safest surgical approach to minimize the risk of ureteric injury on the OT table.

This is because the vaginal approach allows surgeons to follow natural anatomical planes and typically requires less dissection and manipulation of the uterus.

In a retrospective review of study involving 3114 hysterectomies, the following rates of ureteric injury were noted :

Procedure Incidence of Ureteric injury
Abdominal hysterectomy (5/940) 0.53%
Vaginal hysterectomy (1/304) 0.33%
Robotic hysterectomy (7/1088) 0.64%
Laparoscopic hysterectomy (4/782) 0.51%

Procedures that are associated with highest risk for ureteric injury are (but they are not the most common cause of ureteric injuries):

  • Surgery for malignancy
  • Advanced pelvic reconstructive surgery
  • Laparoscopic hysterectomy

Urinary tract injury occurs almost exclusively in major gynecologic surgery that involves surgical dissection in proximity to the ureters or bladder. Vaginal route for hysterectomy tends to have lower rates of ureteric injuries than open or laparoscopic routes.

Patients with ureteric injuries have a complicated post-operative period. They can present with the following features:

  • Fever
  • Flank pain
  • Abdominal distension
  • Prolonged paralytic ileus - bowel sounds are absent
  • High drain outputs, in case abdominal drains are placed.

CT urogram and retrograde pyelography are the investigations of choice. They reveal urinary extravasation from the ureter. Ureteric injuries are prevented by careful division of tissue planes during pelvic or genitourinary surgeries. The condition is managed by prompt surgical repair by ureteroureterostomy or percutaneous ureterostomy.

questions.text: A patient presents with fatigue and chronic diarrhea for 4 months. Endoscopy reveals several ulcers in the gastric antrum and the descending duodenum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of gastrinoma Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. 

Zollinger Ellison Syndrome (ZES)/Gastrinoma is a neuroendocrinal tumour characterized by hypersecretion of gastrin resulting in gastrointestinal tract ulcers. It occurs more commonly in a sporadic pattern but can be associated with MEN-1 (multiple endocrine neoplasia-1) syndromes in the familial pattern. Gastrinoma is most commonly located in the gastrinoma triangle (Passaro's triangle) bounded by the lines connecting the:

  • cystic duct
  • the junction between the second and third parts of the duodenum
  • the junction between the neck and body of the pancreas

 

The most common presentations of gastrinoma are epigastric pain, diarrhoea, and peptic ulcers. The ulcers occur at typical locations (proximal duodenum) and atypical locations (distal duodenum, jejunum). Duodenal ulcers are the most common. Gastrinoma if associated with marked gastric acid production and recurrent peptic ulcer is called Zollinger Ellison syndrome.

Diagnosis: 

The gastric pH <2, basal acid output >15 mEq/hr and serum gastrin concentration more than 1000 pg/ml (normal is <100 pg/ml) confirm the diagnosis of gastrinoma. When the diagnosis is in doubt (like gastrin levels 100-1000 pg/ml), then a secretin test is performed. A secretin test is considered positive when serum gastrin levels are more than 200 pg/ml on secretin administration and confirms the diagnosis of gastrinoma.

For localization of the tumour for surgical management, CT or MRI scans should be done first. If the tumour is not localized on these scans, then somatostatin receptor scintigraphy or endoscopic ultrasound is done for better localization.

Treatment of ZES :

High-dose Proton Pump Inhibitor followed by surgery.

Surgeries that can be done are:

  • Distal Pancreatectomy– if lesion in body or tail of the pancreas
  • Enucleation– if lesion in the head of the pancreas
  • Full-thickness excision– if lesion in duodenum
  • MEN associated– surgery done only if size>2.5cm  

 

 

Other options:

Option A: VIPoma is characterized by watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria (WDHA syndrome). It is caused by the release of vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) from the tumor.

Option C: Glucagonomas, α-cell tumors are associated with increased serum levels of glucagon. The patient presents with mild diabetes mellitus, a characteristic skin rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), and anemia. They occur most frequently in perimenopausal and postmenopausal women and are characterized by extremely high plasma glucagon levels.

Option D: Insulinomas, β-cell tumors are the most common pancreatic endocrine neoplasms. These are usually benign and often cause symptomatic hypoglycemia. Hypoglycemic symptoms appear when blood glucose levels fall below 50 mg/dL. The symptoms usually develop after fasting or exertion and improve after glucose intake.

Related Pearl: Clinical features of gastrinoma (Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome)

Most common symptom: Abdominal pain.

Gastrin hypersecretion stimulates gastric acid secretion, leading to peptic ulcers that occur at atypical sites like the duodenum and jejunum and are refractory and multiple.

Diarrhea is due to

  • Acid-induced injury to the small intestine mucosa
  • Inability of the intestinal tract to absorb large volumes of fluids secreted by the stomach
  • Inactivation of pancreatic lipase by low pH
  • Precipitation of bile salts.

The unique characteristic of acid-induced diarrhea is that it is controlled by nasogastric aspiration of gastric secretions.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic tests in Zollinger Ellison Syndrome

To confirm the diagnosis of ZES,

  • Gastric pH <2.5 and
  • Serum gastrin >1000pg/ml (normal <100pg/ml)

Provocative tests can be done like the secretin stimulation test when the diagnosis is in doubt. An increase in serum gastrin >200pg/ml following an IV bolus of secretin (2U/kg) is diagnostic.

Other tests:

  • BAO >15mEq/h (or >5mEq/h if they have had a procedure for peptic ulcer)
  • BAO: MAO ratio is increased (>0.6)

(BAO=Basal acid output; MAO=Maximal acid output)

For localization

  • Initial investigation - CT or MRI
  • Best investigation - Endoscopic ultrasound
  • If the tumor is not localized - Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old patient presents with respiratory difficulty and a history of chronic smoking for the last 30 years. Pulmonary function testing shows a decrease in FEV1% and FEV1/FVC ratio. What is the most probable diagnosis?

COPD-Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario including symptoms of respiratory difficulty and history of chronic smoking along with pulmonary function testing revealing a reduced FEV1% and FEV1/FVC ratio is indicative of an obstructive disorder - Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD).

These values are measured as a part of the pulmonary function test known as spirometry. At a given lung volume, when a person inhales to the total lung capacity and exhales as hard and completely as possible, the volume of expired air is recorded as forced vital capacity (FVC), and the volume of air expired in the first second is called the forced expiratory volume (FEV1).

In obstructive disorders, a large amount of air gets trapped in the lungs. Due to airway obstruction, it is more difficult to exhale than inhale. As a result, residual volume increases greatly. Difficulty in exhalation leads to a decreased FVC. FEV1 decreases much more than the decrease in FVC. Hence the FEV1% also falls. Obstructive disorders include- 

  • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) - emphysema, chronic bronchitis
  • Bronchiectasis
  • Asthma

The severity of COPD is assessed by using the Global Initiative for Lung Disease (GOLD) criteria. In pulmonary function testing, a postbronchodilator FEV1/FVC ratio of <0.70 is considered diagnostic for COPD. 

The Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease (GOLD) system categorizes COPD into the following stages,

GOLD Stage

Severity

Spirometry

In patients with FEV1/FVC <0.7

GOLD I

Mild

FEV1 ≥80% predicted

GOLD II

Moderate

FEV1 ≥50% but <80% predicted

GOLD III

Severe

FEV1 ≥30% but <50% predicted

GOLD IV

Very severe

FEV1 <30% predicted

Note: FEV1/FVC is measured after the administration of a bronchodilator.

Other Options: Pulmonary fibrosis (Option B), Interstitial Lung Disease(Option C) and Lung cancer(Option D) are examples of restrictive lung disorder. 

In restrictive disorders, there is a loss of lung compliance. This causes a reduction in FVC and  FEV1. However, the ratio FEV% remains normal or may increase.

Related Pearl: PFT for obstructive vs restrictive diseases

PFT

Obstructive disease

Restrictive disease

FVC

Decreased

Decreased (<80% predicted)

FEV1

Decreased (<80% predicted)

 Decreased

FEV1% (FEV1/FVC)

Decreased (<0.7)

Normal/ increased (>0.7)

FEF 25-75

<50% predicted

Normal/ decreased

TLC

Normal/ increased

Decreased

RV

Increased

Decreased

DLCO
  • Normal or increased in asthma
  • Decreased in emphysema
  • Decreased in intrinsic restrictive disease
  • Normal in neuromuscular or musculoskeletal restrictive disease

FVC: Forced Vital Capacity

FEV1: Forced expiratory volume in 1 second

FEF 25-75: Forced expiratory flow at 25-75% vital capacity

TLC: Total lung capacity

RV: Residual volume

DLCO: Diffusion capacity of lung for Carbon monoxide.

questions.text: A patient presents with progressive increase in shortness of breath. On examination, left parasternal heave is noted. On auscultation, a systolic murmur is heard. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with worsening shortness of breath, and examination reveals a left parasternal heave. A systolic murmur is heard on auscultation, leading to the diagnosis of pulmonary stenosis.

Pulmonary stenosis is a congenital heart defect where there is a narrowing of the pulmonary valve or the area just below the valve, obstructing blood flow from the right ventricle to the lungs. This leads to increased pressure in the right ventricle, causing it to work harder to pump blood. The condition may range from mild to severe and can result in symptoms like shortness of breath, fatigue, and cyanosis in severe cases.

On physical examination, a left parasternal heave is often noted due to right ventricular hypertrophy, and auscultation typically reveals a systolic ejection murmur heard best at the upper left sternal border. If left untreated, severe pulmonary stenosis can lead to right heart failure and other complications. Treatment may involve balloon valvuloplasty or surgery, depending on the severity of the obstruction.

Other options:

Option A: Pulmonary regurgitation is the backward flow of blood into the right ventricle due to insufficient closure of the pulmonary valve. It often presents with a diastolic murmur heard at the left upper sternal border and can lead to right heart enlargement if severe. 

Option C: Pulmonary artery hypertension is a condition characterized by elevated blood pressure in the pulmonary arteries, leading to strain on the right side of the heart. Symptoms may include shortness of breath, fatigue, and chest pain, and it can result from various causes like lung diseases or heart conditions.

Option D: Pulmonary embolism is a blockage in one of the pulmonary arteries, usually caused by a blood clot that travels to the lungs from the legs (deep vein thrombosis). It can lead to symptoms like sudden shortness of breath, chest pain, and potentially life-threatening complications if untreated.

questions.text: A 47-year-old hypertensive woman came to your clinic complaining of bone pain. She has a history of recurrent renal stones. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this condition?
questions.solution:
Given the clinical picture of a 47-year-old hypertensive woman with bone pain and recurrent renal stones, the most likely diagnosis is hyperparathyroidism (often primary hyperparathyroidism) and the most appropriate management for the given condition is thiazide diuretics.

Thiazides reduce calcium excretion in the urine, which can help prevent the formation of kidney stones in hyperparathyroidism and help manage the hypercalcemia associated with it.

Hyperparathyroidism is a condition characterized by the overproduction of parathyroid hormone (PTH) by the parathyroid glands, leading to elevated levels of calcium in the blood (hypercalcemia). There are two main types: primary hyperparathyroidism, where an abnormality within the parathyroid glands (often an adenoma) causes excessive PTH production, and secondary hyperparathyroidism, typically caused by chronic kidney disease, which leads to low calcium levels and compensatory increased PTH secretion.

Primary hyperparathyroidism Secondary hyperparathyroidism Tertiary hyperparathyroidism

an autonomous overproduction of parathyroid hormone (PTH)

 compensatory hypersecretion of PTH in response to prolonged hypocalcemia persistent hypersecretion of PTH even after the cause of prolonged hypocalcemia is corrected
Parathyroid  adenoma or hyperplasia chronic renal failure  after renal transplant.

Primary hyperparathyroidism is one of the most common endocrine disorders, and it is an important cause of hypercalcemia. Tumours of the parathyroid glands usually come to attention because of excessive secretion of PTH rather than mass effects. It can also be associated with MEN1 and MEN 2A syndromes. 

The clinical manifestations of hyperparathyroidism can be summarized as “painful bones, renal stones, abdominal groans, and psychic moans.” Skeletal manifestations of hyperparathyroidism include bone resorption, osteitis fibrosa cystica, and brown tumours. Renal changes include nephrolithiasis (stones) and nephrocalcinosis.

Localisation of parathyroid is difficult. Nuclear medicine scanning with radiolabeled Sestamibi is a widely used technique. Sestamibi accumulates in parathyroid adenomas. This radionuclide is concentrated in the thyroid and parathyroid tissue but usually washes out of normal thyroid tissue in under an hour. It persists in abnormal parathyroid tissue. It is now regarded as the most accurate and reliable method for imaging the parathyroid glands.

Other options:

Option B: Loop diuretic is not an appropriate answer, as it increases calcium excretion and could worsen hypocalcemia.

Option C: Calcitriol is not appropriate in this case, as it is a form of active vitamin D that increases calcium absorption, which could exacerbate hypercalcemia.

Option D: Calcium gluconate is not appropriate here, as calcium gluconate is used to treat hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia.

Related Pearl: Causes of Hypercalcemia

Raised [PTH]

Decreased [PTH]

Hyperparathyroidism

  • Primary (adenoma > hyperplasia)
  • Secondary
  • Tertiary

Hypercalcemia of malignancy

Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia

Vitamin D toxicity

 

Immobilization

 

Thiazide diuretics

 

Sarcoidosis

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image below.
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the given image is the buccopharyngeal fascia. 

The structures forming the tonsillar bed from within outward are 

  1. Pharyngobasilar Fascia (number 10- option A)
  2. Superior Constrictor
  3. Buccopharyngeal Fascia (number 11)
  4. Styloglossus
  5. Glossopharyngeal Nerve
  6. Facial Artery

In a retropharyngeal abscess, the pus collects between the buccopharyngeal fascia and the prevertebral fascia. 

An acute retropharyngeal abscess commonly occurs in children below 3 years of age due to infections of adenoids or tonsils that cause suppuration in the retropharyngeal lymph nodes and lead to abscess formation. Since the retropharyngeal lymph nodes disappear after this age, an adult retropharyngeal abscess is uncommon and usually occurs secondary to trauma.

Other options:

Option B: Danger space in neck: The danger space or alar space is the space that is present between the alar fascia and the prevertebral fascia.

Option C:  Prevertebral fascia - It forms the floor of the posterior triangle and the axillary sheath. Inferiorly, it blends with the anterior longitudinal ligament.

questions.text: Identify the part marked 'A'?
questions.solution:
The edge of an ulcer is is represented by 'A'.

An ulcer is defined as a break in the continuity of the epithelium or mucous membrane with molecular death. Classically an ulcer is described to have four parts which are:

  1. Margin
  2. Edge
  3. Floor 
  4. Base

The margin is defined as the junction between the normal epithelium and the ulcer.

The edge is defined as the part between the margin and the floor. Five types of ulcer edges are commonly described as follows:

The floor is defined as the exposed surface of the ulcer. It is better seen than felt, and may contain granulation tissue, discharge or slough. Trophic ulcers have bone as the floor due to their depth.

The base is defined as the structure on which the ulcer rests, eg, bone or soft tissue. It is better felt than seen.

questions.text: A postmenopausal woman presents with irregular bleeding. Endometrial biopsy revealed endometrial hyperplasia without atypia. How would you consider treating this patient?
questions.solution:
Progesterone therapy such as norethisterone followed by endometrial biopsy every 3 to 6 months is the best treatment in the case of endometrial hyperplasia without atypia.

Endometrial hyperplasia is defined as endometrial thickening with the proliferation of irregularly sized and shaped glands and an increased gland-to-stroma ratio. It is a pre-malignant lesion for endometrial carcinoma.

WHO Classification of endometrial hyperplasia based on histology:

  • Simple without atypia: there is an increase in number of glands but the architecture is not compromised. 
  • Simple with atypia: simple hyperplasia with features of nuclear atypia (variation in nuclear shape, size, and prominent nucleoli)
  • Complex without atypia: glands are markedly crowded and irregular
  • Complex with atypia: complex hyperplasia with atypical nuclear features. 

However, there is generally no clear histological distinction between the above mentioned classification, so endometrial hyperplasia is classified into hyperplasia without atypia and atypical hyperplasia/endometrioid intraepithelial neoplasia. 

Type of hyperplasia Risk of progression to cancer
Simple without atypia 1%
Complex without atypia 3%
Simple with atypia 8%
Complex with atypia 29%

Management of Endometrial hyperplasia:

1) Hyperplasia without atypia:

Intrauterine or continuous oral progesterone. Levonorgestrel releasing intrauterine system is preferred due to its lower side effect profile, higher rate of disease resolution. Oral progesterone can be given in the form of medroxyprogesterone acetate 10-20 mg/day. 

Endometrial surveillance in the form of biopsy should be performed at 6-month intervals. At least 2 consecutive negative biopsies should be obtained. Those at high risk (body mass index of more than 35, treated with oral progesterone) should be advised annual follow-up. 

2) Atypical hyperplasia:

Total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy is suggested in those with atypical hyperplasia due to the risk of progression to malignancy. 

Premenopausal women who want to preserve their fertility should be counseled regarding the risk of progression to cancer. Once fertility is no longer required, then hysterectomy should be offered. 

Those who refuse hysterectomy should have routine endometrial biopsies every 3 months until 2 consecutive negative biopsies are obtained.

questions.text: A patient with a history of obstructed labor and cesarean section presents with continuous dribbling of urine through vagina on day 7. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of vesicovaginal fistula.

Vesicovaginal fistula (VVF) is a type of genital fistula, which is an abnormal communication between the genital tract and the urinary tract.

Vesicovaginal fistulae occur mostly due to obstetric injuries such as prolonged labor, and instrumental or manipulative deliveries. Patients present with true incontinence characterized by constant dribbling of urine. The presence of urine in the undergarments is uncomfortable and leads to pruritus and excoriation of the genital area

In obstructed labour, ischemia necrosis occurs as a result of prolonged compression effect on the bladder base between the head and symphysis pubis leading to infection → sloughing → fistula. Thus, it takes around 3–5 days following delivery to produce a fistula.

Clinical assessment by the introduction of a speculum helps to determine the size, number, and location of the fistulae. A methylene blue test helps confirm the diagnosis and determine the type of repair operation.

Small fistulas due to difficult childbirth can heal spontaneously. Most established fistulas need to be repaired vaginally usually after 3 months to allow the inflammation to subside.

The repair operation includes the Latzko procedure. The procedure involves denuding the vaginal epithelium around fistulous edges and approximating the raw surfaces. Another is the Chassar-Moir technique of widely separating the bladder and vagina and suturing them separately in two layers.

Post-operatively, continuous bladder drainage for 14 days along with antibiotics is recommended. Vaginal or speculum examination and intercourse are not advised for 3 months. Avoiding pregnancy for a year is also recommended. A cesarean section is usually done for future pregnancies.

Other options:

Option A: Vesicouterine fistula occurs during cesarean section or uterine rupture or placenta accreta. Patients complain of cyclical hematuria due to the trickling of menstrual blood into the bladder through this anomalous condition. But the urinary continence of the patient remains normal. This is also known as Youssef syndrome. 

Option B: In urethrovaginal fistulae, the patient is continent and dry, but may dribble urine during micturition. This usually follows surgery for a paravaginal cyst or urethral diverticulum, or after a penetrating injury from a fall or criminal abortion. The fistulous opening is visible on speculum examination.

Option C: Ureterovaginal fistulae result from direct injury to the ureter during gynecologic surgery (Eg: Wertheim's procedure for Ca cervix). Urine dribbles from both vagina and urethra post-surgery. The three-swab test will not stain with methylene blue, but with urine.

Related Pearl: Methylene blue - 3 swab test

Procedure:

A catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra. The vaginal cavity is packed with three (or four) sterile cotton swabs.

50–100 mL of dilute methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder using a catheter.

Results:

  • Upper swabs get wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter: Ureterovaginal fistula
  • Upper swabs get stained - the leak is from the bladder: Vesicovaginal fistula
  • Lower swabs get stained - the leak is from the urethra: Urethrovaginal fistula.

Related Pearl: Difference between bladder fistula & ureteric fistula

  Bladder fistula   Ureteric fistula 
Etiology

Obstetric causes:

  • Prolonged obstructed labor
  • Instrumental deliveries
  • Iatrogenic injury during caesarean section or sling operations

Surgical injury during:

  • Abdominal hysterectomy
  • Vaginal hysterectomy
  • Wertheim's hysterectomy
  • Laparoscopic surgeries
  • Caesarean section
Clinical features

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is unable to micturate

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is able to micturate
Methylene blue 3-swab test Middle swab stains with methylene blue   Uppermost swab stains with urine, but not with methylene blue
Intravenous pyelography Normal Hydronephrosis and hydroureter present on the affected side

questions.text: A 24-year-old male with a previous history of  psychiatric disorder has become aggressive with neighbours. He is cheerful, speaking rapidly and also sleeping little. He exhibits hyperactive behaviour after discontinuing his prescribed medication. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette showing increased activity, energy, and euphoria with a decreased need for sleep is indicative of an acute manic episode in the setting of bipolar disorder. 

Lithium is used in the management of bipolar disorder, and mania, and has anti-suicidal properties. It has a narrow therapeutic index, and blood levels in excess of this may cause symptoms of toxicity. Therapeutic drug monitoring is done by measuring lithium levels 12 hours after the last dose.

Lithium therapy for acute mania:

  • Three individual 10-mg/kg doses of a sustained-release preparation administered at 2-h intervals.
  • The sustained-release form is used to minimize GI adverse effects (e.g., nausea, diarrhea)
  • Subsequent treatment may then be continued with Li+ carbonate.

Steady state-concentrations for therapy :

  • For maintainance therapy in bipolar disorder - 0.5-0.8 mEq/L
  • For episodes of acute mania - 0.8-1.2 mEq/L
  • Toxic levels - >1.5 mEq/L

The blood sample for serum lithium estimation is to be collected after a time interval of 10-12 hours from the previous dose of lithium which is used to estimate the steady-state concentration.

Other Options:

Option A: Depression is consistent with feelings of hopelessness, hollowness, and low self-esteem lasting less than two-week intervals during which depressive episodes occur. 

Option C: Diagnosis of Schizophrenia requires: 

A 6-month period with at least 1-month overt psychotic symptoms where 2 or more of the following have to be present. And at least one must be delusion, hallucination or disorganised speech.

  1. Delusion
  2. Hallucination
  3. Disorganized speech (or formal thought disorder)
  4. Disorganized behaviour
  5. Affective flattening or other negative symptoms

Option D: The patient's history does not make mention of the use of any substances.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with lower urinary tract symptoms, including weak urinary stream, hesitancy, and nocturia. On digital rectal examination (DRE), a hard, irregular prostate is palpated. He has no significant past medical history but reports mild back pain over the past few weeks. The physician suspects prostate cancer. Which enzyme is elevated in prostate cancer?
questions.solution:
Prostatic acid phosphatase (PAP) is commonly increased in prostatic cancer. 

The form of acid phosphatase that is found in the prostate gland is called prostatic acid phosphatase (PAP). PAP is a glycoprotein that is synthesized by the epithelial cells of the prostate gland. It is secreted into the prostatic fluid, where it plays a role in the liquefaction of semen.

PAP is also a potential target for monoclonal antibody therapy. Sipuleucel-T is a cell-based approach to induce an immune response against prostatic acid phosphatase (PAP) that is commonly expressed in prostatic cancer.

Option A: Alkaline phosphatase is increased in primary liver cancers, such as hepatocellular carcinoma and cholangiocarcinoma.  Similarly, cancers that metastasize to the bones or primary bone cancers like osteosarcoma. 

Option C: Lactate dehydrogenase elevations can occur in a range of malignancies. It is often observed in hematological cancers like lymphomas and leukemias, reflecting the rapid cell turnover characteristic of these diseases. Lung cancers, both small cell and non-small cell types, can also lead to increased LDH levels. 

Option D: Alpha-fetoprotein is a protein that is produced by the liver and yolk sac during fetal development. Alpha-fetoprotein levels are typically elevated in certain types of cancer, such as liver cancer and testicular cancer, but not in prostate cancer.

Related Pearl: Tumor Markers

questions.text: What is the recommended maximum time frame for cornea harvesting after death to ensure optimal transplant quality?
questions.solution:
Donor corneas are to be harvested within 6 hours of death.

Eye banks manage corneal and scleral tissue donation for transplantation. The process requires next-of-kin consent and involves screening donors for contraindications including infectious diseases, malignancies, and neurological conditions. Tissues must be harvested within 6-8 hours of death.

Two harvesting methods are used:

  1. Whole globe enucleation: Complete eyeball removal, stored in moist chamber bottles
  2. In situ corneoscleral rim excision: Direct corneal rim removal into storage medium

The process is regulated by the Transplantation of Organs and Tissues Act and coordinated by the National Organ and Tissue Transplant Organization. Eye banks conduct public education and place counselors in hospitals to improve donation rates through the Hospital Cornea Retrieval Program.

questions.text: A patient has a history of a flying foreign body injury to the eye. After 8 weeks, heterochromia iridis is noted. Which of the following substances is most likely involved in the deposition?
questions.solution:
History of trauma from a flying object followed by subsequent heterochromia iridis is suggestive of siderosis bulbi which happens due to iron deposition.

The presence of iron deposits in the eye especially in industrial workers is called siderosis bulbi. It refers to the ocular degenerative changes produced by an iron foreign body. It usually occurs 2 months to 2 years after the injury. This condition is due to the electrolytic dissociation of the metal by an intrinsic resting current in the eye which disseminates the metal, combining it with cellular proteins and causing atrophy.

The earliest change is the deposition of iron in the anterior capsule of the lens where oval patches are arranged in a ring corresponding with the edge of the dilated pupil. This eventually leads to the formation of cataract.

Clinical features:

  • Iris: first stained greenish and later turned reddish-brown, causing heterochromia iridis.
  • Pupil: iron deposition in the sphincter leads to mydriasis.
  • Lens: iron deposition in a radial fashion on the anterior capsule of the lens, leading to anterior capsular cataract.
  • Retina: pigmentary retinopathy; followed by atrophy of the retina and retinal pigmentary epithelium.
  • Secondary open-angle glaucoma: due to damage to the trabecular meshwork.

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic man, after attending a party, was brought to the hospital by his relative with complaints of seeing snakes crawling in his room and inability to recognise his family members. He reports his last alcohol intake was 48 hours ago. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a 45-year-old chronic alcoholic man who, after attending a party, was brought to the hospital by his relative due to hallucinations of snakes crawling in his room and an inability to recognize his family members. He mentions that his last alcohol consumption was 48 hours ago. The most probable diagnosis is delirium tremens.

Delirium tremens is a medical emergency that occurs during alcohol withdrawal. It is an acute condition and usually develops within 72 hours after the last drink. It has symptoms of both delirium and alcohol withdrawal. The clinical features of delirium tremens are:

  • Altered sensorium with disorientation
  • Perceptual distortions, most frequently tactile or visual hallucinations
  • Autonomic hyperactivity with tachycardia, fever, anxiety, insomnia, hypertension. And sweating
  • Fluctuating levels of psychomotor activity, ranging from agitation to lethargy
    Altered sleep-wake cycle 

Wernicke’s encephalopathy (alcoholic encephalopathy) is associated with thiamine deficiency. Alcohol abuse may lead to thiamine deficiency because of poor nutritional habits, or malabsorption. It is an acute neurological disorder characterized by:

  • Global confusion
  • Ocular abnormalities like horizontal nystagmus, gaze palsy, anisocoria, and sluggish pupillary reflex
  • Ataxia - mainly affecting the gait
  • Vestibular dysfunction

It may resolve with thiamine therapy or progress to Korsakoff's syndrome.

Other options:

Option B: Alcohol-induced psychosis is a severe mental condition triggered by excessive alcohol use, leading to hallucinations, delusions, and confusion. It typically occurs during withdrawal or chronic alcohol abuse and requires immediate medical intervention.

Option C: Schizophrenia is a chronic mental disorder characterized by hallucinations, delusions, and disorganized thinking. It affects perception, emotions, and behaviour, often requiring lifelong treatment

Option D: Alcohol-induced hallucinations occur due to excessive alcohol use or withdrawal, causing visual, auditory, or tactile false perceptions. They are distinct from delirium tremens and can persist even with clear consciousness.

Related Pearl: Alcohol Withdrawal Syndrome

questions.text: A young lady presents with recent-onset palpitations and dizziness. Her ECG shows absent P waves and an irregularly irregular RR interval. Her pulse rate is 140 bpm and BP is 80/60 mmHg. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient presenting with recent-onset palpitations and dizziness with ECG showing irregularly irregular rhythm with absent p waves, is suggestive of atrial fibrillation. Since the patient is hemodynamically compromised (hypotension), synchronized cardioversion is the most appropriate management.

Urgent electrical cardioversion is indicated if a patient with AF has shock or severe hypotension, pulmonary edema or ongoing myocardial infarction. Although there is a risk of potential thromboembolism if the patient has not been put on anticoagulation before, the need for rate control outweighs this risk. In these patients, heart rate control is achieved using IV β-blockers or calcium channel blockers like verapamil (Option B) or diltiazem. Additionally, they are also given subcutaneous low-molecular-weight heparin as soon as possible.

In hemodynamically stable patients with AF of >48 hours duration or unknown duration, there is a high risk of formation of a thrombus in the left atrium. If the patients are cardioverted at this stage, this thrombus can embolize into the systemic circulation, leading to end organ damage, such as stroke. Therefore, for these patients, any of the following two management strategies can be followed:

  • Give anticoagulation for 3 weeks → cardioversion (pharmacological or electrical) → continue anticoagulation for 4 more weeks
  • Start anticoagulation and do transesophageal echocardiography → if thrombus is absent, do cardioversion (pharmacological or electrical) → continue anticoagulation for 4 more weeks. If a thrombus is present, then cardioversion is delayed by 3 weeks.

Direct-acting oral anticoagulants (DOACs) are preferred over warfarin for anticoagulation. However, warfarin is the preferred drug if the patient has a mechanical prosthetic valve, advanced CKD or moderate-severe mitral stenosis.

Apart from anticoagulation, the most important aspect of the treatment of chronic AF is rate control. The drugs used for this are β blockers (such as metoprolol) and calcium channel blockers (such as diltiazem and verapamil). Reversion to sinus rhythm can be done electrically or using medications. Pharmacological cardioversion can be done using ibutilide, dofetilide and amiodarone (class III antiarryhthmics- Option A) or flecainide and propafenone (class Ic drugs).

Atrial fibrillation rhythm is irregularly irregular. P waves are absent, these irregular waves are known as fibrillation waves, characteristic of atrial fibrillation.

Other options:

Option C: Adenosine is the first-line drug for Supraventricular tachycardia. It blocks conduction across the AV node and terminates the SVT. It is given as a 6-18 mg bolus

questions.text:
A patient presents with vision problems and has a history of cataract surgery. OCT findings are given. What is the syndrome associated with these findings?

OCT- Optical coherence tomography
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a patient with a history of cataract surgery and an OCT showing intraretinal cystoid spaces is suggestive of Cystoid Macular Edema (CME) in the setting of Irvine-Gass syndrome. It occurs due to the accumulation of dye in the macular region.

CME is defined as a collection of fluid between the outer plexiform (Henle's layer) and an inner nuclear layer of the retina. This results in the formation of cyst-like cavities around the foveola. It occurs due to a break in the inner and outer blood-retinal barrier. 

Common causes of CME include uveitis, previous cataract surgery (Irvine-Gass syndrome), retinal vein occlusions, diabetic retinopathy, and retinitis pigmentosa.

Irvine-Gass syndrome is the late postoperative complications of cataract surgery. The characteristic flower-petal appearance is due to the accumulation of dye in the outer plexiform layer at the fovea. CME occurs due to a break in the inner and outer blood-retinal barrier.

Patients may complain of blurring, distortion, and micropsia. In clinically established cases, the macula will show a 'honeycomb' appearance on ophthalmoscopy due to multiple cystoid spaces. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) image shows intraretinal cystoid spaces and foveal depression. In advanced cases, a lamellar macular hole may develop.

Treatment includes topical anti-prostaglandins (ketorolac), steroids, systemic carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (oral acetazolamide), and managing the causative factor. 

Given below is the FFA image showing the classic flower-petal appearance, followed by an OCT image showing intraretinal cystoid spaces in CME:

A few other late postoperative complications of cataract surgery include,

  • Delayed chronic postoperative endophthalmitis
  • Pseudophakic bullous keratopathy
  • Retinal detachment
  • After cataract or secondary cataract

Other options:

Option A: Central serous retinopathy is the spontaneous serous detachment of the macular region neurosensory retina with/without retinal pigment epithelium detachment. Patients complain of sudden onset painless loss of vision, micropsia, and metamorphopsia. FFA shows two patterns of leakage, ink-blot pattern and smoke-stick pattern. OCT image of central serous retinopathy is seen below which neurosensory retinal detachment and accompanying small detachments of the retinal pigment epithelium.

Option B: Posner–Schlossman syndrome is characterized by recurrent unilateral acute raised intraocular pressure (IOP) (>40 mmHg) changes, with mild anterior uveitis. It is also known as glaucomatocyclitic crisis or hypertensive uveitis.

Option D: Elschnig’s pearls are where the subcapsular epithelial cells proliferate and develop into vacuolated soap bubble like clusters along the posterior capsule. It is a type of after-cataract/ secondary cataract or posterior capsular opacification, which is a late postoperative complication that follows extracapsular extraction of the lens.

questions.text: The patient came to the ER with pain on the left side of the chest radiating to the left arm and shoulder for the last 40 minutes. ECG shows ST depression in precordial leads. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient coming to the ER with pain on the left side of the chest radiating to the left arm and shoulder for the last 40 minutes. ECG showing ST depression in precordial leads is suggestive of NSTEMI(Non-ST elevation Myocardial infarction) and the next best step in management is low-dose aspirin with clopidogrel.

Acute coronary syndrome is classified into 2 groups:

  • ST-segment Elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI).
  • NSTE-ACS.

NSTE-ACS further includes:

  • NSTEMI (myocyte necrosis present and cardiac troponins elevated).
  • Unstable Angina (myocyte necrosis absent and cardiac troponins not elevated).

The diagnosis of NSTE-ACS is based on the following:

Severe chest discomfort with at least one of 3 features:

  • Occurring at rest or minimal exertion and lasting for more than 10 minutes
  • Recent onset
  • Crescendo pattern

ECG showing:

  • ST segment depression
  • T wave inversion

Elevated cardiac troponins in case of NSTEMI.

Management of NSTE-ACS:

To provide relief of pain and discomfort, initial treatment includes bed rest, nitrates, beta-blockers, and inhaled oxygen (only if arterial O2 saturation <90%).

Antithrombotic therapy consisting of antiplatelet and anticoagulant drugs:

  • Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT): Aspirin (162-325 mg) AND one ADP receptor inhibitor (Ticagrelor, clopidogrel or prasugrel).
  • Anticoagulation: Enoxaparin, unfractionated heparin, fondaparinux or bivalirudin.
  • An early invasive strategy including diagnostic coronary angiography (within 2–72 hours of presentation) followed by revascularization. (percutaneous coronary intervention/ coronary artery bypass grafting) is indicated for stabilized patients who are at high risk of coronary events (Based on TIMI, GRACE or HEART score).

questions.text: A person presents with complaints of numbness, tingling and paresthesias of the thumb, index finger and middle finger. There is numbness at the dorsum of the base of the thumb as well. What structure is most likely to be damaged?
questions.solution:
Patient presents with pain and paresthesia over the lateral 3 and a half digits and numbness at the dorsum of the base of the thumb, both of which are indicative of a median nerve injury.

There may be weakness of thumb opposition. In chronic cases, the thenar eminence is wasted. Carpal tunnel syndrome is a common cause and can be associated with rheumatoid arthritis, pregnancy, chronic renal failure, acromegaly, hypothyroidism and gout. The diagnosis is usually made on clinical grounds but nerve conduction studies can confirm the diagnosis.

Median nerve injuries:

Distal injury: Thus an injury to the distal median nerve affects the 1st and 2nd lumbricals sparing the flexor digitorum profundus. This causes hyperextension at the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion at the interphalangeal joints, involving the index and middle fingers. This attitude of the hand known as the median claw hand may be seen at rest and is more pronounced on attempting to extend the fingers (attitude is similar to proximal ulnar injury).

Proximal injury: Since the opposing flexor digitorum profundus of the 2nd and 3rd digit that causes the clawing is also affected, the clawing of the hand is less pronounced in distal injuries of the ulnar nerve. The deficits present during voluntary flexion of the digits. Thus, on attempting to make a fist, the flexion of the 2nd and 3rd digits is affected while the 4th and 5th digits are normal giving the Benediction hand sign.

In both cases of median nerve palsy, there is loss of sensations on lateral 3½ digits including the nail beds and distal phalanges on the dorsum of the hand.

Tinel's sign is positive where percussing over the median nerve reproduces symptoms. Phalen's test is positive where the symptoms are reproduced by holding the wrists in full flexion with the dorsum of the hands pressed together.

Other Options: 

Option A: Injury to the anterior interosseous nerve, a branch of the median nerve. It results in the loss of function of both flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) and flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS). Hence, the index finger sticks out when the patient is asked to clasp their hand. 

Option B: In ulnar nerve palsy, only the medial two fingers develop clawing, while in a combined median and ulnar nerve palsy, all four fingers develop clawing. 

Option C:  In radial nerve palsy, the patient presents with 'wrist drop' in case of paralyzed wrist extensors, and 'finger drop' when extensor digitorum is paralyzed. When there is compression in the axilla, radial nerve palsy is called Saturday night palsy. There is paralysis of the triceps, and weakness of the wrist and hand. In high lesions, there is sensory loss on the dorsum of the hand over the anatomical stuff box.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child was eating peanuts when he suddenly developed respiratory distress, cough, and was unable to speak. What is the initial treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
In a choking child (more than 1 year old) or an adult, the first step to be done is to perform Heimlich maneuver, which involves delivering abdominal thrusts.

The rescuer should stand or kneel behind the patient and wrap his arms around the patient’s waist. A fist is made with one hand and using the other hand, the fist is driven into the patient’s abdomen with a rapid, forceful upward thrust so as to dislodge the foreign body. This is continued until the foreign body is expelled or if the patient becomes unresponsive.

If the patient becomes unresponsive, immediately start CPR.

In a choking infant who is responsive, 5 back slaps between the shoulder blades and 5 downward thrusts on the chest are given in order to dislodge the foreign body.

If the patient becomes unresponsive, immediately start CPR.

Other Options:

Option A: The blind finger sweep should be avoided in infants to avoid pushing the object further inside the airway. However, it can be done for unresponsive adults with complete FBAO. With the patient's face up, the mouth is opened by grasping both the tongue and lower jaw and lifting the mandible. The index finger is inserted along the inside of the cheek and using a hooking action, the foreign body is dislodged and removed.

Option B: Endoscopic removal is wrong as an initial treatment because it's not an immediate life-saving measure and requires time to set up and organize. It can be attempted once the airway is stabilized. 

Option C: Immediate X-ray is wrong as initial treatment because it delays essential life-saving intervention. Not all foreign bodies are radio-opaque (especially peanuts) and the patient needs immediate intervention for respiratory distress.

questions.text:
A patient presented with the lesion shown in the image. Which of the following will have least priority in calculating the prognosis in this patient?

MRND-Modified radical neck dissection
questions.solution:
The given image dipicts a patient with carcinoma of the lower lip and most likely has a squamous cell carcinoma of the lip. Duration of the lesion will not have any affect on the prognosis.

The factors that affect prognosis are:

  1. The biological behavior and histological grade (Option A)
  2. Extent or depth of invasion (Option B)
  3. Anatomical considerations like the site of the lesion (Option C)

Lip cancer most commonly occurs in men from 50 to 70 years old but can be seen in younger patients. Risk factors include sunlight exposure, smoking, and tobacco use. Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of lip cancer. But commonly occurring cancer in the upper lip is basal cell carcinoma.

Most lip cancers occur in the lower lip followed by the upper lip and commissure. The most common site is the vermilion border of the lower lip. Ulcerative lesion on the vermilion border of the lower lip is the most common clinical manifestation. Mass can extend and fix on the underlying bone. Loss of sensation over the chin indicates mental nerve involvement. The most frequently involved nodes are the submental and submandibular nodes.

Surgical resection (wide local excision with negative margins) is the preferred treatment modality. The typical lip length is 6 to 7 cm. For defects of <1/3rd of the lip, resection with primary closure is the preferred treatment.

For defects of more than 1/3rd of the lip, require local flaps for reconstruction after resection:

  • Johansen step technique- local flap for large central defects 
  • Lip-switch (Abbe-Estlander) flap- based on the sublabial or superior labial artery. When the defect involves only the commissure, the Estlander flap is used, and the Abbé flap is used for midline defects. Abbe-Estlander Flap is used for mixed defects. The markings of the Abbe-Estlander flap are shown below.
  • Karapandzic flap - circumoral advancement flap. It is a neuromuscular flap that includes the remaining orbicularis oris muscle with its innervation.

In the presence of neck metastasis, neck dissection is indicated. Postoperative radiation is administered to patients with positive margins, lymph node metastases, tumor thickness >4mm, or perineural invasion. If the mandible is involved, mandibulectomy and free flap reconstruction is required.

Related Pearl: TNM staging of oral cavity cancer - AJCC 8th edition
