questions.text:
The patient came to the ER with pain on the left side of the chest radiating to the left arm and shoulder following exercise. The pain subsided after some time. What is the next step in management?

ECG-Electro cardio graphy
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient coming to the ER with pain on the left side of the chest radiating to the left arm and shoulder can be suggestive of ACS (Acute Coronary Syndrome), and the next best step in management is doing an ECG.

Acute coronary syndromes (ACS) includes:

  • Unstable angina(UA)
  • Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction(NSTEMI)
  • ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)

The diagnosis of ACS can be based on the ECG findings-:

STEMI-  Features of MI on ECG:

  • ST-segment elevation: Zone of injury
  • T wave inversions
  • Deep Q waves: late sign to develop
  • New left bundle branch block (LBBB)

 

NSTEMI- Features of NSTEMI on ECG (Troponins are elevated)

  •  ST-segment depression
  • Deep T-wave inversions

Unstable Angina - Features of Unstable Angina on ECG (Troponins are not elevated)

  • Hyperacute T-wave
  • T-wave flattening
  • Inverted T-waves
  • ST depression

The following protocol must be followed in the management of patients with acute coronary syndrome:

  1. Stabilization of airway, breathing, and circulation
  2. Administration of O2
  3. Treatment of sustained ventricular arrhythmia rapidly according to ACLS protocols
  4. Give aspirin 325 mg
  5. History and examination, assess cardiac biomarkers
  6. Give three sublingual nitroglycerin tablets each 5 min apart. Add IV nitroglycerin for the persistence of symptoms.
  7. Treat left heart failure if present with an after-load reducing agent or loop diuretic
  8. Give beta-blockers
  9. Give morphine for the persistence of anxiety and discomfort related to MI
  10. In patients with STEMI - Reperfusion with PCI or fibrinolysis (if PCI is unavailable within 120 min) followed by antiplatelet and anticoagulant therapy. In patients with NSTEMI - antiplatelet and anticoagulant therapy are indicated.

Related Pearl: Localisation of MI based on ST elevations in different leads

Extensive anterior - I, aVL, V1-V6

Lateral - I, aVL

Inferior - II, III, aVF

Anteroseptal - V1-V4

Anterolateral - I, aVL, V3-V6

Posterior - ST depression and tall R in V1-V4

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man with a known case of rheumatic heart disease presents with SOB. On examination, hyperdynamic precordium is noted with a water hammer pulse, and a pistol shot sound over femoral arteries is heard. Auscultation shows pan systolic murmur and early diastolic murmur. Which is the predominant valvular lesion shown below?

Shortness of breath- SOB
questions.solution:
The predominant valvular lesion is aortic regurgitation. The water hammer pulse and pistol shot sounds over the femoral arteries suggest high-pressure blood flow due to aortic insufficiency. The pan systolic murmur indicates mitral regurgitation, while the early diastolic murmur is characteristic of aortic regurgitation, often seen in rheumatic heart disease.

Aortic regurgitation (AR) is a valvular disease of the aortic valve caused by primary valve disease, aortic root disease or their combination.

Auscultatory findings in AR are:

  • Soft S1 - due to the early closure of the mitral valve
  • Diminished or absent A2
  • S3 - due to increased left ventricular (LV) end-diastolic volume. The presence of S3 may be a sign of impaired LV function.
  • Early diastolic murmur -
    • High-pitched, blowing, decrescendo, early diastolic murmur.
    • Best heard in the left-third intercostal space.
    • Heard the patient sitting up and leaning forward, with breath held in forced expiration.
    • The duration of the murmur best correlates with the severity.
  • Systolic ejection murmur - It is heard due to increased LV stroke volume and ejection rate.
  • Austin Flint murmur - a low-pitched, mid to late diastolic murmur. It is caused due to the large volume of regurgitant blood, hitting the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve or LV wall.

Other signs :

  • Pulsations of the spleen, detected in the presence of splenomegaly are called Gerhardt’s sign. (Option B)
  • The Rosenbach sign is seen in AR where pulsations are felt over the liver (Option A)
  • Becker's sign is the presence of retinal artery pulsation on fundoscopy. (Option C)
  • Systolic pulsations of the uvula are known as Muller's sign. (Option D)

Treatment of aortic regurgitation:

  • In non-severe AR, periodic monitoring can be done. The symptoms of dyspnea and decreased cardiac output can be managed by diuretics and vasodilators.
  • In severe AR, surgery is indicated in the following conditions:
    • The patient is symptomatic
    • The patient is asymptomatic, but the LV ejection fraction is less than 50% or LV end-diastolic diameter is more than 65mm.
    • The patient is asymptomatic and undergoing other cardiac surgeries.

Related Pearl: Different signs in Aortic Regurgitation

Sign

Description

  Head nodding with each heartbeat

 It is a bounding pulse with rapid upstroke  and descent

  Alternate flushing & blanching of the forehead

  Alternating constriction and dilation of the pupil

  Retinal artery pulsations

 Alternate flushing and paling of the skin at the root of the nail while pressure is applied to the tip of the nail
